Text

One evening of late summer , before the nineteenth century had reached one - third of its span , [a young man]285-a young man and [woman]286-woman , [the latter carrying]287-the latter carrying [a child]288-a child , were approaching [the large village of [Weydon - Priors]1-weydon - priors]289-the large village of weydon - priors , in [Upper Wessex]2-upper wessex , on foot . [They]290-their were plainly but not ill clad , though the thick hoar of dust which had accumulated on [their]290-their shoes and garments from an obviously long journey lent a disadvantageous shabbiness to [their]290-their appearance just now . [The man]291-the man was of fine figure , swarthy , and stern in aspect ; and [he]291-the man showed in profile a facial angle so slightly inclined as to be almost perpendicular . [He]291-the man wore a short jacket of brown corduroy , newer than the remainder of [his]291-the man suit , which was a fustian waistcoat with white horn buttons , breeches of the same , tanned leggings , and a straw hat overlaid with black glazed canvas . At [his]291-the man back [he]291-the man carried by a looped strap a rush basket , from which protruded at one end the crutch of a hay - knife , a wimble for hay - bonds being also visible in the aperture . [His]291-the man measured , springless walk was the walk of [the skilled countryman]292-the skilled countryman as distinct from the desultory shamble of [the general labourer]293-the general labourer ; while in the turn and plant of each foot there was , further , a dogged and cynical indifference personal to [himself]291-the man , showing its presence even in the regularly interchanging fustian folds , now in the left leg , now in the right , as [he]291-the man paced along . What was really peculiar , however , in [this couple]294-this couple 's progress , and would have attracted the attention of [any casual observer]295-any casual observer otherwise disposed to overlook [them]294-this couple , was the perfect silence [they]294-this couple preserved . [They]294-this couple walked side by side in such a way as to suggest afar off the low , easy , confidential chat of [people full of reciprocity]296-people full of reciprocity ; but on closer view it could be discerned that [the man]291-the man was reading , or pretending to read , a ballad sheet which [he]291-the man kept before [his]291-the man eyes with some difficulty by the hand that was passed through the basket strap . Whether this apparent cause were the real cause , or whether it were an assumed one to escape an intercourse that would have been irksome to [him]291-the man , [[nobody]298-nobody but [himself]291-the man]299-nobody but himself could have said precisely ; but [his]291-the man taciturnity was unbroken , and [the woman]300-the woman enjoyed no society whatever from [his]291-the man presence . Virtually [she]300-the woman walked [the highway]301-the highway alone , save for [the child [she]300-the woman bore]302-the child she bore . Sometimes [the man]291-the man 's bent elbow almost touched [her]300-the woman shoulder , for [she]300-the woman kept as close to [his]291-the man side as was possible without actual contact , but [she]300-the woman seemed to have no idea of taking [his]291-the man arm , nor [he]291-the man of offering it ; and far from exhibiting surprise at [his]291-the man ignoring silence [she]300-the woman appeared to receive it as a natural thing . If any word at all were uttered by [the little group]304-the little group , it was an occasional whisper of [the woman]300-the woman to [the child]306-the child — [a tiny girl in short clothes and blue boots of knitted yarn]307-a tiny girl in short clothes and blue boots of knitted yarn — and the murmured babble of [the child]306-the child in reply . [The chief — almost the only — attraction of]309-the chief — almost the only — attraction of [the young woman]310-the young woman 's face was its mobility . When [she]300-the woman looked down sideways to [the girl]311-the girl [she]300-the woman became pretty , and even handsome , particularly that in the action [her]300-the woman features caught slantwise the rays of the strongly coloured sun , which made transparencies of [her]300-the woman eyelids and nostrils and set fire on [her]300-the woman lips . When [she]300-the woman plodded on in the shade of the hedge , silently thinking , [she]300-the woman had the hard , half - apathetic expression of [one who deems anything possible at the hands of Time and Chance except , perhaps , fair play]312-one who deems anything possible at the hands of time and chance except , perhaps , fair play . The first phase was the work of Nature , the second probably of civilization . That [the man]291-the man and [woman]286-woman were [husband]315-husband and [wife]316-wife , and [the parents of [the girl in arms]318-the girl in arms]317-the parents of the girl in arms there could be little doubt . No other than such relationship would have accounted for the atmosphere of stale familiarity which [the trio]319-the trio carried along with [them]319-the trio like a nimbus as [they]319-the trio moved down [the road]320-the road . [The wife]321-the wife mostly kept [her]321-the wife eyes fixed ahead , though with little interest — the scene for that matter being one that might have been matched at almost any spot in [[any county]322-any county in [England]3-england]323-any county in england at this time of the year ; [a road neither straight nor crooked , neither level nor hilly]324-a road neither straight nor crooked , neither level nor hilly , bordered by hedges , trees , and other vegetation , which had entered the blackened - green stage of colour that the doomed leaves pass through on [their]319-the trio way to dingy , and yellow , and red . The grassy margin of [the bank]325-the bank , and the nearest hedgerow boughs , were powdered by the dust that had been stirred over [them]319-the trio by [hasty vehicles]326-hasty vehicles , the same dust as it lay on [the road]320-the road deadening [their]319-the trio footfalls like a carpet ; and this , with the aforesaid total absence of conversation , allowed every extraneous sound to be heard . For a long time there was none , beyond the voice of a weak bird singing a trite old evening song that might doubtless have been heard on [the hill]328-the hill at the same hour , and with the self - same trills , quavers , and breves , at any sunset of that season for centuries untold . But as [they]319-the trio approached [the village]329-the village sundry distant shouts and rattles reached [their]319-the trio ears from some elevated spot in that direction , as yet screened from view by foliage . When [the outlying houses of [Weydon - Priors]1-weydon - priors]330-the outlying houses of weydon - priors could just be described , [the family group]331-the family group was met by [a turnip - hoer with [his]332-a turnip - hoer with his hoe on his shoulder hoe on [his]332-a turnip - hoer with his hoe on his shoulder shoulder]332-a turnip - hoer with his hoe on his shoulder , and [his]332-a turnip - hoer with his hoe on his shoulder dinner - bag suspended from it . [The reader]333-the reader promptly glanced up . “ Any trade doing here ? ”[333-the reader] [he]333-the reader asked phlegmatically , designating [the village]329-the village in [[his]333-the reader van]335-his van by a wave of the broadsheet . And thinking [the labourer]336-the labourer did not understand [him]333-the reader , [he]333-the reader added , “ Anything in the hay - trussing line ? ”[333-the reader] [The turnip - hoer]337-the turnip - hoer had already begun shaking [his]337-the turnip - hoer head . “ Why , save [the man]291-the man , what wisdom 's in [him]291-the man that ' a should come to [Weydon]5-weydon for a job of that sort this time o ' year ? ”[337-the turnip - hoer] “ Then is there any house to let — [a little small new cottage just a builded]4414-a little small new cottage just a builded , or such like ? ”[338-the other] asked [the other]338-the other . [The pessimist]339-the pessimist still maintained a negative . “ Pulling down is more [the nater of [Weydon]5-weydon]4415-the nater of weydon . There were [five houses]4416-five houses cleared away last year , and three this ; and the volk nowhere to go — no , not so much as a thatched hurdle ; that 's the way o ' [Weydon]5-weydon - Priors . ”[339-the pessimist] The hay - trusser , which [he]337-the turnip - hoer obviously was , nodded with some superciliousness . Looking towards [the village]329-the village , [he]337-the turnip - hoer continued , “ There is something going on [here]4417-here , however , is there not ? ”[337-the turnip - hoer] “ Ay . ' Tis Fair Day . Though what [you]4418-you hear now is little more than the clatter and scurry of getting away the money o ' [children]4419-children and [fools]4420-fools , for the real business is done earlier than this . [I]337-the turnip - hoer 've been working within sound o't all day , but [I]337-the turnip - hoer did n't go up — not [I.]337-the turnip - hoer ' Twas no business of [mine]337-the turnip - hoer . ”[337-the turnip - hoer] [The trusser]341-the trusser and [[his]341-the trusser family]342-his family proceeded on [their]342-his family way , and soon entered [the Fair - field]343-the fair - field , which showed standing - places and pens where many hundreds of horses and sheep had been exhibited and sold in the forenoon , but were now in great part taken away . At present , as [[their]342-his family informant]344-their informant had observed , but little real business remained on hand , [the chief]345-the chief being the sale by auction of a few inferior animals , that could not otherwise be disposed of , and had been absolutely refused by [the better class of traders , who came and went early]346-the better class of traders , who came and went early . Yet [the crowd]347-the crowd was denser now than during the morning hours , the frivolous contingent of [visitors]348-visitors , including [journeymen]349-journeymen out for a holiday , [a stray soldier or two]350-a stray soldier or two come on furlough , [village shopkeepers]351-village shopkeepers , and [the like]352-the like , having latterly flocked in ; persons whose activities found a congenial field among the peep - shows , toy - stands , waxworks , [inspired monsters]353-inspired monsters , [disinterested medical men who travelled for the public good]354-disinterested medical men who travelled for the public good , [thimble - riggers]355-thimble - riggers , [nick - nack vendors]356-nick - nack vendors , and [readers of Fate]357-readers of fate . [Neither of [[our]359-our pedestrians]360-our pedestrians]358-neither of our pedestrians had much heart for these things , and [they]342-his family looked around for [a refreshment tent among the many which dotted the down]361-a refreshment tent among the many which dotted the down . Two , which stood nearest to [them]342-his family in the ochreous haze of expiring sunlight , seemed almost equally inviting . One was formed of new , milk - hued canvas , and bore red flags on [its]362-its summit ; it announced “ Good Home - brewed Beer , Ale , and [Cyder]118-cyder . ”[300-the woman] The other was less new ; a little iron stove - pipe came out of it at the back and in front appeared the placard , “ Good Furmity Sold Hear . ”[291-the man] [The man]291-the man mentally weighed the two inscriptions and inclined to [the former tent]364-the former tent . “ No — no — the other one , ”[300-the woman] said [the woman]300-the woman . “ [I]300-the woman always like furmity ; and so does [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard ; and so will [you]291-the man . It is nourishing after a long hard day . ”[300-the woman] “ [I]291-the man 've never tasted it , ”[291-the man] said [the man]291-the man . However , [he]291-the man gave way to [her]300-the woman representations , and [they]342-his family entered the furmity booth forthwith . [A rather numerous company]367-a rather numerous company appeared within , seated at the long narrow tables that ran down [the tent]368-the tent on each side . At the upper end stood a stove , containing a charcoal fire , over which hung a large three - legged crock , sufficiently polished round the rim to show that it was made of bell - metal . [A haggish creature of about fifty presided]369-a haggish creature of about fifty presided , in a white apron , which as it threw an air of respectability over [her]300-the woman as far as it extended , was made so wide as to reach nearly round [her]300-the woman waist . [She]300-the woman slowly stirred the contents of the pot . The dull scrape of [her]300-the woman large spoon was audible throughout [the tent]368-the tent as [she]300-the woman thus kept from burning the mixture of corn in the grain , flour , milk , raisins , currants , and what not , that composed the antiquated slop in which [she]300-the woman dealt . Vessels holding the separate ingredients stood on a white - clothed table of boards and trestles close by . [The young man]371-the young man and [woman]286-woman ordered a basin each of the mixture , steaming hot , and sat down to consume it at leisure . This was very well so far , for furmity , as [the woman]300-the woman had said , was nourishing , and as proper a food as could be obtained within the four seas ; though , to [those not accustomed to it]374-those not accustomed to it , the grains of wheat swollen as large as lemon - pips , which floated on its surface , might have a deterrent effect at first . But there was more in [that tent]375-that tent than met the cursory glance ; and [the man , with the instinct of a perverse character]376-the man , with the instinct of a perverse character , scented it quickly . After a mincing attack on [his]291-the man bowl , [he]291-the man watched [the hag]377-the hag 's proceedings from the corner of [his]291-the man eye , and saw the game [she]300-the woman played . [He]291-the man winked to [her]300-the woman , and passed up [his]291-the man basin in reply to [her]300-the woman nod ; when [she]300-the woman took a bottle from under the table , slily measured out a quantity of its contents , and tipped the same into [the man]291-the man 's furmity . The liquor poured in was rum . [The man]291-the man as slily sent back money in payment . [He]291-the man found the concoction , thus strongly laced , much more to [his]291-the man satisfaction than it had been in its natural state . [[His]291-the man wife]380-his wife had observed the proceeding with much uneasiness ; but [he]291-the man persuaded [her]300-the woman to have hers laced also , and [she]300-the woman agreed to a milder allowance after some misgiving . [The man]291-the man finished [his]291-the man basin , and called for another , the rum being signalled for in yet stronger proportion . The effect of it was soon apparent in [his]291-the man manner , and [[his]291-the man wife]380-his wife but too sadly perceived that in strenuously steering off the rocks of [the licensed liquor - tent]383-the licensed liquor - tent [she]300-the woman had only got into maelstrom depths here amongst [the smugglers]384-the smugglers . [The child]306-the child began to prattle impatiently , and [the wife]321-the wife more than once said to [[her]321-the wife husband]387-her husband , “ [Michael]120-henchard , how about [[our]4421-we lodging]4422-our lodging ? [You]120-henchard know [we]4421-we may have trouble in getting it if [we]4421-we do n't go soon . ”[321-the wife] But [he]291-the man turned a deaf ear to those bird - like chirpings . [He]291-the man talked loud to [the company]388-the company . [The child]306-the child 's black eyes , after slow , round , ruminating gazes at the candles when they were lighted , fell together ; then they opened , then shut again , and [she]306-the child slept . At the end of the first basin [the man]291-the man had risen to serenity ; at the second [he]291-the man was jovial ; at the third , argumentative , at the fourth , the qualities signified by the shape of [his]291-the man face , the occasional clench of [his]291-the man mouth , and the fiery spark of [his]291-the man dark eye , began to tell in [his]291-the man conduct ; [he]291-the man was overbearing — even brilliantly quarrelsome . The conversation took a high turn , as it often does on such occasions . The ruin of [good men]391-good men by [bad wives]392-bad wives , and , more particularly , the frustration of [many a promising youth]393-many a promising youth 's high aims and hopes and the extinction of [his]291-the man energies by an early imprudent marriage , was the theme . “ [I]341-the trusser did for [myself]341-the trusser that way thoroughly , ”[341-the trusser] said [the trusser]341-the trusser with a contemplative bitterness that was well - night resentful . “ [I]341-the trusser married at eighteen , like [the fool]4423-the fool that [I]341-the trusser was ; and this is the consequence o't . ”[341-the trusser] [He]341-the trusser pointed at [himself]341-the trusser and [family]395-family with a wave of the hand intended to bring out the penuriousness of the exhibition . [The young woman [[his]341-the trusser wife]380-his wife , who seemed accustomed to such remarks , acted as if [she]380-his wife did not hear them , and continued [her]380-his wife intermittent private words of tender trifles to [the sleeping and waking child]398-the sleeping and waking child , who was just big enough to be placed for a moment on the bench beside [her]380-his wife when [she]380-his wife wished to ease [her]380-his wife arms]396-the young woman his wife , who seemed accustomed to such remarks , acted as if she did not hear them , and continued her intermittent private words of tender trifles to the sleeping and waking child , who was just big enough to be placed for a moment on the bench beside her when she wished to ease her arms . [The man]291-the man continued — “ [I]291-the man have n't more than fifteen shillings in [the world]4424-the world , and yet [I]291-the man am [a good experienced hand in [my]291-the man line]4425-a good experienced hand in my line . [I]291-the man 'd challenge [England]3-england to beat [me]291-the man in the fodder business ; and if [I]291-the man were [a free man]4426-a free man again [I]291-the man 'd be worth a thousand pound before [I]291-the man 'd done o't . But [a fellow]4427-a fellow never knows these little things till all chance of acting upon 'em is past . ”[291-the man] [The auctioneer selling the old horses in [the field outside]401-the field outside]400-the auctioneer selling the old horses in the field outside could be heard saying , “ Now this is [the last lot]4428-the last lot — now who 'll take the last lot for a song ? Shall [I]291-the man say forty shillings ? ' Tis [a very promising broodmare]4429-a very promising broodmare , a trifle over five years old , and nothing the matter with the hoss at all , except that [she]4429-a very promising broodmare 's a little holler in the back and had [her]4429-a very promising broodmare left eye knocked out by the kick of another , [[her]4429-a very promising broodmare own sister]4430-her own sister , coming along [the road]320-the road . ”[291-the man] “ For [my]402-the man in the tent part [I]402-the man in the tent do n't see why [men]4432-men who have got [wives]4433-wives and do n't want 'em , should n't get rid of 'em as [these gipsy fellows]4434-these gipsy fellows do [their]4434-these gipsy fellows old horses , ”[402-the man in the tent] said [the man in the tent]402-the man in the tent . “ Why should n't [they]4434-these gipsy fellows put ['em]4435-'em up and sell 'em by auction to [men who are in need of such articles]4436-men who are in need of such articles ? Hey ? Why , begad , [I]402-the man in the tent 'd sell [mine]402-the man in the tent this minute if [anybody]4437-anybody would buy [her]405-the woman , who was by no means ill - favoured ! ”[402-the man in the tent] “ There 's [them]4434-these gipsy fellows that would do that , ”[403-some of the guests] [some of [the guests]404-the guests]403-some of the guests replied , looking at [the woman , who was by no means ill - favoured]405-the woman , who was by no means ill - favoured . “ True , ”[406-a smoking gentleman] said [a smoking gentleman]406-a smoking gentleman , whose coat had the fine polish about the collar , elbows , seams , and shoulder - blades that long - continued friction with grimy surfaces will produce , and which is usually more desired on furniture than on clothes . Standing in the triangular opening which formed the door of [the tent]368-the tent was [a sailor , who , unobserved by the rest]446-a sailor , who , unobserved by the rest , had arrived [there]447-there within the last two or three minutes . A dead silence followed [his]446-a sailor , who , unobserved by the rest affirmation . “ [You]122-henchard say [you]122-henchard do ? ”[432-the husband] asked [the husband]432-the husband , staring at [him]446-a sailor , who , unobserved by the rest . “ [I]449-the sailor say so , ”[449-the sailor] replied [the sailor]449-the sailor . “ Saying is one thing , and paying is another . Where 's the money ? ”[449-the sailor] [The sailor]449-the sailor hesitated a moment , looked anew at [the woman]300-the woman , came in , unfolded five crisp pieces of paper , and threw them down upon the tablecloth . They were Bank - of - [England]3-england notes for five pounds . Upon the face of this [he]432-the husband clinked down the shillings severally — one , two , three , four , five . The sight of real money in full amount , in answer to a challenge for the same till then deemed slightly hypothetical had a great effect upon [the spectators]452-the spectators . [Their]452-the spectators eyes became riveted upon the faces of [the chief actors]453-the chief actors , and then upon the notes as [they]452-the spectators lay , weighted by the shillings , on the table . Up to this moment it could not positively have been asserted that [the man]291-the man , in spite of [his]291-the man tantalizing declaration , was really in earnest . [The spectators]452-the spectators had indeed taken the proceedings throughout as a piece of mirthful irony carried to extremes ; and had assumed that , being out of work , [he]291-the man was , as a consequence , out of temper with [the world]4424-the world , and society , and [[his]291-the man nearest kin]457-his nearest kin . But with the demand and response of [real cash]458-real cash the jovial frivolity of the scene departed . A lurid colour seemed to fill [the tent]368-the tent , and change the aspect of all therein . The mirth - wrinkles left [the listeners]460-the listeners ' faces , and [they]460-the listeners waited with parting lips . “ Now , ”[300-the woman] said [the woman]300-the woman , breaking the silence , so that [her]300-the woman low dry voice sounded quite loud , “ before [you]387-her husband go further , [Michael]120-henchard , listen to [me]300-the woman . A stolid look of concern filled [the husband]432-the husband 's face , as if , after all , [he]432-the husband had not quite anticipated this ending ; and [some of [the guests]404-the guests]403-some of the guests laughed . “ Is [she]474-the little girl gone ? ”[432-the husband] [he]432-the husband said . “ Faith , ay ! [He]432-the husband rose and walked to the entrance with the careful tread of one conscious of [his]432-the husband alcoholic load . [Some others]480-some others followed , and [they]480-some others stood looking into the twilight . The difference between the peacefulness of inferior nature and the wilful hostilities of [mankind]481-mankind was very apparent at [this place]482-this place . In contrast with the harshness of the act just ended within [the tent]368-the tent was the sight of several horses crossing [their]480-some others necks and rubbing each other lovingly as [they]480-some others waited in patience to be harnessed for the homeward journey . Outside [the fair]484-the fair , in [the valleys and woods]485-the valleys and woods , all was quiet . The sun had recently set , and [the west heaven]486-the west heaven was hung with rosy cloud , which seemed permanent , yet slowly changed . To watch it was like looking at some grand feat of stagery from [a darkened auditorium]487-a darkened auditorium . In presence of this scene after the other there was a natural instinct to abjure [man]488-man as the blot on [an otherwise kindly universe]489-an otherwise kindly universe ; till it was remembered that all terrestrial conditions were intermittent , and that [mankind]481-mankind might some night be innocently sleeping when these quiet objects were raging loud . “ Where do [the sailor]449-the sailor live ? ”[491-a spectator] asked [a spectator]491-a spectator , when [they]480-some others had vainly gazed around . “ God knows that , ”[492-the man who had seen high life] replied [the man who had seen high life]492-the man who had seen high life . “ [He]449-the sailor 's without doubt [a stranger]4470-a stranger [here]4417-here . ”[492-the man who had seen high life] “ [He]449-the sailor came in about five minutes ago , ”[493-the furmity woman] said [the furmity woman]493-the furmity woman , joining [the rest]494-the rest with [her]493-the furmity woman hands on [her]493-the furmity woman hips . “ And then ' a stepped back , and then ' a looked in again . [The man]291-the man stretched [his]291-the man elbows forward on the table leant [his]291-the man face upon [his]291-the man arms , and soon began to snore . [The furmity seller]501-the furmity seller decided to close for the night , and after seeing the rum - bottles , milk , corn , raisins , etc . , that remained on hand , loaded into [the cart]502-the cart , came to where [the man]291-the man reclined . [She]501-the furmity seller shook [him]291-the man , but could not wake [him]291-the man . Extinguishing the last candle , and lowering the flap of [the tent]368-the tent , [she]501-the furmity seller left it , and drove away .

The morning sun was streaming through the crevices of the canvas when [the man]291-the man awoke . A warm glow pervaded the whole atmosphere of [the marquee]509-the marquee , and a single big blue fly buzzed musically round and round it . Besides the buzz of the fly there was not a sound . [He]291-the man looked about — at the benches — at the table supported by trestles — at [his]291-the man basket of tools — at the stove where the furmity had been boiled — at the empty basins — at some shed grains of wheat — at the corks which dotted the grassy floor . Among the odds and ends [he]291-the man discerned a little shining object , and picked it up . It was [[his]291-the man wife]380-his wife 's ring . A confused picture of the events of the previous evening seemed to come back to [him]291-the man , and [he]291-the man thrust [his]291-the man hand into [his]291-the man breast - pocket . A rustling revealed [the sailor]449-the sailor 's bank - notes thrust carelessly in . This second verification of [his]291-the man dim memories was enough ; [he]291-the man knew now they were not dreams . [He]291-the man remained seated , looking on the ground for some time . “ [I]291-the man must get out of this as soon as [I]291-the man can , ”[291-the man] [he]291-the man said deliberately at last , with the air of one who could not catch [his]291-the man thoughts without pronouncing them . “ [She]380-his wife 's gone — to be sure [she]380-his wife is — gone with [that sailor who bought [her]380-his wife]4483-that sailor who bought her , and [little Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard . [We]4484-we walked [here]4417-here , and [I]291-the man had the furmity , and rum in it — and sold [her]380-his wife . Yes , that 's what 's happened and here am [I.]291-the man Now , what am [I]291-the man to do — am [I]291-the man sober enough to walk , [I]291-the man wonder ? ”[291-the man] [He]291-the man stood up , found that [he]291-the man was in fairly good condition for progress , unencumbered . Next [he]291-the man shouldered [his]291-the man tool basket , and found [he]291-the man could carry it . Then lifting the tent door [he]291-the man emerged into the open air . Here [the man]291-the man looked around with gloomy curiosity . The freshness of the September morning inspired and braced [him]291-the man as [he]291-the man stood . [He]291-the man and [[his]291-the man family]342-his family had been weary when [they]514-they arrived the night before , and [they]514-they had observed but little of [the place]515-the place ; so that [he]291-the man now beheld [it]515-the place as a new thing . [It]515-the place exhibited itself as the top of [an open down]516-an open down , bounded on one extreme by [a plantation]517-a plantation , and approached by [a winding road]518-a winding road . At the bottom stood [the village]329-the village which lent [its]329-the village name to [the upland]520-the upland and the annual fair that was held thereon . [The spot]521-the spot stretched downward into [valleys]522-valleys , and onward to [other uplands]523-other uplands , dotted with barrows , and trenched with the remains of [prehistoric forts]524-prehistoric forts . [The whole scene]525-the whole scene lay under the rays of a newly risen sun , which had not as yet dried a single blade of the heavily dewed grass , whereon the shadows of the yellow and red vans were projected far away , those thrown by the felloe of each wheel being elongated in shape to the orbit of a comet . [All the gipsies and [showmen who had remained on the ground]527-showmen who had remained on the ground]526-all the gipsies and showmen who had remained on the ground lay snug within [[their]526-all the gipsies and showmen who had remained on the ground carts]528-their carts and tents or wrapped in horse - cloths under [them]526-all the gipsies and showmen who had remained on the ground , and were silent and still as death , with the exception of an occasional snore that revealed [their]526-all the gipsies and showmen who had remained on the ground presence . But [the Seven Sleepers]125-the seven sleepers had a dog ; and dogs of the mysterious breeds that [vagrants]529-vagrants own , that are as much like cats as dogs and as much like foxes as cats also lay about [here]4417-here . [A little one]531-a little one started up under one of [the carts]532-the carts , barked as a matter of principle , and quickly lay down again . [He]531-a little one was [the only positive spectator of the hay - trusser]533-the only positive spectator of the hay - trusser 's exit from [the Weydon Fair - field]534-the weydon fair - field . This seemed to accord with [his]531-a little one desire . [He]531-a little one went on in silent thought , unheeding the yellowhammers which flitted about [the hedges]535-the hedges with straws in their bills , the crowns of the mushrooms , and the tinkling of local sheep - bells , whose [wearer had had the good fortune not to be included in the fair]536-wearer had had the good fortune not to be included in the fair . When [he]531-a little one reached [a lane]537-a lane , a good mile from the scene of the previous evening , [the man]291-the man pitched [his]291-the man basket and leant upon a gate . A difficult problem or two occupied [his]291-the man mind . “ Did [I]291-the man tell [my]291-the man name to [anybody]4437-anybody last night , or did n't [I]291-the man tell [my]291-the man name ? ”[291-the man] [he]291-the man said to [himself]291-the man ; and at last concluded that [he]291-the man did not . [His]291-the man general demeanour was enough to show how [he]291-the man was surprised and nettled that [[his]291-the man wife]380-his wife had taken [him]291-the man so literally — as much could be seen in [his]291-the man face , and in the way [he]291-the man nibbled a straw which [he]291-the man pulled from the hedge . [He]291-the man knew that [she]380-his wife must have been somewhat excited to do this ; moreover , [she]380-his wife must have believed that there was some sort of binding force in the transaction . On this latter point [he]291-the man felt almost certain , knowing [her]380-his wife freedom from levity of character , and the extreme simplicity of [her]380-his wife intellect . There may , too , have been enough recklessness and resentment beneath [her]380-his wife ordinary placidity to make [her]380-his wife stifle any momentary doubts . On a previous occasion when [he]291-the man had declared during a fuddle that [he]291-the man would dispose of [her]380-his wife as [he]291-the man had done , [she]380-his wife had replied that [she]380-his wife would not hear [him]291-the man say that many times more before it happened , in the resigned tones of a fatalist .... “ Yet [she]380-his wife knows [I]291-the man am not in [my]291-the man senses when [I]291-the man do that ! ”[291-the man] [he]291-the man exclaimed . “ Well , [I]291-the man must walk about till [I]291-the man find [her]380-his wife .... Seize [her]380-his wife , why did n't [she]380-his wife know better than bring [me]291-the man into this disgrace ! ”[291-the man] [he]291-the man roared out . “ [She]380-his wife was n't queer if [I]291-the man was . ' Tis like [Susan]122-henchard to show such idiotic simplicity . Meek — that meekness has done [me]291-the man more harm than the bitterest temper ! ”[291-the man] When [he]291-the man was calmer [he]291-the man turned to [his]291-the man original conviction that [he]291-the man must somehow find [her]540-her and [[his]291-the man little Elizabeth - [Jane]191-henchard]541-his little elizabeth - jane , and put up with the shame as best [he]291-the man could . It was of [his]291-the man own making , and [he]291-the man ought to bear it . But first [he]291-the man resolved to register an oath , a greater oath than [he]291-the man had ever sworn before : and to do it properly [he]291-the man required a fit place and imagery ; for there was something fetichistic in [this man]542-this man 's beliefs . [He]291-the man shouldered [his]291-the man basket and moved on , casting [his]291-the man eyes inquisitively round upon [the landscape]543-the landscape as [he]291-the man walked , and at the distance of three or four miles perceived [the roofs of [a village]545-a village]544-the roofs of a village and [the tower of [a church]547-a church]546-the tower of a church . [He]291-the man instantly made towards the latter object . [The village]329-the village was quite still , it being that motionless hour of rustic daily life which fills the interval between the departure of [the field - labourers]549-the field - labourers to [their]549-the field - labourers work , and the rising of [[their]549-the field - labourers wives]550-their wives and [daughters]551-daughters to prepare the breakfast for [their]549-the field - labourers return . Hence [he]291-the man reached [the church]552-the church without observation , and the door being only latched [he]291-the man entered . [The hay - trusser]428-the hay - trusser deposited [his]291-the man basket by the font , went up [the nave]554-the nave till [he]291-the man reached the altar - rails , and opening the gate entered [the sacrarium]555-the sacrarium , where [he]291-the man seemed to feel a sense of the strangeness for a moment ; then [he]291-the man knelt upon the footpace . Dropping [his]291-the man head upon the clamped book which lay on the Communion - table , [he]291-the man said aloud — “ [I]291-the man , [Michael Henchard]120-henchard , on this morning of the sixteenth of September , do take an oath before [God]126-god here in [this solemn place]4487-this solemn place that [I]291-the man will avoid all strong liquors for the space of twenty - one years to come , being a year for every year that [I]291-the man have lived . And this [I]291-the man swear upon the book before [me]291-the man ; and may [I]291-the man be strook dumb , blind , and helpless , if [I]291-the man break this [my]291-the man oath ! ”[291-the man] When [he]291-the man had said it and kissed the big book , [the hay - trusser]428-the hay - trusser arose , and seemed relieved at having made a start in a new direction . While standing in [the porch]557-the porch a moment [he]291-the man saw a thick jet of wood smoke suddenly start up from the red chimney of [a cottage near]558-a cottage near , and knew that [the occupant]559-the occupant had just lit [her]559-the occupant fire . [He]291-the man went round to the door , and [the housewife]560-the housewife agreed to prepare [him]291-the man some breakfast for a trifling payment , which was done . Then [he]291-the man started on the search for [[his]291-the man wife]380-his wife and [child]562-child . The perplexing nature of the undertaking became apparent soon enough . Though [he]291-the man examined and inquired , and walked hither and thither day after day , no such characters as those [he]291-the man described had anywhere been seen since the evening of the fair . To add to the difficulty [he]291-the man could gain no sound of [the sailor]449-the sailor 's name . As money was short with [him]291-the man [he]291-the man decided , after some hesitation , to spend [the sailor]449-the sailor 's money in the prosecution of this search ; but it was equally in vain . The truth was that a certain shyness of revealing [his]291-the man conduct prevented [Michael Henchard]120-henchard from following up the investigation with the loud hue - and - cry such a pursuit demanded to render it effectual ; and it was probably for this reason that [he]291-the man obtained no clue , though everything was done by [him]291-the man that did not involve an explanation of the circumstances under which [he]291-the man had lost [her]559-the occupant . Weeks counted up to months , and still [he]291-the man searched on , maintaining [himself]291-the man by small jobs of work in the intervals . By this time [he]291-the man had arrived at [a seaport]565-a seaport , and there [he]291-the man derived intelligence that persons answering somewhat to [his]291-the man description had emigrated a little time before . Then [he]291-the man said [he]291-the man would search no longer , and that [he]291-the man would go and settle in [the district which [he]291-the man had had for some time in [his]291-the man mind]566-the district which he had had for some time in his mind . Next day [he]291-the man started , journeying south - westward , and did not pause , except for nights ' lodgings , till [he]291-the man reached [the town of [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge]567-the town of casterbridge , in [a far distant part of [Wessex]7-wessex]568-a far distant part of wessex .

[The highroad into [the village of [Weydon - Priors]1-weydon - priors]570-the village of weydon - priors]569-the highroad into the village of weydon - priors was again carpeted with dust . The trees had put on as of yore [their]571-their aspect of dingy green , and where [the Henchard family of three]572-the henchard family of three had once walked along , [two persons not unconnected with [the family]574-the family]573-two persons not unconnected with the family walked now . The scene in [its]575-its broad aspect had so much of its previous character , even to the voices and rattle from [the neighbouring village]576-the neighbouring village down , that it might for that matter have been the afternoon following the previously recorded episode . Change was only to be observed in details ; but here it was obvious that a long procession of years had passed by . [One of [the two who walked [the road]320-the road]578-the two who walked the road]577-one of the two who walked the road was [[she]577-one of the two who walked the road who had figured as [the young wife of [Henchard]120-henchard]581-the young wife of henchard on the previous occasion]580-she who had figured as the young wife of henchard on the previous occasion ; now [her]580-she who had figured as the young wife of henchard on the previous occasion face had lost much of its rotundity ; [her]580-she who had figured as the young wife of henchard on the previous occasion skin had undergone a textural change ; and though [her]580-she who had figured as the young wife of henchard on the previous occasion hair had not lost colour it was considerably thinner than heretofore . [[Her]580-she who had figured as the young wife of henchard on the previous occasion companion]583-her companion , also in black , appeared as [a well - formed young woman about eighteen , completely possessed of that ephemeral precious essence youth , which is itself beauty , irrespective of complexion or contour]584-a well - formed young woman about eighteen , completely possessed of that ephemeral precious essence youth , which is itself beauty , irrespective of complexion or contour . A glance was sufficient to inform the eye that this was [[Susan Henchard]122-henchard 's grown - up daughter]585-susan henchard 's grown - up daughter . [They]590-they walked with joined hands , and it could be perceived that this was the act of simple affection . [The daughter]591-the daughter carried in [her]591-the daughter outer hand a withy basket of old - fashioned make ; [the mother]586-the mother a blue bundle , which contrasted oddly with [her]586-the mother black stuff gown . Reaching [the outskirts of [the village]329-the village]593-the outskirts of the village [they]590-they pursued the same track as formerly , and ascended to the fair . Here , too it was evident that the years had told . Certain mechanical improvements might have been noticed in the roundabouts and high - fliers , machines for testing rustic strength and weight , and in the erections devoted to shooting for nuts . But the real business of the fair had considerably dwindled . [The new periodical great markets of [neighbouring towns]596-neighbouring towns]595-the new periodical great markets of neighbouring towns were beginning to interfere seriously with the trade carried on [here]4417-here for centuries . The pens for sheep , the tie - ropes for horses , were about half as long as they had been . The stalls of [tailors]598-tailors , [hosiers]599-hosiers , [coopers , linen - drapers]600-coopers , linen - drapers , and other such trades had almost disappeared , and [the vehicles]601-the vehicles were far less numerous . [The mother]586-the mother and [daughter]603-daughter threaded [the crowd]347-the crowd for some little distance , and then stood still . “ Why did [we]590-they hinder [our]590-they time by coming in [here]4417-here ? [I]605-the maiden thought [you]338-the other wished to get onward ? ”[605-the maiden] said [the maiden]605-the maiden . “ Yes , [[my]338-the other dear]4489-my dear [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard , ”[338-the other] explained [the other]338-the other . “ But [I]338-the other had a fancy for looking up here . ”[338-the other] “ Why ? ”[338-the other] “ It was [here]4417-here [I]338-the other first met with [Newson]191-henchard — on such a day as this . ”[338-the other] “ First met with [father]4491-father [here]4417-here ? The object pointed out was a tripod of sticks stuck into the earth , from which hung a three - legged crock , kept hot by a smouldering wood fire beneath . Over the pot stooped [an old woman haggard , wrinkled , and almost in rags]4503-an old woman haggard , wrinkled , and almost in rags . [She]128-henchard stirred the contents of the pot with a large spoon , and occasionally croaked in a broken voice , “[0-i] Good furmity sold here ! ” It was indeed [the former mistress of [the furmity tent]4505-the furmity tent]4504-the former mistress of the furmity tent — once thriving , cleanly , white - aproned , and chinking with money — now tentless , dirty , owning no tables or benches , and having scarce any customers except [two small whity - brown boys]4506-two small whity - brown boys , who came up and asked for “[0-i] A ha'p'orth , please — good measure , ” which [she]128-henchard served in a couple of chipped yellow basins of commonest clay . “[616-she] [She]616-she was here at that time , ” resumed [Mrs. Newson]128-henchard , making a step as if to draw nearer . “[616-she] Do n't speak to [her]616-she — it is n't respectable ! ” urged [the other]338-the other . “[0-i] [I]0-i will just say a word — [you]191-henchard , [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard , can stay [here]4417-here . ” [The girl]311-the girl was not loth , and turned to some stalls of coloured prints while [[her]311-the girl mother]588-her mother went forward . [The old woman]4510-the old woman begged for [the latter]4511-the latter 's custom as soon as [she]4510-the old woman saw [her]311-the girl , and responded to [Mrs. Henchard - Newson]128-henchard 's request for a pennyworth with more alacrity than [she]4510-the old woman had shown in selling six - pennyworths in [her]4510-the old woman younger days . [[Henchard]128-henchard 's wife]655-henchard 's wife acted for the best , but [she]655-henchard 's wife had involved [herself]655-henchard 's wife in difficulties . A hundred times [she]655-henchard 's wife had been upon the point of telling [[her]655-henchard 's wife daughter]4518-her daughter [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard the true story of [her]655-henchard 's wife life , the tragical crisis of which had been the transaction at [Weydon Fair]8-weydon fair , when [she]655-henchard 's wife was not much older than [the girl now beside [her]655-henchard 's wife]657-the girl now beside her . But [she]655-henchard 's wife had refrained . [An innocent maiden]658-an innocent maiden had thus grown up in the belief that the relations between [the genial sailor]659-the genial sailor and [[her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother were the ordinary ones that [they]661-they had always appeared to be . The risk of endangering [a child]288-a child 's strong affection by disturbing ideas which had grown with [her]191-henchard growth was to [Mrs. Henchard]128-henchard too fearful a thing to contemplate . It had seemed , indeed folly to think of making [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard wise . But [Susan Henchard]122-henchard 's fear of losing [[her]655-henchard 's wife dearly loved daughter]663-her dearly loved daughter 's heart by a revelation had little to do with any sense of wrong - doing on [her]655-henchard 's wife own part . [Her]655-henchard 's wife simplicity — the original ground of [Henchard]122-henchard 's contempt for [her]655-henchard 's wife — had allowed [her]655-henchard 's wife to live on in the conviction that [Newson]128-henchard had acquired a morally real and justifiable right to [her]655-henchard 's wife by [his]659-the genial sailor purchase — though the exact bearings and legal limits of that right were vague . It may seem strange to [sophisticated minds]664-sophisticated minds that [a sane young matron]665-a sane young matron could believe in the seriousness of such a transfer ; and were there not numerous other instances of the same belief the thing might scarcely be credited . But [she]655-henchard 's wife was by no means [the first or last peasant woman who had religiously adhered to [[her]655-henchard 's wife purchaser]667-her purchaser]666-the first or last peasant woman who had religiously adhered to her purchaser , as too many rural records show . The history of [Susan Henchard]122-henchard 's adventures in the interim can be told in two or three sentences . Absolutely helpless [she]655-henchard 's wife had been taken off to [Canada]9-canada where [they]668-they had lived several years without any great worldly success , though [she]655-henchard 's wife worked as hard as [any woman]669-any woman could to keep [[their]668-they cottage]670-their cottage cheerful and well - provided . When [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard was about twelve years old [the three]671-the three returned to [England]3-england , and settled at [Falmouth]10-falmouth , where [Newson]191-henchard made a living for a few years as [boatman]672-boatman and [general handy shoreman]673-general handy shoreman . [He]667-her purchaser then engaged in the [Newfoundland]11-newfoundland trade , and it was during this period that [Susan]122-henchard had an awakening . [A friend to whom [she]655-henchard 's wife confided [her]655-henchard 's wife history]674-a friend to whom she confided her history ridiculed [her]655-henchard 's wife grave acceptance of [her]655-henchard 's wife position ; and all was over with [her]655-henchard 's wife peace of mind . When [Newson]191-henchard came [home]675-home at the end of one winter [he]667-her purchaser saw that the delusion [he]667-her purchaser had so carefully sustained had vanished for ever . There was then a time of sadness , in which [she]655-henchard 's wife told [him]667-her purchaser [her]655-henchard 's wife doubts if [she]655-henchard 's wife could live with [him]667-her purchaser longer . [Newson]191-henchard left [home]675-home again on the [Newfoundland]11-newfoundland trade when the season came round . The vague news of [his]667-her purchaser loss at [sea]677-sea a little later on solved a problem which had become torture to [her]655-henchard 's wife meek conscience . [She]655-henchard 's wife saw [him]667-her purchaser no more . Of [Henchard]120-henchard [they]678-they heard nothing . To [the liege subjects of Labour]679-the liege subjects of labour , [the [England]3-england of those days]680-the england of those days was [a continent]681-a continent , and a mile a geographical degree . [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard developed early into womanliness . One day a month or so after receiving intelligence of [Newson]191-henchard 's death off [the Bank of [Newfoundland]11-newfoundland]682-the bank of newfoundland , when [the girl]311-the girl was about eighteen , [she]311-the girl was sitting on a willow chair in [the cottage [they]678-they still occupied , working twine nets for [the fishermen]685-the fishermen]684-the cottage they still occupied , working twine nets for the fishermen . [[Her]311-the girl mother]588-her mother was in a back corner of [the same room]687-the same room engaged in the same labour , and dropping the heavy wood needle [she]588-her mother was filling [she]588-her mother surveyed [[her]588-her mother daughter]4518-her daughter thoughtfully . The sun shone in at the door upon [the young woman]310-the young woman 's head and hair , which was worn loose , so that the rays streamed into its depths as into a hazel copse . [Her]310-the young woman face , though somewhat wan and incomplete , possessed the raw materials of beauty in a promising degree . There was an under - handsomeness in it , struggling to reveal itself through the provisional curves of immaturity , and the casual disfigurements that resulted from the straitened circumstances of [their]678-they lives . [She]310-the young woman was handsome in the bone , hardly as yet handsome in the flesh . [She]310-the young woman possibly might never be fully handsome , unless the carking accidents of [her]310-the young woman daily existence could be evaded before the mobile parts of [her]310-the young woman countenance had settled to their final mould . The sight of [the girl]311-the girl made [[her]311-the girl mother]588-her mother sad — not vaguely but by logical inference . [They]678-they both were still in that strait - waistcoat of poverty from which [she]588-her mother had tried so many times to be delivered for [the girl]311-the girl 's sake . [The woman]300-the woman had long perceived how zealously and constantly [the young mind of [[her]300-the woman companion]583-her companion]694-the young mind of her companion was struggling for enlargement ; and yet now , in [her]300-the woman eighteenth year , it still remained but little unfolded . The desire — sober and repressed — of [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard 's heart was indeed to see , to hear , and to understand . How could [she]300-the woman become [a woman of wider knowledge]696-a woman of wider knowledge , higher repute — “ better , ”[300-the woman] as [she]300-the woman termed it — this was [her]300-the woman constant inquiry of [[her]311-the girl mother]588-her mother . [She]300-the woman sought further into things than [other girls in [her]300-the woman position]698-other girls in her position ever did , and [[her]311-the girl mother]588-her mother groaned as [she]588-her mother felt [she]588-her mother could not aid in the search . [The sailor , drowned or no]700-the sailor , drowned or no , was probably now lost to [them]701-them ; and [Susan]122-henchard 's staunch , religious adherence to [him]700-the sailor , drowned or no as [[her]300-the woman husband]387-her husband in principle , till [her]300-the woman views had been disturbed by enlightenment , was demanded no more . [She]300-the woman asked [herself]300-the woman whether the present moment , now that [she]300-the woman was [a free woman]703-a free woman again , were not as opportune a one as [she]300-the woman would find in a world where everything had been so inopportune , for making a desperate effort to advance [Elizabeth]191-henchard . To pocket [her]300-the woman pride and search for [the first husband]704-the first husband seemed , wisely or not , the best initiatory step . [He]700-the sailor , drowned or no had possibly drunk [himself]700-the sailor , drowned or no into [[his]700-the sailor , drowned or no tomb]705-his tomb . But [he]700-the sailor , drowned or no might , on the other hand , have had too much sense to do so ; for in [her]300-the woman time with [him]700-the sailor , drowned or no [he]700-the sailor , drowned or no had been given to [bouts]706-bouts only , and was not [a habitual drunkard]707-a habitual drunkard . At any rate , the propriety of returning to [him]700-the sailor , drowned or no , if [he]700-the sailor , drowned or no lived , was unquestionable . The awkwardness of searching for [him]700-the sailor , drowned or no lay in enlightening [Elizabeth]191-henchard , a proceeding which [[her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother could not endure to contemplate . [She]588-her mother finally resolved to undertake the search without confiding to [the girl [her]588-her mother former relations with [Henchard]122-henchard]709-the girl her former relations with henchard , leaving it to [him]700-the sailor , drowned or no if [they]710-they found [him]700-the sailor , drowned or no to take what steps [he]700-the sailor , drowned or no might choose to that end . This will account for [their]710-they conversation at the fair and the half - informed state at which [Elizabeth]191-henchard was led onward . In this attitude [they]710-they proceeded on [their]710-they journey , trusting solely to the dim light afforded of [Henchard]122-henchard 's whereabouts by [the furmity woman]493-the furmity woman . The strictest economy was indispensable . Sometimes [they]710-they might have been seen on foot , sometimes on [farmers]712-farmers ' waggons , sometimes in [carriers]713-carriers ' vans ; and thus [they]710-they drew near to [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge . [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard discovered to [her]191-henchard alarm that [[her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother 's health was not what it once had been , and there was ever and anon in [her]588-her mother talk that renunciatory tone which showed that , but for [the girl]311-the girl , [she]311-the girl would not be very sorry to quit a life [she]311-the girl was growing thoroughly weary of . It was on a Friday evening , near the middle of September and just before dusk , that [they]710-they reached the summit of a hill within a mile of [the place [they]710-they sought]716-the place they sought . There were high banked hedges to [the coach - road]717-the coach - road here , and [they]710-they mounted upon the green turf within , and sat down . [The spot]521-the spot commanded a full view of [the town]632-the town and [[its]632-the town environs]720-its environs . “ What [an old - fashioned place]4530-an old - fashioned place [it]632-the town seems to be ! ”[191-henchard] said [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard , while [[her]191-henchard silent mother]721-her silent mother mused on other things than topography . “ [It]632-the town is huddled all together ; and [it]632-the town is shut in by a square wall of trees , like a plot of garden ground by a box - edging . ”[191-henchard] [Its]632-the town squareness was , indeed , the characteristic which most struck the eye in [this antiquated borough]722-this antiquated borough , [the borough of Casterbridge]723-the borough of casterbridge — at that time , recent as [it]632-the town was , untouched by the faintest sprinkle of modernism . [It]632-the town was compact as a box of dominoes . [It]632-the town had [no suburbs]724-no suburbs — in the ordinary sense . [[Country]725-country and [town]727-town]726-country and town met at a mathematical line . To [birds of the more soaring kind]728-birds of the more soaring kind [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge must have appeared on this fine evening as a mosaic - work of subdued reds , browns , greys , and crystals , held together by a rectangular frame of deep green . To the level eye of humanity it stood as an indistinct mass behind a dense stockade of limes and chestnuts , set in the midst of miles of rotund down and concave field . The mass became gradually dissected by the vision into [towers]729-towers , [gables]730-gables , [chimneys]731-chimneys , and casements , the highest glazings shining bleared and bloodshot with the coppery fire [they]732-they caught from the belt of sunlit cloud in the west . From the centre of each side of [this tree - bound square]733-this tree - bound square ran avenues east , west , and south into the wide expanse of cornland and coomb to the distance of a mile or so . It was by one of [these avenues]734-these avenues that [the pedestrians]735-the pedestrians were about to enter . Before [they]735-the pedestrians had risen to proceed [two men]736-two men passed outside the hedge , engaged in argumentative conversation . “ Why , surely , ”[191-henchard] said [Elizabeth]191-henchard , as [they]736-two men receded , “ [those men]4531-those men mentioned the name of [Henchard]122-henchard in [their]4531-those men talk — the name of [[our]735-the pedestrians relative]653-our relative ? ”[191-henchard] “ [I]128-henchard thought so too , ”[128-henchard] said [Mrs. Newson]128-henchard . “ That seems a hint to [us]735-the pedestrians that [he]122-henchard is still [here]4417-here . ”[128-henchard] “ Yes . ”[191-henchard] “ Shall [I]191-henchard run after [them]4531-those men , and ask [them]4531-those men about [him]122-henchard — — ”[191-henchard] “ No , no , no ! But [we]735-the pedestrians must make private inquiries . ”[191-henchard] Having sufficiently rested [they]737-they proceeded on [their]737-they way at [evenfall]13-evenfall . The dense trees of [the avenue]738-the avenue rendered [the road]320-the road dark as [a tunnel]740-a tunnel , though [the open land on each side]741-the open land on each side was still under a faint daylight , in other words , [they]737-they passed down [a midnight between two gloamings]742-a midnight between two gloamings . The features of [the town]632-the town had a keen interest for [[Elizabeth]191-henchard 's mother]744-elizabeth 's mother , now that the human side came to the fore . Within [the avenue and bank]749-the avenue and bank was a wall more or less discontinuous , and within the wall were packed [the abodes of [the burghers]751-the burghers]750-the abodes of the burghers . Though [the two women]752-the two women did not know it these external features were but [the ancient defences of [the town]632-the town]753-the ancient defences of the town , planted as [a promenade]755-a promenade . The lamplights now glimmered through the engirdling trees , conveying a sense of great smugness and comfort inside , and rendering at the same time [the unlighted country]756-the unlighted country without strangely solitary and vacant in aspect , considering [its]756-the unlighted country nearness to life . The difference between [burgh]757-burgh and champaign was increased , too , by sounds which now reached [them]737-they above others — the notes of a brass band . [The travellers]758-the travellers returned into [the High Street]759-the high street , where there were [timber houses with overhanging stories]760-timber houses with overhanging stories , whose small - paned lattices were screened by dimity curtains on a drawing - string , and under whose bargeboards old cobwebs waved in the breeze . There were [houses of brick - nogging]761-houses of brick - nogging , which derived [their]761-houses of brick - nogging chief support from those adjoining . There were slate roofs patched with tiles , and tile roofs patched with slate , with occasionally a roof of thatch . The agricultural and pastoral character of [the people upon whom [the town]632-the town depended for [its]632-the town existence]762-the people upon whom the town depended for its existence was shown by the class of objects displayed in the shop windows . Scythes , reap - hooks , sheep - shears , bill - hooks , spades , mattocks , and hoes at [the iron - monger]764-the iron - monger 's ; bee - hives , butter - firkins , churns , milking stools and pails , hay - rakes , field - flagons , and seed - lips at [the cooper]765-the cooper 's ; cart - ropes and plough - harness at [the saddler]766-the saddler 's ; [carts]767-carts , wheel - barrows , and mill - gear at [[the wheelwright]768-the wheelwright 's and [machinist]770-machinist 's , [horse - embrocations at the chemist]771-horse - embrocations at the chemist 's]769-the wheelwright 's and machinist 's , horse - embrocations at the chemist 's ; at [the glover]772-the glover 's and [leather - cutter]773-leather - cutter 's , hedging - gloves , [thatchers]774-thatchers ' knee - caps , [ploughmen]775-ploughmen 's leggings , [villagers]776-villagers ' pattens and clogs . [They]777-they came to [a grizzled church]778-a grizzled church , whose massive square tower rose unbroken into the darkening sky , the lower parts being illuminated by the nearest lamps sufficiently to show how completely the mortar from the joints of the stonework had been nibbled out by time and weather , which had planted in the crevices thus made little tufts of stone - crop and grass almost as far up as the very battlements . From [this tower]779-this tower the clock struck eight , and thereupon a bell began to toll with a peremptory clang . The curfew was still rung in [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge , and it was utilized by [the inhabitants]780-the inhabitants as a signal for shutting [[their]780-the inhabitants shops]781-their shops . No sooner did the deep notes of the bell throb between [the house]782-the house - fronts than a clatter of shutters arose through the whole length of [the High Street]759-the high street . In a few minutes business at [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge was ended for the day . Other clocks struck eight from time to time — one gloomily from [the gaol]784-the gaol , another from the gable of [an almshouse]785-an almshouse , with a preparative creak of machinery , more audible than the note of the bell ; a row of tall , varnished case - clocks from [the interior of [a clock - maker]787-a clock - maker 's shop]786-the interior of a clock - maker 's shop joined in one after another just as the shutters were enclosing them , like a row of [actors]788-actors delivering [their]788-actors final speeches before the fall of the curtain ; then chimes were heard stammering out the Sicilian Mariners ' Hymn ; so that [chronologists of the advanced school]789-chronologists of the advanced school were appreciably on [their]789-chronologists of the advanced school way to the next hour before the whole business of [the old one]790-the old one was satisfactorily wound up . [[Her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother , though [her]588-her mother head was bowed , had already caught from the inn - window tones that strangely riveted [her]588-her mother attention , before [the old man]818-the old man 's words , “ [Mr. Henchard]120-henchard , [the Mayor]4556-the mayor , ”[588-her mother] reached [her]588-her mother ears .
