[The interior of [the hotel dining - room]823-the hotel dining - room]822-the interior of the hotel dining - room was spread out before [her]588-her mother , with [its]822-the interior of the hotel dining - room tables , and glass , and plate , and inmates . Facing the window , in the chair of dignity , sat [a man about forty years of age]824-a man about forty years of age ; of heavy frame , large features , and commanding voice ; [his]824-a man about forty years of age general build being rather coarse than compact . [He]824-a man about forty years of age had a rich complexion , which verged on swarthiness , a flashing black eye , and dark , bushy brows and hair . When [he]824-a man about forty years of age indulged in an occasional loud laugh at some remark among [the guests]404-the guests , [his]824-a man about forty years of age large mouth parted so far back as to show to the rays of the chandelier a full score or more of the two - and - thirty sound white teeth that [he]824-a man about forty years of age obviously still could boast of . That laugh was not encouraging to [strangers]826-strangers , and hence it may have been well that it was rarely heard . Many theories might have been built upon it . It fell in well with conjectures of a temperament which would have no pity for weakness , but would be ready to yield ungrudging admiration to greatness and strength . [[Its]827-its producer]828-its producer 's personal goodness , if [he]828-its producer had any , would be of a very fitful cast — an occasional almost oppressive generosity rather than a mild and constant kindness . [[Susan Henchard]122-henchard 's husband]829-susan henchard 's husband — in law , at least — sat before [them]830-them , matured in shape , stiffened in line , exaggerated in traits ; disciplined , thought - marked — in a word , older . [Elizabeth]191-henchard , encumbered with no recollections as [[her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother was , regarded [him]824-a man about forty years of age with nothing more than the keen curiosity and interest which the discovery of such unexpected social standing in [the long - sought relative]832-the long - sought relative naturally begot . [He]824-a man about forty years of age was dressed in an old - fashioned evening suit , an expanse of frilled shirt showing on [his]824-a man about forty years of age broad breast ; jewelled studs , and a heavy gold chain . Three glasses stood at [his]824-a man about forty years of age right hand ; but , to [[his]824-a man about forty years of age wife]380-his wife 's surprise , the two for wine were empty , while the third , a tumbler , was half full of water . When last [she]380-his wife had seen [him]824-a man about forty years of age [he]824-a man about forty years of age was sitting in a corduroy jacket , fustian waistcoat and breeches , and tanned leather leggings , with a basin of hot furmity before [him]824-a man about forty years of age . Time , [the magician]834-the magician , had wrought much here . Watching [him]824-a man about forty years of age , and thus thinking of past days , [she]380-his wife became so moved that [she]380-his wife shrank back against the jamb of the waggon - office doorway to which the steps gave access , the shadow from it conveniently hiding [her]380-his wife features . [She]380-his wife forgot [[her]380-his wife daughter]4518-her daughter till a touch from [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard aroused [her]380-his wife . “ Have [you]380-his wife seen [him]824-a man about forty years of age , [mother]4495-mother ? ”[311-the girl] whispered [the girl]311-the girl . “ Yes , yes , ”[311-the girl] answered [[her]380-his wife companion]583-her companion hastily . “ [I]311-the girl have seen [him]824-a man about forty years of age , and it is enough for [me]311-the girl ! Now [I]311-the girl only want to go — pass away — die . ”[311-the girl] “ Why — O what ? ”[311-the girl] [She]311-the girl drew closer , and whispered in [[her]311-the girl mother]588-her mother 's ear , “ Does [he]824-a man about forty years of age seem to [you]588-her mother not likely to befriend [us]4560-us ? [I]311-the girl thought [he]824-a man about forty years of age looked [a generous man]4561-a generous man . What [a gentleman]4562-a gentleman [he]824-a man about forty years of age is , is n't [he]824-a man about forty years of age ? and how [his]824-a man about forty years of age diamond studs shine ! How strange that [you]588-her mother should have said [he]824-a man about forty years of age might be in the stocks , or in [the workhouse]4535-the workhouse , or dead ! Did ever anything go more by contraries ! Why do [you]588-her mother feel so afraid of [him]824-a man about forty years of age ? [I]311-the girl am not at all ; [I]311-the girl 'll call upon [him]824-a man about forty years of age — [he]824-a man about forty years of age can but say [he]824-a man about forty years of age do n't own [such remote kin]4564-such remote kin . ”[311-the girl] “ [I]311-the girl do n't know at all — [I]311-the girl ca n't tell what to set about . [I]311-the girl feel so down . ”[311-the girl] “ Do n't be that , [mother]4495-mother , now [we]4566-we have got here and all ! Rest there where [you]588-her mother be a little while — [I]311-the girl will look on and find out more about [him]824-a man about forty years of age . ”[311-the girl] “ [I]311-the girl do n't think [I]311-the girl can ever meet [Mr. Henchard]120-henchard . [He]824-a man about forty years of age is not how [I]311-the girl thought [he]824-a man about forty years of age would be — [he]824-a man about forty years of age overpowers [me]311-the girl ! [I]311-the girl do n't wish to see [him]824-a man about forty years of age any more . ”[311-the girl] “ But wait a little time and consider . ”[191-henchard] [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard had never been so much interested in anything in [her]191-henchard life as in [their]839-their present position , partly from the natural elation [she]191-henchard felt at discovering [herself]191-henchard akin to [a coach]840-a coach ; and [she]191-henchard gazed again at the scene . [The younger guests]841-the younger guests were talking and eating with animation ; [[their]839-their elders]842-their elders were searching for titbits , and sniffing and grunting over [their]839-their plates like sows nuzzling for acorns . Three drinks seemed to be sacred to [the company]388-the company — port , sherry , and rum ; outside which old - established trinity few or no palates ranged . A row of ancient rummers with ground figures on [their]839-their sides , and each primed with a spoon , was now placed down the table , and these were promptly filled with grog at such high temperatures as to raise serious considerations for the articles exposed to its vapours . But [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard noticed that , though this filling went on with great promptness up and down the table , [nobody]298-nobody filled [the Mayor]4556-the mayor 's glass , who still drank large quantities of water from the tumbler behind the clump of crystal vessels intended for wine and spirits . “ [They]839-their do n't fill [Mr. Henchard]120-henchard 's wine - glasses , ”[191-henchard] [she]191-henchard ventured to say to [[her]191-henchard elbow acquaintance]846-her elbow acquaintance , [the old man]818-the old man . “ Ah , no ; do n't [ye]818-the old man know [him]818-the old man to be [the celebrated abstaining worthy of that name]4567-the celebrated abstaining worthy of that name ? [He]818-the old man scorns all tempting liquors ; never touches nothing . O yes , [he've]818-the old man strong qualities that way . [I]848-another elderly man have heard tell that [he]818-the old man sware a gospel oath in bygone times , and has bode by it ever since . So [they]839-their do n't press [him]818-the old man , knowing it would be unbecoming in the face of that : for [yer]818-the old man gospel oath is a serious thing . ”[848-another elderly man] [Another elderly man]848-another elderly man , hearing this discourse , now joined in by inquiring , “ How much longer have [he]818-the old man got to suffer from it , [Solomon Longways]131-longways ? ”[848-another elderly man] “ Another two year , [they]839-their say . [I]848-another elderly man do n't know the why and the wherefore of [his]818-the old man fixing such a time , for ' a never has told [anybody]4437-anybody . But ' tis exactly two calendar years longer , [they]839-their say . A powerful mind to hold out so long ! ”[848-another elderly man] “ True .... But there 's great strength in hope . Knowing that in four - and - twenty months ' time [ye'll]4569-ye'll be out of [your]4569-ye'll bondage , and able to make up for all [you]4569-ye'll 've suffered , by partaking without stint — why , it keeps [a man]4474-a man up , no doubt . ”[848-another elderly man] “ No doubt , [Christopher Coney]132-christopher coney , no doubt . And ' a must need such reflections — [a lonely widow man]4571-a lonely widow man , ”[131-longways] said [Longways]131-longways . “ When did [he]818-the old man lose [[his]818-the old man wife]380-his wife ? ”[191-henchard] asked [Elizabeth]191-henchard . “ [I]131-longways never knowed [her]380-his wife . ' Twas afore [he]818-the old man came to [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge , ”[131-longways] [Solomon Longways]131-longways replied with terminative emphasis , as if the fact of [his]131-longways ignorance of [Mrs. Henchard]128-henchard were sufficient to deprive [her]128-henchard history of all interest . “ But [I]131-longways know that ' a 's [a banded teetotaller]4573-a banded teetotaller , and that if [any of [[his]818-the old man men]4575-his men]4574-any of his men be ever so little overtook by a drop [he]818-the old man 's down upon ['em]818-the old man as stern as [the Lord upon the jovial Jews]4576-the lord upon the jovial jews . ”[131-longways] “ Has [he]818-the old man many [men]4432-men , then ? ”[191-henchard] said [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard . “ Many ! Why , [[my]191-henchard good maid]4578-my good maid , [he]818-the old man 's [the powerfullest member of [the Town Council]4580-the town council]4579-the powerfullest member of the town council , and quite [a principal man in [the country]633-the country round besides]4581-a principal man in the country round besides . Never a big dealing in wheat , barley , oats , hay , roots , and such - like but [Henchard]128-henchard 's got a hand in it . Ay , and [he]818-the old man 'll go into other things too ; and that 's where [he]818-the old man makes [his]818-the old man mistake . [He]818-the old man worked [his]818-the old man way up from nothing when ' a came [here]4417-here ; and now [he]818-the old man 's [a pillar of [the town]632-the town]4584-a pillar of the town . Not but what [he]818-the old man 's been shaken a little to - year about this bad corn [he]818-the old man has supplied in [his]818-the old man contracts . [I]191-henchard 've seen the sun rise over [Durnover]15-durnover Moor these nine - and - sixty year , and though [Mr. Henchard]120-henchard has never cussed [me]191-henchard unfairly ever since [I]191-henchard 've worked for'n , seeing [I]191-henchard be but [a little small man]4586-a little small man , [I]191-henchard must say that [I]191-henchard have never before tasted such rough bread as has been made from [Henchard]120-henchard 's wheat lately . ' Tis that growed out that [ye]4587-ye could a'most call it malt , and there 's a list at bottom o ' the loaf as thick as the sole of one 's shoe . ”[191-henchard] [The band]849-the band now struck up another melody , and by the time it was ended the dinner was over , and speeches began to be made . The evening being calm , and the windows still open , these orations could be distinctly heard . [Henchard]120-henchard 's voice arose above the rest ; [he]120-henchard was telling a story of [his]120-henchard hay - dealing experiences , in which [he]120-henchard had outwitted [a sharper who had been bent upon outwitting [him]120-henchard]850-a sharper who had been bent upon outwitting him . “ Ha - ha - ha ! ”[851-his audience] responded [[his]120-henchard audience]851-his audience at the upshot of the story ; and hilarity was general till a new voice arose with , “ This is all very well ; but how about the bad bread ? ”[851-his audience] It came from the lower end of the table , where there sat [a group of minor tradesmen who , although part of [the company]388-the company , appeared to be a little below the social level of [the others]854-the others]852-a group of minor tradesmen who , although part of the company , appeared to be a little below the social level of the others ; and who seemed to nourish a certain independence of opinion and carry on discussions not quite in harmony with [those at the head]855-those at the head ; just as the west end of [a church]547-a church is sometimes persistently found to sing out of time and tune with [the leading spirits in [the chancel]858-the chancel]857-the leading spirits in the chancel . This interruption about the bad bread afforded infinite satisfaction to [the loungers outside]859-the loungers outside , several of [whom]859-the loungers outside were in the mood which finds its pleasure in [others]860-others ' discomfiture ; and hence [they]859-the loungers outside echoed pretty freely , “ Hey ! How about the bad bread , [Mr. Mayor]133-mr. mayor ? ”[859-the loungers outside] Moreover , feeling none of the restraints of those who shared the feast , [they]859-the loungers outside could afford to add , “ [You]133-mr. mayor rather ought to tell the story o ' that , [sir]4588-sir ! ”[859-the loungers outside] The interruption was sufficient to compel [the Mayor]4556-the mayor to notice it . “ Well , [I]120-henchard admit that the wheat turned out badly , ”[120-henchard] [he]120-henchard said . “ But [I]120-henchard was taken in in buying it as much as [the bakers who bought it o ' [me]120-henchard]4589-the bakers who bought it o ' me . ”[120-henchard] “ And [the poor folk who had to eat it whether or no]4590-the poor folk who had to eat it whether or no , ”[862-the inharmonious man outside the window] said [the inharmonious man outside the window]862-the inharmonious man outside the window . [Henchard]120-henchard 's face darkened . There was temper under the thin bland surface — the temper which , artificially intensified , had banished [a wife]638-a wife nearly a score of years before . “ [You]4591-you must make allowances for the accidents of a large business , ”[120-henchard] [he]120-henchard said . “ [You]4591-you must bear in mind that the weather just at the harvest of that corn was worse than [we]4592-we have known it for years . However , [I]120-henchard have mended [my]120-henchard arrangements on account o't . Since [I]120-henchard have found [[my]120-henchard business]4593-my business too large to be well looked after by [myself]120-henchard alone , [I]120-henchard have advertised for [a thorough good man]4594-a thorough good man as [manager of the corn department]4595-manager of the corn department . When [I]120-henchard 've got [him]4594-a thorough good man [you]4591-you will find these mistakes will no longer occur — matters will be better looked into . ”[120-henchard] “ But what are [you]120-henchard going to do to repay [us]4596-us for the past ? ”[864-the man who had before spoken , and who seemed to be a baker or miller] inquired [the man who had before spoken , and who seemed to be [a baker]865-a baker or [miller]866-miller]864-the man who had before spoken , and who seemed to be a baker or miller . “ Will [you]120-henchard replace the grown flour [we]4596-us 've still got by sound grain ? ”[120-henchard] [Henchard]120-henchard 's face had become still more stern at these interruptions , and [he]120-henchard drank from [his]120-henchard tumbler of water as if to calm [himself]120-henchard or gain time . Instead of vouchsafing a direct reply , [he]120-henchard stiffly observed — “ If [anybody]4437-anybody will tell [me]120-henchard how to turn grown wheat into wholesome wheat [I]120-henchard 'll take it back with pleasure . But it ca n't be done . ”[120-henchard] [Henchard]120-henchard was not to be drawn again . Having said this , [he]120-henchard sat down .

Now [the group outside the window]867-the group outside the window had within the last few minutes been reinforced by [new arrivals]868-new arrivals , [some of [them]868-new arrivals [respectable shopkeepers]870-respectable shopkeepers and [[their]870-respectable shopkeepers assistants]871-their assistants , [who had come out for a whiff of air after putting up the shutters for the night]872-who had come out for a whiff of air after putting up the shutters for the night]869-some of them respectable shopkeepers and their assistants , who had come out for a whiff of air after putting up the shutters for the night ; [some of [them]868-new arrivals of [a lower class]874-a lower class]873-some of them of a lower class . Distinct from either there appeared [a stranger]4470-a stranger — [a young man of remarkably pleasant aspect]876-a young man of remarkably pleasant aspect — who carried in [his]4470-a stranger hand a carpet - bag of the smart floral pattern prevalent in such articles at that time . [He]4470-a stranger was ruddy and of a fair countenance , bright - eyed , and slight in build . [He]4470-a stranger might possibly have passed by without stopping at all , or at most for half a minute to glance in at the scene , had not [his]4470-a stranger advent coincided with the discussion on corn and bread , in which event this history had never been enacted . But the subject seemed to arrest [him]4470-a stranger , and [he]4470-a stranger whispered some inquiries of [the other bystanders]877-the other bystanders , and remained listening . When [he]4470-a stranger heard [Henchard]120-henchard 's closing words , “ It ca n't be done , ”[4470-a stranger] [he]4470-a stranger smiled impulsively , drew out [his]4470-a stranger pocketbook , and wrote down a few words by the aid of the light in the window . [He]4470-a stranger tore out the leaf , folded and directed it , and seemed about to throw it in through the open sash upon the dining - table ; but , on second thoughts , edged [himself]4470-a stranger through [the loiterers]878-the loiterers , till [he]4470-a stranger reached the door of [the hotel]879-the hotel , where one of [the waiters who had been serving inside]880-the waiters who had been serving inside was now idly leaning against the doorpost . “ Give this to [the Mayor]4556-the mayor at once , ”[4470-a stranger] [he]4470-a stranger said , handing in [his]4470-a stranger hasty note . [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard had seen [his]4470-a stranger movements and heard the words , which attracted [her]191-henchard both by [their]881-their subject and by [their]881-their accent — a strange one for those parts . It was quaint and northerly . [The waiter]882-the waiter took the note , while [the young stranger]883-the young stranger continued — “ And can [ye]191-henchard tell [me]883-the young stranger of [a respectable hotel that 's a little more moderate than this]4599-a respectable hotel that 's a little more moderate than this ? ”[883-the young stranger] [The waiter]882-the waiter glanced indifferently up and down [the street]797-the street . “ [They]4600-they say [the Three Mariners]4601-the three mariners , just below here , is [a very good place]4602-a very good place , ”[4470-a stranger] [he]4470-a stranger languidly answered ; “ but [I]4470-a stranger have never stayed [there]447-there [myself]4470-a stranger . ”[4470-a stranger] [The Scotchman]886-the scotchman , as [he]886-the scotchman seemed to be , thanked [him]882-the waiter , and strolled on in the direction of [the Three Mariners aforesaid]887-the three mariners aforesaid , apparently more concerned about the question of [an inn]888-an inn than about the fate of [his]4470-a stranger note , now that the momentary impulse of writing it was over . While [he]4470-a stranger was disappearing slowly down [the street]797-the street [the waiter]882-the waiter left the door , and [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard saw with some interest the note brought into [the dining - room]891-the dining - room and handed to [the Mayor]4556-the mayor . [Henchard]120-henchard looked at it carelessly , unfolded it with one hand , and glanced it through . Thereupon it was curious to note an unexpected effect . The nettled , clouded aspect which had held possession of [his]120-henchard face since the subject of [his]120-henchard corn - dealings had been broached , changed itself into one of arrested attention . [He]120-henchard read the note slowly , and fell into thought , not moody , but fitfully intense , as that of [a man who has been captured by an idea]893-a man who has been captured by an idea . By this time toasts and speeches had given place to songs , the wheat subject being quite forgotten . [Men]4432-men were putting [their]4432-men heads together in twos and threes , telling good stories , with pantomimic laughter which reached convulsive grimace . [Some]895-some were beginning to look as if [they]895-some did not know how [they]895-some had come [there]447-there , what [they]895-some had come for , or how [they]895-some were going to get [home]675-home again ; and provisionally sat on with a dazed smile . [Square - built men]898-square - built men showed a tendency to become hunchbacks ; [men with a dignified presence]899-men with a dignified presence lost it in a curious obliquity of figure , in which [their]899-men with a dignified presence features grew disarranged and one - sided , whilst the heads of [a few who had dined with extreme thoroughness]900-a few who had dined with extreme thoroughness were somehow sinking into [their]900-a few who had dined with extreme thoroughness shoulders , the corners of [their]900-a few who had dined with extreme thoroughness mouth and eyes being bent upwards by the subsidence . [Only Henchard]120-henchard did not conform to these flexuous changes ; [he]120-henchard remained stately and vertical , silently thinking . The clock struck nine . [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard turned to [[her]191-henchard companion]583-her companion . “ The evening is drawing on , [mother]4495-mother , ”[191-henchard] [she]191-henchard said . “ What do [you]4495-mother propose to do ? ”[191-henchard] [She]191-henchard was surprised to find how irresolute [[her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother had become . “ [We]4605-we must get a place to lie down in , ”[191-henchard] [she]191-henchard murmured . “ [I]191-henchard have seen — [Mr. Henchard]120-henchard ; and that 's all [I]191-henchard wanted to do . ”[191-henchard] “ That 's enough for to - night , at any rate , ”[191-henchard] [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard replied soothingly . “ [We]4605-we can think to - morrow what is best to do about [him]120-henchard . The question now is — is it not ? — how shall [we]4605-we find [a lodging]4606-a lodging ? ”[191-henchard] As [[her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother did not reply [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard 's mind reverted to the words of [the waiter]882-the waiter , that [the Three Mariners]4601-the three mariners was [an inn of moderate charges]906-an inn of moderate charges . A recommendation good for [one person]907-one person was probably good for another . “ Let 's go where [the young man]371-the young man has gone to , ”[191-henchard] [she]191-henchard said . “ [He]371-the young man is respectable . What do [you]191-henchard say ? ”[191-henchard] [[Her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother assented , and down [the street]797-the street [they]910-they went . In the meantime [the Mayor]4556-the mayor 's thoughtfulness , engendered by the note as stated , continued to hold [him]4556-the mayor in abstraction ; till , whispering to [[his]4556-the mayor neighbour]912-his neighbour to take [his]4556-the mayor place , [he]4556-the mayor found opportunity to leave the chair . This was just after the departure of [[his]4556-the mayor wife]380-his wife and [Elizabeth]191-henchard . Outside the door of [the assembly - room]914-the assembly - room [he]4556-the mayor saw [the waiter]882-the waiter , and beckoning to [him]4556-the mayor asked who had brought the note which had been handed in a quarter of an hour before . “ [A young man]285-a young man , [sir]4588-sir — [a sort of traveller]4610-a sort of traveller . [He]285-a young man went to [the Three Mariners]4601-the three mariners , [I]4556-the mayor believe . ”[4556-the mayor] [The mayor]4556-the mayor walked up and down [the vestibule of [the hotel]879-the hotel]917-the vestibule of the hotel with [his]4556-the mayor hands under [his]4556-the mayor coat tails , as if [he]4556-the mayor were merely seeking a cooler atmosphere than that of [the room [he]4556-the mayor had quitted]919-the room he had quitted . But there could be no doubt that [he]4556-the mayor was in reality still possessed to the full by the new idea , whatever that might be . At length [he]4556-the mayor went back to the door of [the dining - room]891-the dining - room , paused , and found that the songs , toasts , and conversation were proceeding quite satisfactorily without [his]4556-the mayor presence . [The Corporation]16-the corporation , [private residents]921-private residents , and [major and minor tradesmen]922-major and minor tradesmen had , in fact , gone in for comforting beverages to such an extent that [they]923-they had quite forgotten , not only [the Mayor]4556-the mayor , but all those vast , political , religious , and social differences which [they]923-they felt necessary to maintain in the daytime , and which separated [them]923-they like iron grills . Seeing this [the Mayor]4556-the mayor took [his]4556-the mayor hat , and when [the waiter]882-the waiter had helped [him]4556-the mayor on with a thin holland overcoat , went out and stood under [the portico]927-the portico . [Very few persons]928-very few persons were now in [the street]797-the street ; and [his]4556-the mayor eyes , by a sort of attraction , turned and dwelt upon a spot about a hundred yards further down . [It]930-it was [the house to which [the writer of the note]932-the writer of the note had gone — [the Three Mariners]4601-the three mariners — whose two prominent Elizabethan gables , bow - window , and passage - light could be seen from where [he]4556-the mayor stood]931-the house to which the writer of the note had gone — the three mariners — whose two prominent elizabethan gables , bow - window , and passage - light could be seen from where he stood . Having kept [his]4556-the mayor eyes on [it]930-it for a while [he]4556-the mayor strolled in that direction . [This ancient house of accommodation for [man]488-man]934-this ancient house of accommodation for man and beast , now , unfortunately , pulled down , was built of mellow sandstone , with mullioned windows of the same material , markedly out of perpendicular from the settlement of [foundations]936-foundations . The bay window projecting into [the street]797-the street , whose interior was so popular among [the frequenters of [the inn]939-the inn]938-the frequenters of the inn , was closed with shutters , in each of which appeared a heart - shaped aperture , somewhat more attenuated in the right and left ventricles than is seen in Nature . Inside these illuminated holes , at a distance of about three inches , were ranged at this hour , as [every passer]940-every passer knew , the ruddy polls of [Billy Wills the glazier]134-billy wills the glazier , [Smart the shoemaker]941-smart the shoemaker , [Buzzford the general dealer]942-buzzford the general dealer , and [others of a secondary set of worthies]943-others of a secondary set of worthies , of a grade somewhat below that of [the diners at [the King 's Arms]945-the king 's arms]944-the diners at the king 's arms , each with [his]4556-the mayor yard of clay . [A four - centred Tudor arch]946-a four - centred tudor arch was over the entrance , and over the arch the signboard , now visible in the rays of an opposite lamp . Hereon [the Mariners]135-the three mariners , who had been represented by [the artist]947-the artist as [persons of two dimensions only — in other words , flat as a shadow]948-persons of two dimensions only — in other words , flat as a shadow — were standing in a row in paralyzed attitudes . Being on the sunny side of [the street]797-the street [the three comrades]950-the three comrades had suffered largely from warping , splitting , fading , and shrinkage , so that [they]950-the three comrades were but [a half - invisible film upon the reality of the grain , and knots , and nails]951-a half - invisible film upon the reality of the grain , and knots , and nails , which composed the signboard . As a matter of fact , this state of things was not so much owing to [Stannidge]136-mrs. stannidge [the landlord]952-the landlord 's neglect , as from the lack of [a painter in [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge who would undertake to reproduce the features of [men so traditional]954-men so traditional]953-a painter in casterbridge who would undertake to reproduce the features of men so traditional . [A long , narrow , dimly - lit passage]955-a long , narrow , dimly - lit passage gave access to [the inn]939-the inn , within which passage the horses going to [[their]957-their stalls]958-their stalls at the back , and [the coming and departing human guests]959-the coming and departing human guests , rubbed shoulders indiscriminately , the latter running no slight risk of having [their]959-the coming and departing human guests toes trodden upon by the animals . The good stabling and the good ale of [the Mariners]960-the mariners , though somewhat difficult to reach on account of there being but this narrow way to both , were nevertheless perseveringly sought out by [the sagacious old heads who knew what was what in [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge]961-the sagacious old heads who knew what was what in casterbridge . [Henchard]120-henchard stood without [the inn]939-the inn for a few instants ; then lowering the dignity of [his]120-henchard presence as much as possible by buttoning the brown holland coat over [his]120-henchard shirt - front , and in other ways toning [himself]120-henchard down to [his]120-henchard ordinary everyday appearance , [he]120-henchard entered [the inn]939-the inn door .

[Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard and [[her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother had arrived some twenty minutes earlier . Outside [the house]782-the house [they]960-the mariners had stood and considered whether even [this homely place]966-this homely place , though recommended as moderate , might not be too serious in [its]966-this homely place prices for [their]960-the mariners light pockets . Finally , however , [they]960-the mariners had found courage to enter , and duly met [[Stannidge]136-mrs. stannidge [the landlord]952-the landlord , [a silent man]969-a silent man , who drew and carried frothing measures to [this room]811-this room and to that , shoulder to shoulder with [[his]120-henchard waiting - maids]971-his waiting - maids]967-stannidge the landlord , a silent man , who drew and carried frothing measures to this room and to that , shoulder to shoulder with his waiting - maids — a stately slowness , however , entering into [his]120-henchard ministrations by contrast with [theirs]960-the mariners , as became one whose service was somewhat optional . It would have been altogether optional but for the orders of [the landlady]972-the landlady , [a person who sat in the bar , corporeally motionless , but with a flitting eye and quick ear , with which [she]972-the landlady observed and heard through the open door and hatchway the pressing needs of customers whom [[her]972-the landlady husband]387-her husband overlooked though close at hand]973-a person who sat in the bar , corporeally motionless , but with a flitting eye and quick ear , with which she observed and heard through the open door and hatchway the pressing needs of customers whom her husband overlooked though close at hand . [Elizabeth]191-henchard and [[her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother were passively accepted as [sojourners]976-sojourners , and shown to [a small bedroom under one of [the gables]978-the gables]977-a small bedroom under one of the gables , where [they]979-we sat down . The principle of [the inn]939-the inn seemed to be to compensate for the antique awkwardness , crookedness , and obscurity of the passages , floors , and windows , by quantities of clean linen spread about everywhere , and this had a dazzling effect upon [the travellers]758-the travellers . “ ' Tis too good for [us]979-we — [we]979-we ca n't meet it ! ”[982-the elder woman] said [the elder woman]982-the elder woman , looking round [the apartment]983-the apartment with misgiving as soon as [they]979-we were left alone . “ [I]191-henchard fear it is , too , ”[191-henchard] said [Elizabeth]191-henchard . “ But [we]979-we must be respectable . ”[191-henchard] “ [We]979-we must pay [our]979-we way even before [we]979-we must be respectable , ”[588-her mother] replied [[her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother . “ [Mr. Henchard]120-henchard is too high for [us]979-we to make [ourselves]979-we known to [him]120-henchard , [I]588-her mother much fear ; so [we]979-we 've only [our]979-we own pockets to depend on . ”[588-her mother] “ [I]191-henchard know what [I]191-henchard 'll do , ”[191-henchard] said [Elizabeth]191-henchard - [Jane]191-henchard after an interval of waiting , during which [their]979-we needs seemed quite forgotten under the press of business below . And leaving [the room]985-the room , [she]191-henchard descended the stairs and penetrated to [the bar]986-the bar . If there was one good thing more than another which characterized [this single - hearted girl]987-this single - hearted girl it was a willingness to sacrifice [her]987-this single - hearted girl personal comfort and dignity to the common weal . “ As [you]972-the landlady seem busy [here]4417-here to - night , and [mother]4495-mother 's not well off , might [I]191-henchard take out part of [[our]979-we accommodation]4619-our accommodation by helping ? ”[191-henchard] [she]191-henchard asked of [the landlady]972-the landlady . [The latter]4511-the latter , who remained as fixed in the arm - chair as if [she]4511-the latter had been melted into it when in a liquid state , and could not now be unstuck , looked [the girl]311-the girl up and down inquiringly , with [her]4511-the latter hands on the chair - arms . Such arrangements as the one [Elizabeth]191-henchard proposed were not uncommon in [country villages]991-country villages ; but , though [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge was old - fashioned , the custom was well - nigh obsolete [here]4417-here . [The mistress of [the house]782-the house]993-the mistress of the house , however , was [an easy woman]995-an easy woman to [strangers]826-strangers , and [she]993-the mistress of the house made no objection . Thereupon [Elizabeth]191-henchard , being instructed by nods and motions from [the taciturn landlord]997-the taciturn landlord as to where [she]191-henchard could find the different things , trotted up and down stairs with materials for [her]191-henchard own and [[her]191-henchard parent]998-her parent 's meal . While [she]191-henchard was doing this the wood partition in the centre of [the house]782-the house thrilled to its centre with the tugging of a bell - pull [upstairs]1000-upstairs . A bell below tinkled a note that was feebler in sound than the twanging of wires and cranks that had produced it . “ ' Tis [the Scotch gentleman]4620-the scotch gentleman , ”[972-the landlady] said [the landlady]972-the landlady omnisciently ; and turning [her]972-the landlady eyes to [Elizabeth]191-henchard , “ Now then , can [you]191-henchard go and see if [his]4620-the scotch gentleman supper is on the tray ? If it is [you]191-henchard can take it up to [him]4620-the scotch gentleman . [The front room]4621-the front room over this . ”[191-henchard] [Elizabeth]191-henchard - [Jane]191-henchard , though hungry , willingly postponed serving [herself]191-henchard awhile , and applied to [the cook in [the kitchen]1003-the kitchen]1002-the cook in the kitchen whence [she]191-henchard brought forth the tray of supper viands , and proceeded with it [upstairs]1000-upstairs to [the apartment indicated]1005-the apartment indicated . [The accommodation of [the Three Mariners]4601-the three mariners]1006-the accommodation of the three mariners was far from spacious , despite the fair area of ground [it]1006-the accommodation of the three mariners covered . [The room]985-the room demanded by intrusive beams and rafters , partitions , passages , staircases , disused ovens , [settles]1009-settles , and four - posters , left [comparatively small quarters for [human beings]1011-human beings]1010-comparatively small quarters for human beings . Moreover , this being at a time before [home]675-home - brewing was abandoned by [the smaller victuallers]1013-the smaller victuallers , and [a house in which the twelve - bushel strength was still religiously adhered to by [the landlord]952-the landlord in [his]952-the landlord ale]1014-a house in which the twelve - bushel strength was still religiously adhered to by the landlord in his ale , the quality of the liquor was the chief attraction of [the premises]1016-the premises , so that everything had to make way for utensils and operations in connection therewith . Thus [Elizabeth]191-henchard found that [the Scotchman]886-the scotchman was located in [a room quite close to [the small one that had been allotted to [herself]191-henchard and]1019-the small one that had been allotted to herself and [[her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother]1018-a room quite close to the small one that had been allotted to herself and her mother . When [she]191-henchard entered [nobody]298-nobody was present but [the young man]371-the young man [himself]371-the young man — [the same whom [she]191-henchard had seen lingering without the windows of [the King 's Arms Hotel]1024-the king 's arms hotel]1023-the same whom she had seen lingering without the windows of the king 's arms hotel . [He]371-the young man was now idly reading a copy of the local paper , and was hardly conscious of [her]191-henchard entry , so that [she]191-henchard looked at [him]371-the young man quite coolly , and saw how [his]371-the young man forehead shone where the light caught it , and how nicely [his]371-the young man hair was cut , and the sort of velvet - pile or down that was on the skin at the back of [his]371-the young man neck , and how [his]371-the young man cheek was so truly curved as to be part of a globe , and how clearly drawn were the lids and lashes which hid [his]371-the young man bent eyes . [She]191-henchard set down the tray , spread [his]371-the young man supper , and went away without a word . On [her]191-henchard arrival below [the landlady]972-the landlady , who was as kind as [she]972-the landlady was fat and lazy , saw that [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard was rather tired , though in [her]191-henchard earnestness to be useful [she]191-henchard was waiving [her]191-henchard own needs altogether . [Mrs. Stannidge]136-mrs. stannidge thereupon said with a considerate peremptoriness that [she]136-mrs. stannidge and [[her]136-mrs. stannidge mother]588-her mother had better take [their]1027-their own suppers if [they]1027-their meant to have any . [Elizabeth]191-henchard fetched [their]1027-their simple provisions , as [she]191-henchard had fetched [the Scotchman]886-the scotchman 's , and went up to [the little chamber where [she]191-henchard had left [[her]136-mrs. stannidge mother]588-her mother , noiselessly pushing open the door with the edge of the tray]1029-the little chamber where she had left her mother , noiselessly pushing open the door with the edge of the tray . To [her]191-henchard surprise [[her]136-mrs. stannidge mother]588-her mother , instead of being reclined on the bed where [she]191-henchard had left [her]588-her mother was in an erect position , with lips parted . At [Elizabeth]191-henchard 's entry [she]191-henchard lifted [her]191-henchard finger . The meaning of this was soon apparent . [The room allotted to [the two women]752-the two women]1032-the room allotted to the two women had at one time served as [a dressing - room to [[the Scotchman]886-the scotchman 's chamber]1036-the scotchman 's chamber]1034-a dressing - room to the scotchman 's chamber , as was evidenced by signs of a door of communication between [them]752-the two women — now screwed up and pasted over with the wall paper . But , as is frequently the case with hotels of far higher pretensions than [the Three Mariners]4601-the three mariners , every word spoken in either of [these rooms]1038-these rooms was distinctly audible in the other . Such sounds came through now . Thus silently conjured [Elizabeth]191-henchard deposited the tray , and [[her]136-mrs. stannidge mother]588-her mother whispered as [she]588-her mother drew near , “ ' Tis [he]886-the scotchman . ”[588-her mother] “ Who ? ”[311-the girl] said [the girl]311-the girl . “ [The Mayor]4556-the mayor . ”[311-the girl] The tremors in [Susan Henchard]122-henchard 's tone might have led [any person but one so perfectly unsuspicious of the truth]1041-any person but one so perfectly unsuspicious of the truth as [the girl]311-the girl was , to surmise some closer connection than the admitted simple kinship as a means of accounting for [them]752-the two women . [Two men]736-two men were indeed talking in [the adjoining chamber]1044-the adjoining chamber , [the young Scotchman]1045-the young scotchman and [Henchard]122-henchard , who , having entered [the inn]939-the inn while [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard was in [the kitchen]1003-the kitchen waiting for the supper , had been deferentially conducted [upstairs]1000-upstairs by [host Stannidge]136-mrs. stannidge [himself]136-mrs. stannidge . [The girl]311-the girl noiselessly laid out [their]736-two men little meal , and beckoned to [[her]311-the girl mother]588-her mother to join [her]311-the girl , which [Mrs. Henchard]128-henchard mechanically did , [her]128-henchard attention being fixed on the conversation through the door . “ [I]4556-the mayor merely strolled in on [my]4556-the mayor way [home]675-home to ask [you]311-the girl a question about something that has excited [my]4556-the mayor curiosity , ”[4556-the mayor] said [the Mayor]4556-the mayor , with careless geniality . “ But [I]4556-the mayor see [you]311-the girl have not finished supper . ”[4556-the mayor] “ Ay , but [I]128-henchard will be done in a little ! [Ye]311-the girl need n't go , [sir]4588-sir . Take a seat . [I]128-henchard 've almost done , and it makes no difference at all . ”[128-henchard] [Henchard]128-henchard seemed to take the seat offered , and in a moment [he]4556-the mayor resumed : “ Well , first [I]4556-the mayor should ask , did [you]311-the girl write this ? ”[4556-the mayor] A rustling of paper followed . “ Yes , [I]886-the scotchman did , ”[886-the scotchman] said [the Scotchman]886-the scotchman . “ Then , ”[128-henchard] said [Henchard]128-henchard , “ [I]128-henchard am under the impression that [we]4625-we have met by accident while waiting for the morning to keep an appointment with [each other]4626-each other ? [My]128-henchard name is [Henchard]128-henchard , ha'n't [you]311-the girl replied to an advertisement for [a corn - factor 's manager]4627-a corn - factor 's manager that [I]128-henchard put into the paper — ha'n't [you]311-the girl come here to see [me]128-henchard about it ? ”[128-henchard] “ No , ”[886-the scotchman] said [the Scotchman]886-the scotchman , with some surprise . “ Surely [you]311-the girl are [the man]291-the man , ”[128-henchard] went on [Henchard]128-henchard insistingly , “ who arranged to come and see [me]128-henchard ? [Joshua]137-jopp , [Joshua]137-jopp , [Jipp]138-jipp — [Jopp]137-jopp — what was [his]137-jopp name ? ”[128-henchard] “ [You]311-the girl 're wrong ! ”[371-the young man] said [the young man]371-the young man . “ [My]371-the young man name is [Donald Farfrae]139-farfrae . It is true [I]371-the young man am in the corren trade — but [I]371-the young man have replied to no advertisement , and arranged to see [no one]437-no one . [I]371-the young man am on [my]371-the young man way to [Bristol]17-bristol — from there to [the other side of [the warrld]4631-the warrld]4630-the other side of the warrld , to try [my]371-the young man fortune in [the great wheat - growing districts of [the West]18-the west]4632-the great wheat - growing districts of the west ! [I]371-the young man have some inventions useful to the trade , and there is no scope for developing them heere . ”[371-the young man] “ To [America]19-america — well , well , ”[128-henchard] said [Henchard]128-henchard , in a tone of disappointment , so strong as to make itself felt like a damp atmosphere . “ And yet [I]128-henchard could have sworn [you]128-henchard were [the man]291-the man ! ”[128-henchard] [The Scotchman]886-the scotchman murmured another negative , and there was a silence , till [Henchard]128-henchard resumed : “ Then [I]128-henchard am truly and sincerely obliged to [you]886-the scotchman for the few words [you]886-the scotchman wrote on that paper . ”[128-henchard] “ It was nothing , [sir]4588-sir . ”[371-the young man] “ Well , it has a great importance for [me]371-the young man just now . This row about [my]371-the young man grown wheat , which [I]371-the young man declare to [Heaven]123-heaven [I]371-the young man did n't know to be bad till [the people]4635-the people came complaining , has put [me]371-the young man to [my]371-the young man wits ' end . [I]371-the young man 've some hundreds of quarters of it on hand ; and if [your]886-the scotchman renovating process will make it wholesome , why , [you]886-the scotchman can see what a quag ' twould get [me]371-the young man out of . [I]371-the young man saw in a moment there might be truth in it . But [I]371-the young man should like to have it proved ; and of course [you]886-the scotchman do n't care to tell the steps of the process sufficiently for [me]371-the young man to do that , without [my]371-the young man paying [ye]886-the scotchman well for't first . ”[371-the young man] [The young man]371-the young man reflected a moment or two . “ [I]371-the young man do n't know that [I]371-the young man have any objection , ”[371-the young man] [he]371-the young man said . “ [I]371-the young man 'm going to [another country]4636-another country , and curing bad corn is not the line [I]371-the young man 'll take up there . Yes , [I]371-the young man 'll tell [ye]886-the scotchman the whole of it — [you]886-the scotchman 'll make more out of it heere than [I]371-the young man will in [a foreign country]4637-a foreign country . Just look heere a minute , [sir]4588-sir . [I]371-the young man can show [ye]886-the scotchman by a sample in [my]371-the young man carpet - bag . ”[371-the young man] The click of a lock followed , and there was a sifting and rustling ; then a discussion about so many ounces to the bushel , and drying , and refrigerating , and so on . “ These few grains will be sufficient to show [ye]886-the scotchman with , ”[1057-the young fellow] came in [the young fellow]1057-the young fellow 's voice ; and after a pause , during which some operation seemed to be intently watched by [them]1058-them both , [he]371-the young man exclaimed , “ There , now , do [you]886-the scotchman taste that . ”[371-the young man] “ It 's complete ! — quite restored , or — well — nearly . ”[371-the young man] “ Quite enough restored to make good seconds out of it , ”[886-the scotchman] said [the Scotchman]886-the scotchman . “ To fetch it back entirely is impossible ; Nature wo n't stand so much as that , but heere [you]886-the scotchman go a great way towards it . Well , [sir]4588-sir , that 's the process , [I]886-the scotchman do n't value it , for it can be but of little use in [countries where the weather is more settled than in]4640-countries where the weather is more settled than in [ours]4641-ours ; and [I]886-the scotchman 'll be only too glad if it 's of service to [you]4588-sir . ”[886-the scotchman] “ But hearken to [me]128-henchard , ”[128-henchard] pleaded [Henchard]128-henchard . “ [My]128-henchard business [you]4588-sir know , is in corn and in hay , but [I]128-henchard was brought up as a hay - trusser simply , and hay is what [I]128-henchard understand best though [I]128-henchard now do more in corn than in the other . If [you]4588-sir 'll accept [the place]515-the place , [you]4588-sir shall manage the corn branch entirely , and receive a commission in addition to salary . ”[128-henchard] “ [You]4588-sir 're liberal — very liberal , but no , no — [I]371-the young man cannet ! ”[371-the young man] [the young man]371-the young man still replied , with some distress in [his]371-the young man accents . “ So be it ! ”[128-henchard] said [Henchard]128-henchard conclusively . “ Now — to change the subject — one good turn deserves another ; do n't stay to finish that miserable supper . Come to [[my]128-henchard house]4643-my house , [I]128-henchard can find something better for ' ee than cold ham and ale . ”[128-henchard] [Donald Farfrae]139-farfrae was grateful — said [he]371-the young man feared [he]371-the young man must decline — that [he]371-the young man wished to leave early next day . “ Very well , ”[128-henchard] said [Henchard]128-henchard quickly , “ please [yourself]4588-sir . But [I]128-henchard tell [you]4588-sir , [young man]4644-young man , if this holds good for the bulk , as it has done for the sample , [you]4588-sir have saved [my]128-henchard credit , stranger though [you]4588-sir be . What shall [I]128-henchard pay [you]4588-sir for this knowledge ? ”[128-henchard] “ Nothing at all , nothing at all . It may not prove necessary to [ye]4588-sir to use it often , and [I]128-henchard do n't value it at all . [I]128-henchard thought [I]128-henchard might just as well let [ye]4588-sir know , as [you]4588-sir were in a difficulty , and they were harrd upon [ye]4588-sir . ”[128-henchard] [Henchard]128-henchard paused . “ [I]371-the young man sha n't soon forget this , ”[371-the young man] [he]371-the young man said . “ And from [a stranger]4470-a stranger ! ... [I]371-the young man could n't believe [you]4588-sir were not [the man [I]371-the young man had engaged]4646-the man i had engaged !
