The amount was significant ; it may tacitly have said to [her]588-her mother that [he]120-henchard bought [her]588-her mother back again . [She]588-her mother waited restlessly for the close of the day , telling [Elizabeth]191-henchard - [Jane]191-henchard that [she]588-her mother was invited to see [Mr. Henchard]120-henchard ; that [she]588-her mother would go alone . But [she]588-her mother said nothing to show that the place of meeting was not at [[his]120-henchard house]1329-his house , nor did [she]588-her mother hand the note to [Elizabeth]191-henchard .

[The Ring at [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge]1369-the ring at casterbridge was merely the local name of one of [the finest Roman Amphitheatres]1370-the finest roman amphitheatres , if not the very finest , remaining in [Britain]40-britain . [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge announced old [Rome]41-rome in [every street]1371-every street , [alley]1372-alley , and [precinct]1373-precinct . [It]6-casterbridge looked Roman , bespoke the art of [Rome]41-rome , concealed [dead men of [Rome]41-rome]1374-dead men of rome . It was impossible to dig more than a foot or two deep about [the town fields and gardens]1375-the town fields and gardens without coming upon [some tall soldier or other of the Empire]1376-some tall soldier or other of the empire , who had lain there in [his]120-henchard silent unobtrusive rest for a space of fifteen hundred years . [He]120-henchard was mostly found lying on [his]120-henchard side , in an oval scoop in the chalk , like a chicken in its shell ; [his]120-henchard knees drawn up to [his]120-henchard chest ; sometimes with the remains of [his]120-henchard spear against [his]120-henchard arm , a fibula or brooch of bronze on [his]120-henchard breast or forehead , an urn at [his]120-henchard knees , a jar at [his]120-henchard throat , a bottle at [his]120-henchard mouth ; and mystified conjecture pouring down upon [him]120-henchard from the eyes of [[Casterbridge]6-casterbridge street boys]1377-casterbridge street boys and [men , who had turned a moment to gaze at the familiar spectacle]1378-men , who had turned a moment to gaze at the familiar spectacle as [they]1378-men , who had turned a moment to gaze at the familiar spectacle passed by . [Imaginative inhabitants , who would have felt an unpleasantness at the discovery of a comparatively modern skeleton]1379-imaginative inhabitants , who would have felt an unpleasantness at the discovery of a comparatively modern skeleton in [[their]1379-imaginative inhabitants , who would have felt an unpleasantness at the discovery of a comparatively modern skeleton gardens]1380-their gardens , were quite unmoved by these hoary shapes . [They]1379-imaginative inhabitants , who would have felt an unpleasantness at the discovery of a comparatively modern skeleton had lived so long ago , [their]1379-imaginative inhabitants , who would have felt an unpleasantness at the discovery of a comparatively modern skeleton time was so unlike the present , [their]1379-imaginative inhabitants , who would have felt an unpleasantness at the discovery of a comparatively modern skeleton hopes and motives were so widely removed from [ours]1381-ours , that between [them]1379-imaginative inhabitants , who would have felt an unpleasantness at the discovery of a comparatively modern skeleton and [the living there]1382-the living there seemed to stretch a gulf too wide for even a spirit to pass . [The Amphitheatre]1383-the amphitheatre was [a huge circular enclosure , with a notch at opposite extremities of [its]1383-the amphitheatre diameter north and south]1384-a huge circular enclosure , with a notch at opposite extremities of its diameter north and south . From [its]1383-the amphitheatre sloping internal form it might have been called [the spittoon of [the Jotuns]42-the jotuns]1385-the spittoon of the jotuns . It was to [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge what [the ruined Coliseum]1386-the ruined coliseum is to modern [Rome]41-rome , and was nearly of the same magnitude . The dusk of evening was the proper hour at which a true impression of [this suggestive place]1387-this suggestive place could be received . Standing in the middle of [the arena]1388-the arena at that time there by degrees became apparent [its]1383-the amphitheatre real vastness , which a cursory view from the summit at noon - day was apt to obscure . Melancholy , impressive , lonely , yet accessible from [every part of [the town]632-the town]1389-every part of the town , the historic circle was the frequent spot for appointments of a furtive kind . Intrigues were arranged [there]447-there ; tentative meetings were there experimented after divisions and feuds . But one kind of appointment — in itself the most common of any — seldom had place in [the Amphitheatre]1383-the amphitheatre : that of [happy lovers]1393-happy lovers . Why , seeing that [it]1383-the amphitheatre was pre - eminently [an airy , accessible , and sequestered spot for interviews]1394-an airy , accessible , and sequestered spot for interviews , the cheerfullest form of those occurrences never took kindly to the soil of [the ruin]1395-the ruin , would be a curious inquiry . Perhaps it was because [its]1383-the amphitheatre associations had about [them]1396-them something sinister . [Its]1383-the amphitheatre history proved that . Apart from the sanguinary nature of the games originally played therein , such incidents attached to [its]1383-the amphitheatre past as these : that for scores of years [the town - gallows]1397-the town - gallows had stood at one corner ; that in 1705 [a woman who had murdered [[her]1398-a woman who had murdered her husband was half - strangled and then burnt there in the presence of ten thousand spectators husband]387-her husband was half - strangled and then burnt there in the presence of [ten thousand spectators]1400-ten thousand spectators]1398-a woman who had murdered her husband was half - strangled and then burnt there in the presence of ten thousand spectators . Tradition reports that at a certain stage of the burning [her]1398-a woman who had murdered her husband was half - strangled and then burnt there in the presence of ten thousand spectators heart burst and leapt out of [her]1398-a woman who had murdered her husband was half - strangled and then burnt there in the presence of ten thousand spectators body , to the terror of [them]1400-ten thousand spectators all , and that [not one of those ten thousand people]1401-not one of those ten thousand people ever cared particularly for hot roast after that . In addition to these old tragedies , pugilistic encounters almost to the death had come off down to recent dates in [that secluded arena]1402-that secluded arena , entirely invisible to [the outside world]1403-the outside world save by climbing to the top of the enclosure , which [few towns - people in the daily round of [their]1404-few towns - people in the daily round of their lives lives]1404-few towns - people in the daily round of their lives ever took the trouble to do . So that , though close to [the turnpike - road]1405-the turnpike - road , crimes might be perpetrated there unseen at mid - day . [Some boys]1406-some boys had latterly tried to impart gaiety to [the ruin]1395-the ruin by using [the central arena]1408-the central arena as [a cricket - ground]1409-a cricket - ground . But the game usually languished for the aforesaid reason — the dismal privacy which the earthen circle enforced , shutting out [every appreciative passer]1410-every appreciative passer 's vision , every commendatory remark from [outsiders]1411-outsiders — everything , except the sky ; and to play at games in such circumstances was like acting to [an empty house]1412-an empty house . Possibly , too , [the boys]1413-the boys were timid , for [some old people]1414-some old people said that at certain moments in the summer time , in broad daylight , persons sitting with a book or dozing in [the arena]1388-the arena had , on lifting [their]1404-few towns - people in the daily round of their lives eyes , beheld the slopes lined with a gazing legion of Hadrian 's soldiery as if watching the gladiatorial combat ; and had heard the roar of [their]1404-few towns - people in the daily round of their lives excited voices , that the scene would remain but a moment , like a lightning flash , and then disappear . It was related that there still remained under the south entrance excavated cells for the reception of the wild animals and [athletes who took part in the games]1416-athletes who took part in the games . [The arena]1388-the arena was still smooth and circular , as if used for [its]1388-the arena original purpose not so very long ago . [The sloping pathways by which [spectators]1419-spectators had ascended to [their]1419-spectators seats]1418-the sloping pathways by which spectators had ascended to their seats were pathways yet . But the whole was grown over with grass , which now , at the end of summer , was bearded with withered bents that formed waves under the brush of the wind , returning to the attentive ear aeolian modulations , and detaining for moments the flying globes of thistledown . [Henchard]120-henchard had chosen [this spot]1420-this spot as being the safest from observation which [he]120-henchard could think of for meeting [[his]120-henchard long - lost wife]1421-his long - lost wife , and at the same time as one easily to be found by [a stranger after nightfall]1422-a stranger after nightfall . As [Mayor of [the town]632-the town]4714-mayor of the town , with a reputation to keep up , [he]120-henchard could not invite [her]1421-his long - lost wife to come to [[his]120-henchard house]1329-his house till some definite course had been decided on . Just before eight [he]120-henchard approached [the deserted earth - work]1426-the deserted earth - work and entered by the south path which descended over [the debris of [the former dens]1428-the former dens]1427-the debris of the former dens . In a few moments [he]120-henchard could discern [a female figure creeping in by]1429-a female figure creeping in by [the great north gap]1430-the great north gap , or public gateway . [They]1431-they met in the middle of [the arena]1388-the arena . [Neither]1433-neither spoke just at first — there was no necessity for speech — and [the poor woman]1434-the poor woman leant against [Henchard]120-henchard , who supported [her]1434-the poor woman in [his]120-henchard arms . “ [I]120-henchard do n't drink , ”[120-henchard] [he]120-henchard said in a low , halting , apologetic voice . “ [You]1434-the poor woman hear , [Susan]151-susan ? — [I]120-henchard do n't drink now — [I]120-henchard have n't since that night . ”[120-henchard] Those were [his]120-henchard first words . [He]120-henchard felt [her]1434-the poor woman bow [her]1434-the poor woman head in acknowledgment that [she]1434-the poor woman understood . After a minute or two [he]120-henchard again began : “ If [I]1434-the poor woman had known [you]151-susan were living , [Susan]151-susan ! But there was every reason to suppose [you]151-susan and [the child]306-the child were dead and gone . [I]1434-the poor woman took every possible step to find [you]151-susan — travelled — advertised . [My]1434-the poor woman opinion at last was that [you]151-susan had started for [some colony]4799-some colony with [that man]4800-that man , and had been drowned on [your]151-susan voyage . Why did [you]151-susan keep silent like this ? ”[1434-the poor woman] “ O [Michael]120-henchard ! because of [him]4800-that man — what other reason could there be ? [I]1434-the poor woman thought [I]1434-the poor woman owed [him]4800-that man faithfulness to the end of one of [our]4801-our lives — foolishly [I]1434-the poor woman believed there was something solemn and binding in the bargain ; [I]1434-the poor woman thought that even in honour [I]1434-the poor woman dared not desert [him]4800-that man when [he]4800-that man had paid so much for [me]1434-the poor woman in good faith . [I]1434-the poor woman meet [you]151-susan now only as [[his]4800-that man widow]4802-his widow — [I]1434-the poor woman consider [myself]1434-the poor woman that , and that [I]1434-the poor woman have no claim upon [you]151-susan . Had [he]4800-that man not died [I]1434-the poor woman should never have come — never ! Of that [you]151-susan may be sure . ”[1434-the poor woman] “ Ts - s - s ! How could [you]151-susan be so simple ? ”[151-susan] “ [I]151-susan do n't know . Yet it would have been very wicked — if [I]151-susan had not thought like that ! ”[151-susan] said [Susan]151-susan , almost crying . “ Yes — yes — so it would . It is only that which makes [me]151-susan feel ' ee [an innocent woman]4803-an innocent woman . But — to lead [me]151-susan into this ! ”[151-susan] “ What , [Michael]120-henchard ? ”[151-susan] [she]151-susan asked , alarmed . “ Why , this difficulty about [our]4804-our living together again , and [Elizabeth]191-henchard - [Jane]191-henchard . [She]191-henchard can not be told all — [she]191-henchard would so despise [us]4804-our both that — [I]1434-the poor woman could not bear it ! ”[1434-the poor woman] “ That was why [she]191-henchard was brought up in ignorance of [you]120-henchard . [I]1434-the poor woman could not bear it either . ”[1434-the poor woman] “ Well — [we]4804-our must talk of a plan for keeping [her]191-henchard in [her]191-henchard present belief , and getting matters straight in spite of it . [You]120-henchard have heard [I]1435-i am in a large way of business here — that [I]1435-i am [Mayor of [the town]632-the town]4714-mayor of the town , and [churchwarden]4807-churchwarden , and [I]1435-i do n't know what all ? ”[1435-i] “ Yes , ”[1435-i] [she]1435-i murmured . “ These things , as well as the dread of [the girl]311-the girl discovering [our]4804-our disgrace , makes it necessary to act with extreme caution . So that [I]1434-the poor woman do n't see how [[you]120-henchard two]4809-you two can return openly to [[my]1434-the poor woman house]4643-my house as [the wife]321-the wife and [daughter]603-daughter [I]1434-the poor woman once treated badly , and banished from [me]1434-the poor woman ; and there 's the rub o't . ”[1434-the poor woman] “ [We]4804-our 'll go away at once . [I]1435-i only came to see — ”[1435-i] “ No , no , [Susan]151-susan ; [you]151-susan are not to go — [you]151-susan mistake [me]1435-i ! ”[1435-i] [he]1435-i said with kindly severity . “ [I]1436-i have thought of this plan : that [you]151-susan and [Elizabeth]191-henchard take [a cottage in [the town]632-the town]4813-a cottage in the town as [the widow [Mrs. Newson]128-henchard and [[her]128-henchard daughter]4518-her daughter]4815-the widow mrs. newson and her daughter ; that [I]1436-i meet [you]151-susan , court [you]151-susan , and marry [you]151-susan . [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard coming to [[my]1436-i house]4643-my house as [[my]1436-i step - daughter]4818-my step - daughter . This would leave [my]1436-i shady , headstrong , disgraceful life as [a young man]285-a young man absolutely unopened ; the secret would be [yours]151-susan and [mine]1436-i only ; and [I]1436-i should have the pleasure of seeing [[my]1436-i own only child under [my]1436-i roof]4820-my own only child under my roof , as well as [[my]1436-i wife]4821-my wife . ”[1436-i] “ [I]1436-i am quite in [your]1436-i hands , [Michael]120-henchard , ”[1436-i] [she]1436-i said meekly . “ [I]120-henchard came here for the sake of [Elizabeth]191-henchard ; for [myself]120-henchard , if [you]1436-i tell [me]120-henchard to leave again to - morrow morning , and never come near [you]191-henchard more , [I]120-henchard am content to go . ”[120-henchard] “ Now , now ; [we]4822-our do n't want to hear that , ”[120-henchard] said [Henchard]120-henchard gently . “ Of course [you]191-henchard wo n't leave again . Think over the plan [I]1436-i have proposed for a few hours ; and if [you]191-henchard ca n't hit upon a better one [we]4822-our 'll adopt it . [I]1436-i have to be away for a day or two on business , unfortunately ; but during that time [you]191-henchard can get lodgings — the only ones in [the town]632-the town fit for [you]191-henchard are those over [the china - shop in [High Street]27-high street]4824-the china - shop in high street — and [you]191-henchard can also look for [a cottage]4825-a cottage . ”[1436-i] “ If [the lodgings]4826-the lodgings are in [High Street]27-high street [they]4826-the lodgings are dear , [I]1436-i suppose ? ”[1436-i] “ Never mind — [you]191-henchard MUST start genteel if [our]4822-our plan is to be carried out . Look to [me]1437-i for money . Have [you]191-henchard enough till [I]1437-i come back ? ”[1437-i] “ Quite , ”[1437-i] said [she]1437-i . “ And are [you]191-henchard comfortable at [the inn]939-the inn ? ”[1436-i] “ O yes . ”[1436-i] “ And [the girl]311-the girl is quite safe from learning the shame of [her]311-the girl case and [ours]4822-our ? — that 's what makes [me]1437-i most anxious of all . ”[1437-i] “ [You]191-henchard would be surprised to find how unlikely [she]311-the girl is to dream of the truth . How could [she]311-the girl ever suppose such a thing ? ”[1436-i] “ True ! ”[128-henchard] “ [I]128-henchard like the idea of repeating [our]4822-our marriage , ”[128-henchard] said [Mrs. Henchard]128-henchard , after a pause . “ It seems the only right course , after all this . Now [I]1437-i think [I]1437-i must go back to [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard , and tell [her]191-henchard that [[our]4822-our kinsman]4829-our kinsman , [Mr. Henchard]120-henchard , kindly wishes [us]4822-our to stay in [the town]632-the town . ”[1437-i] “ Very well — arrange that [yourself]1437-i . [I]380-his wife 'll go some way with [you]1437-i . ”[380-his wife] “ No , no . Do n't run any risk ! ”[380-his wife] said [[his]1438-his wife]380-his wife anxiously . “ [I]120-henchard can find [my]120-henchard way back — it is not late . Please let [me]120-henchard go alone . ”[120-henchard] “ Right , ”[120-henchard] said [Henchard]120-henchard . “ But just one word . Do [you]1437-i forgive [me]120-henchard , [Susan]151-susan ? ”[120-henchard] [She]380-his wife murmured something ; but seemed to find it difficult to frame [her]380-his wife answer . “ Never mind — all in good time , ”[120-henchard] said [he]120-henchard . “ Judge [me]120-henchard by [my]120-henchard future works — good - bye ! ”[120-henchard] [He]120-henchard retreated , and stood at the upper side of [the Amphitheatre]1383-the amphitheatre while [[his]1438-his wife]380-his wife passed out through the lower way , and descended under the trees to [the town]632-the town . Then [Henchard]120-henchard [himself]120-henchard went homeward , going so fast that by the time [he]120-henchard reached [his]120-henchard door [he]120-henchard was almost upon the heels of [the unconscious woman from whom [he]120-henchard had just parted]1443-the unconscious woman from whom he had just parted . [He]120-henchard watched [her]1443-the unconscious woman from whom he had just parted up [the street]797-the street , and turned into [[his]1438-his house]1329-his house .

On entering [his]1438-his own door after watching [[his]1438-his wife]380-his wife out of sight , [the Mayor]4556-the mayor walked on through the tunnel - shaped passage into [the garden]1272-the garden , and thence by the back door towards [the stores and granaries]1449-the stores and granaries . A light shone from [the office]1349-the office - window , and there being no blind to screen the interior [Henchard]120-henchard could see [Donald Farfrae]139-farfrae still seated where [he]1438-his had left [him]1438-his , initiating [himself]1438-his into the managerial work of [the house]782-the house by overhauling the books . [Henchard]120-henchard entered , merely observing , “ Do n't let [me]120-henchard interrupt [you]139-farfrae , if [ye]139-farfrae will stay so late . ”[120-henchard] [He]120-henchard stood behind [Farfrae]139-farfrae 's chair , watching [his]1438-his dexterity in clearing up the numerical fogs which had been allowed to grow so thick in [Henchard]120-henchard 's books as almost to baffle even [the Scotchman]886-the scotchman 's perspicacity . [The corn - factor 's mien]1453-the corn - factor 's mien was half admiring , and yet it was not without a dash of pity for the tastes of [any one who could care to give [his]1438-his mind to such finnikin details]1454-any one who could care to give his mind to such finnikin details . [Henchard]120-henchard [himself]120-henchard was mentally and physically unfit for grubbing subtleties from soiled paper ; [he]120-henchard had in a modern sense received the education of [Achilles]154-achilles , and found penmanship a tantalizing art . “ [You]139-farfrae shall do no more to - night , ”[120-henchard] [he]120-henchard said at length , spreading [his]120-henchard great hand over the paper . “ There 's time enough to - morrow . [I]120-henchard am determined on't . ”[120-henchard] [He]120-henchard shut the account - books with friendly force . [Donald]139-farfrae had wished to get to [[his]120-henchard lodgings]1455-his lodgings ; but [he]120-henchard already saw that [[his]120-henchard friend]1456-his friend and [employer]1457-employer was [a man who knew no moderation in [his]120-henchard requests and impulses]1458-a man who knew no moderation in his requests and impulses , and [he]120-henchard yielded gracefully . [He]120-henchard liked [Henchard]120-henchard 's warmth , even if it inconvenienced [him]120-henchard ; the great difference in [their]1459-they characters adding to the liking . [They]1459-they locked up [the office]1349-the office , and [the young man]371-the young man followed [[his]371-the young man companion]1462-his companion through the private little door which , admitting directly into [[Henchard]120-henchard 's garden]1463-henchard 's garden , permitted a passage from the utilitarian to the beautiful at one step . [The garden]1272-the garden was silent , dewy , and full of perfume . [It]1272-the garden extended a long way back from [the house]782-the house , first as [lawn and flower - beds]1466-lawn and flower - beds , then as [fruit - garden , where the long - tied espaliers , as old as [the old house itself]1468-the old house itself]1467-fruit - garden , where the long - tied espaliers , as old as the old house itself , had grown so stout , and cramped , and gnarled that [they]1469-they had pulled [their]1469-they stakes out of the ground and stood distorted and writhing in vegetable agony , like leafy Laocoons . The flowers which smelt so sweetly were not discernible ; and [they]1469-they passed through [them]1469-they into [the house]782-the house . The hospitalities of the morning were repeated , and when [they]1459-they were over [Henchard]120-henchard said , “ Pull [your]371-the young man chair round to the fireplace , [[my]120-henchard dear fellow]4832-my dear fellow , and let 's make a blaze — there 's nothing [I]120-henchard hate like a black grate , even in September . ”[120-henchard] [He]120-henchard applied a light to the laid - in fuel , and a cheerful radiance spread around . “ It is odd , ”[120-henchard] said [Henchard]120-henchard , “ that [two men]736-two men should meet as [we]736-two men have done on a purely business ground , and that at the end of the first day [I]139-farfrae should wish to speak to ' [ee]4834-ee on a family matter . But , damn it all , [I]139-farfrae am [a lonely man]4835-a lonely man , [Farfrae]139-farfrae : [I]139-farfrae have [nobody else]4836-nobody else to speak to ; and why should n't [I]139-farfrae tell it to ' [ee]4834-ee ? ”[139-farfrae] “ [I]120-henchard 'll be glad to hear it , if [I]120-henchard can be of any service , ”[120-henchard] said [Donald]139-farfrae , allowing [his]1471-his eyes to travel over the intricate wood - carvings of the chimney - piece , representing garlanded lyres , shields , and quivers , on either side of a draped ox - skull , and flanked by heads of [Apollo]155-apollo and [Diana]156-diana in low relief . “ [I]4432-men 've not been always what [I]4432-men am now , ”[4432-men] continued [Henchard]120-henchard , [his]120-henchard firm deep voice being ever so little shaken . [He]120-henchard was plainly under that strange influence which sometimes prompts [men]4432-men to confide to [the new - found friend]1473-the new - found friend what [they]4432-men will not tell to [the old]1474-the old . “ [I]120-henchard began life as [a working hay - trusser]4837-a working hay - trusser , and when [I]120-henchard was eighteen [I]120-henchard married on the strength o ' [my]120-henchard calling . Would [you]120-henchard think [me]120-henchard [a married man]4838-a married man ? ”[120-henchard] “ [I]4432-men heard in [the town]632-the town that [you]4432-men were [a widower]4840-a widower . ”[4432-men] “ Ah , yes — [you]4432-men would naturally have heard that . Well , [I]120-henchard lost [[my]120-henchard wife]4821-my wife nineteen years ago or so — by [my]120-henchard own fault .... This is how it came about . It has been [my]139-farfrae custom for many years to run across to [Jersey]43-jersey in the the way of business , particularly in the potato and root season . [I]139-farfrae do a large trade wi ' them in that line . Well , one autumn when stopping [there]447-there [I]139-farfrae fell quite ill , and in [my]139-farfrae illness [I]139-farfrae sank into one of those gloomy fits [I]139-farfrae sometimes suffer from , on account o ' the loneliness of [my]139-farfrae domestic life , when [the world]4424-the world seems to have the blackness of hell , and , like [Job]157-job , [I]139-farfrae could curse the day that gave [me]139-farfrae birth . ”[139-farfrae] “ Ah , now , [I]139-farfrae never feel like it , ”[139-farfrae] said [Farfrae]139-farfrae . “ Then pray to [God]126-god that [you]139-farfrae never may , [young man]4644-young man . While in this state [I]1478-i was taken pity on by [a woman]647-a woman — [a young lady [I]1478-i should call [her]4858-a young lady i should call her]4858-a young lady i should call her , for [she]4858-a young lady i should call her was of good family , well bred , and well educated — [the daughter of [some harum - scarum military officer who had got into difficulties , and had [his]4860-some harum - scarum military officer who had got into difficulties , and had his pay sequestrated pay sequestrated]4860-some harum - scarum military officer who had got into difficulties , and had his pay sequestrated . But being together in [the same house]4864-the same house , and [her]4862-this young creature feeling warm , [we]4865-we got naturally intimate . [I]1478-i wo n't go into particulars of what [our]4865-we relations were . It is enough to say that [we]4865-we honestly meant to marry . There arose a scandal , which did [me]1478-i no harm , but was of course ruin to [her]4862-this young creature . Though , [Farfrae]139-farfrae , between [you]139-farfrae and [me]1478-i , as [man]488-man and [man]488-man , [I]1478-i solemnly declare that philandering with [womankind]4868-womankind has neither been [my]1478-i vice nor [my]1478-i virtue . [She]4862-this young creature was terribly careless of appearances , and [I]1478-i was perhaps more , because o ' [my]1478-i dreary state ; and it was through this that the scandal arose . At last [I]1478-i was well , and came away . When [I]1478-i was gone [she]4862-this young creature suffered much on [my]1478-i account , and did n't forget to tell [me]1478-i so in letters one after another ; till latterly , [I]1478-i felt [I]1478-i owed [her]4862-this young creature something , and thought that , as [I]1478-i had not heard of [Susan]151-susan for so long , [I]1478-i would make this other one the only return [I]1478-i could make , and ask [her]4862-this young creature if [she]4862-this young creature would run the risk of [Susan]151-susan being alive ( very slight as [I]1478-i believed ) and marry [me]1478-i , such as [I]1478-i was . [She]4862-this young creature jumped for joy , and [we]4869-we should no doubt soon have been married — but , behold , [Susan]151-susan appears ! ”[1478-i] [Donald]139-farfrae showed [his]1478-i deep concern at a complication so far beyond the degree of [his]1478-i simple experiences . “ Now see what injury [a man]4474-a man may cause around [him]4474-a man ! Even after that wrong - doing at the fair when [I]139-farfrae was young , if [I]139-farfrae had never been so selfish as to let [this giddy girl]4871-this giddy girl devote [herself]4871-this giddy girl to [me]139-farfrae over at [Jersey]43-jersey , to the injury of [her]4862-this young creature name , all might now be well . [My]139-farfrae first duty is to [Susan]151-susan — there 's no doubt about that . ”[139-farfrae] “ [They]4873-these women are both in a very melancholy position , and that 's true ! ”[139-farfrae] murmured [Donald]139-farfrae . “ [They]4873-these women are ! For [myself]120-henchard [I]120-henchard do n't care — ' twill all end one way . But these two . ”[120-henchard] [Henchard]120-henchard paused in reverie . “ [I]338-the other feel [I]338-the other should like to treat [the second]4874-the second , no less than the first , as kindly as [a man]4474-a man can in such a case . ”[338-the other] “ Ah , well , it cannet be helped ! ”[338-the other] said [the other]338-the other , with philosophic woefulness . “ [You]338-the other mun write to [the young lady]4876-the young lady , and in [your]338-the other letter [you]338-the other must put it plain and honest that it turns out [she]4876-the young lady cannet be [[your]338-the other wife]4877-your wife , the first having come back ; that [ye]338-the other cannet see [her]4876-the young lady more ; and that — [ye]338-the other wish [her]4876-the young lady weel . ”[120-henchard] “ That wo n't do . [[My]120-henchard wife]4821-my wife [Susan]151-susan has [[my]120-henchard daughter]4881-my daughter with [her]151-susan — [the baby that was in [her]151-susan arms at the fair]4882-the baby that was in her arms at the fair ; and [this girl]4461-this girl knows nothing of [me]120-henchard beyond that [I]120-henchard am some sort of relation by marriage . [She]4461-this girl has grown up in the belief that [the sailor to whom [I]120-henchard made over [[her]4461-this girl mother]588-her mother , and who is now dead , was [[her]4461-this girl father]4886-her father , and [[her]4461-this girl mother 's husband]4887-her mother 's husband]4884-the sailor to whom i made over her mother , and who is now dead , was her father , and her mother 's husband . The letter to [the young Jersey woman]1480-the young jersey woman was carefully framed by [him]120-henchard , and the interview ended , [Henchard]120-henchard saying , as [the Scotchman]886-the scotchman left , “ [I]139-farfrae feel it a great relief , [Farfrae]139-farfrae , to tell [some friend]4895-some friend o ' this ! And [I]120-henchard 'm sorry for [ye]139-farfrae ! ”[120-henchard] said [Farfrae]139-farfrae .
