Now then , to make amends to [Susan]151-susan ! ”[120-henchard]

The cottage which [Michael Henchard]120-henchard hired for [[his]120-henchard wife]380-his wife [Susan]151-susan under [her]151-susan name of [Newson]151-susan — in pursuance of [their]1484-their plan — was in [the upper or western part of [the town]632-the town]1485-the upper or western part of the town , near the Roman wall , and [the avenue which overshadowed [it]1488-it]1487-the avenue which overshadowed it . The evening sun seemed to shine more yellowly there than anywhere else this autumn — stretching its rays , as the hours grew later , under the lowest sycamore boughs , and steeping the ground - floor of [the dwelling]1489-the dwelling , with [its]1488-it green shutters , in a substratum of radiance which the foliage screened from the upper parts . Beneath these sycamores on the town walls could be seen from [the sitting - room the tumuli and earth forts of [the distant uplands]1491-the distant uplands]1490-the sitting - room the tumuli and earth forts of the distant uplands ; making [it]1488-it altogether [a pleasant spot]1492-a pleasant spot , with the usual touch of melancholy that a past - marked prospect lends . As soon as [the mother]586-the mother and [daughter]603-daughter were comfortably installed , with [a white - aproned servant]1495-a white - aproned servant and [all complete]1496-all complete , [Henchard]120-henchard paid [them]1484-their a visit , and remained to tea . During the entertainment [Elizabeth]191-henchard was carefully hoodwinked by the very general tone of the conversation that prevailed — a proceeding which seemed to afford some humour to [Henchard]120-henchard , though [[his]120-henchard wife]380-his wife was not particularly happy in it . The visit was repeated again and again with business - like determination by [the Mayor]4556-the mayor , who seemed to have schooled [himself]4556-the mayor into a course of strict mechanical rightness towards [this woman of prior claim]1499-this woman of prior claim , at any expense to [the later one]1500-the later one and to [his]4556-the mayor own sentiments . One afternoon [the daughter]591-the daughter was not indoors when [Henchard]120-henchard came , and [he]120-henchard said drily , “ This is a very good opportunity for [me]1434-the poor woman to ask [you]591-the daughter to name the happy day , [Susan]151-susan . ”[1434-the poor woman] [The poor woman]1434-the poor woman smiled faintly ; [she]1434-the poor woman did not enjoy pleasantries on a situation into which [she]1434-the poor woman had entered solely for the sake of [[her]1434-the poor woman girl]1503-her girl 's reputation . [She]1434-the poor woman liked them so little , indeed , that there was room for wonder why [she]1434-the poor woman had countenanced deception at all , and had not bravely let [the girl]311-the girl know [her]1434-the poor woman history . But the flesh is weak ; and the true explanation came in due course . “ O [Michael]120-henchard ! ”[1434-the poor woman] [she]1434-the poor woman said , “ [I]120-henchard am afraid all this is taking up [your]120-henchard time and giving trouble — when [I]120-henchard did not expect any such thing ! ”[120-henchard] And [she]1434-the poor woman looked at [him]120-henchard and at [his]120-henchard dress as [a man of affluence]1505-a man of affluence , and at the furniture [he]120-henchard had provided for [the room]985-the room — ornate and lavish to [her]1434-the poor woman eyes . “ Not at all , ”[120-henchard] said [Henchard]120-henchard , in rough benignity . “ This is only [a cottage]4825-a cottage — it costs [me]120-henchard next to nothing . And as to taking up [my]120-henchard time ”[120-henchard] — here [his]120-henchard red and black visage kindled with satisfaction — “ [I]128-henchard 've [a splendid fellow]4898-a splendid fellow to superintend [my]128-henchard business now — [a man whose like [I]128-henchard 've never been able to lay hands on before]4899-a man whose like i 've never been able to lay hands on before . [I]128-henchard shall soon be able to leave everything to [him]120-henchard , and have more time to call [my]128-henchard own than [I]128-henchard 've had for these last twenty years . ”[128-henchard] [Henchard]120-henchard 's visits [here]4417-here grew so frequent and so regular that it soon became whispered , and then openly discussed in [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge that [the masterful , coercive Mayor of [the town]632-the town]1508-the masterful , coercive mayor of the town was raptured and enervated by [the genteel widow [Mrs. Newson]128-henchard]1510-the genteel widow mrs. newson . [His]120-henchard well - known haughty indifference to the society of [womankind]4868-womankind , [his]120-henchard silent avoidance of converse with the sex , contributed a piquancy to what would otherwise have been an unromantic matter enough . That [such a poor fragile woman]1512-such a poor fragile woman should be [his]120-henchard choice was inexplicable , except on the ground that the engagement was a family affair in which sentimental passion had no place ; for it was known that [they]1513-they were related in some way . [Mrs. Henchard]128-henchard was so pale that [the boys]1413-the boys called [her]128-henchard “ [The Ghost]4900-the ghost . ”[132-christopher coney] Sometimes [Henchard]128-henchard overheard this epithet when [they]1513-they passed together along [the Walks]1515-the walks — as the avenues on the walls were named — at which [his]120-henchard face would darken with an expression of destructiveness towards [the speakers ominous to see]1516-the speakers ominous to see ; but [he]120-henchard said nothing . [He]120-henchard pressed on the preparations for [his]120-henchard union , or rather reunion , with [this pale creature]1517-this pale creature in a dogged , unflinching spirit which did credit to [his]120-henchard conscientiousness . [Nobody]298-nobody would have conceived from [his]120-henchard outward demeanour that there was no amatory fire or pulse of romance acting as stimulant to the bustle going on in [[his]120-henchard gaunt , great house]1519-his gaunt , great house ; nothing but three large resolves — one , to make amends to [his]120-henchard neglected [Susan]151-susan , another , to provide [a comfortable home for [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard under [his]120-henchard paternal eye]1520-a comfortable home for elizabeth - jane under his paternal eye ; and a third , to castigate [himself]120-henchard with the thorns which these restitutory acts brought in [their]1521-their train ; among them the lowering of [his]120-henchard dignity in public opinion by marrying [so comparatively humble a woman]1522-so comparatively humble a woman . [Susan Henchard]122-henchard entered [a carriage]1523-a carriage for the first time in [her]1524-her life when [she]1524-her stepped into the plain brougham which drew up at the door on the wedding - day to take [her]1524-her and [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard to [church]1525-church . It was a windless morning of warm November rain , which floated down like meal , and lay in a powdery form on the nap of hats and coats . [Few people]1526-few people had gathered round [the church]552-the church door though [they]1526-few people were well packed within . [The Scotchman]153-the scotchman , who assisted as [groomsman]1528-groomsman , was of course the only one present , beyond [the chief actors , who knew the true situation of the contracting parties]1529-the chief actors , who knew the true situation of the contracting parties . [He]153-the scotchman , however , was too inexperienced , too thoughtful , too judicial , too strongly conscious of the serious side of the business , to enter into the scene in its dramatic aspect . That required the special genius of [Christopher Coney]132-christopher coney , [Solomon Longways]131-longways , [Buzzford]142-buzzford , and [[their]1521-their fellows]1530-their fellows . But [they]1521-their knew nothing of the secret ; though , as the time for coming out of [church]1525-church drew on , [they]1521-their gathered on [the pavement]1160-the pavement adjoining , and expounded the subject according to [their]1521-their lights . “ ' Tis five - and - forty years since [I]132-christopher coney had [[my]132-christopher coney settlement]4901-my settlement in this [here town]4902-here town , ”[132-christopher coney] said [Coney]132-christopher coney ; “ but daze [me]1536-that lady if [I]1536-that lady ever see [a man]4474-a man wait so long before to take so little ! There 's a chance even for [thee]122-henchard after this , [Nance Mockridge]158-nance . ”[1536-that lady] The remark was addressed to [a woman who stood behind [his]132-christopher coney shoulder]1533-a woman who stood behind his shoulder — [the same who had exhibited [Henchard]122-henchard 's bad bread in public when [Elizabeth]191-henchard and [[her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother entered [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge]1534-the same who had exhibited henchard 's bad bread in public when elizabeth and her mother entered casterbridge . “ Be cust if [I]1536-that lady 'd marry any such as [he]132-christopher coney , or [thee]122-henchard either , ”[1536-that lady] replied [that lady]1536-that lady . “ As for [thee]122-henchard , [Christopher]132-christopher coney , [we]4904-we know what [ye]122-henchard be , and the less said the better . And as for [he]132-christopher coney — well , there — ( lowering [her]1536-that lady voice ) ' tis said ' a was [a poor parish ' prentice]4905-a poor parish ' prentice — [I]131-longways would n't say it for all [the world]4424-the world — but ' a was [a poor parish ' prentice]4905-a poor parish ' prentice , that began life wi ' no more belonging to ' en than a carrion crow . ”[131-longways] “ And now [he]132-christopher coney 's worth ever so much a minute , ”[131-longways] murmured [Longways]131-longways . “ When [a man]4474-a man is said to be worth so much a minute , [he]132-christopher coney 's [a man]4474-a man to be considered ! ”[131-longways] Turning , [he]131-longways saw a circular disc reticulated with creases , and recognized the smiling countenance of [the fat woman who had asked for another song at the Three Mariners]1537-the fat woman who had asked for another song at the three mariners . “ Well , [Mother Cuxsom]145-mother cuxsom , ”[131-longways] [he]131-longways said , “ how 's this ? Here 's [Mrs. Newson]128-henchard , [a mere skellinton]4910-a mere skellinton , has got [another husband]4911-another husband to keep [her]128-henchard , while [a woman of [your]145-mother cuxsom tonnage]4912-a woman of your tonnage have not . ”[1536-that lady] “ [I]159-mrs. cuxsom have not . Nor another to beat [me]159-mrs. cuxsom .... Ah , yes , [Cuxsom]145-mother cuxsom 's gone , and so shall leather breeches ! ”[159-mrs. cuxsom] “ Yes ; with the blessing of [God]126-god leather breeches shall go . ”[159-mrs. cuxsom] “ ' Tisn't worth [my]159-mrs. cuxsom old while to think of [another husband]4911-another husband , ”[159-mrs. cuxsom] continued [Mrs. Cuxsom]159-mrs. cuxsom . “ And yet [I]159-mrs. cuxsom 'll lay [my]159-mrs. cuxsom life [I]159-mrs. cuxsom 'm as respectable born as [she]1537-the fat woman who had asked for another song at the three mariners . ”[159-mrs. cuxsom] “ True ; [[your]145-mother cuxsom mother]4779-your mother was [a very good woman]4915-a very good woman — [I]159-mrs. cuxsom can mind [her]4779-your mother . [She]4779-your mother were rewarded by [the Agricultural Society]4916-the agricultural society for having begot the greatest number of [healthy children]4917-healthy children without parish assistance , and other virtuous marvels . ”[159-mrs. cuxsom] “ ' Twas that that kept [us]4918-we so low upon ground — [that great hungry family]4919-that great hungry family . ”[159-mrs. cuxsom] “ Ay . Where the pigs be many the wash runs thin . ”[159-mrs. cuxsom] “ And dostn't mind how [mother]4495-mother would sing , [Christopher]132-christopher coney ? ”[159-mrs. cuxsom] continued [Mrs. Cuxsom]159-mrs. cuxsom , kindling at the retrospection ; “ and how [we]4918-we went with [her]4495-mother to the party at [Mellstock]29-mellstock , do [ye]132-christopher coney mind ? — at old [Dame Ledlow]160-dame ledlow 's , [[farmer Shinar]4921-farmer shinar 's aunt]4922-farmer shinar 's aunt , do [ye]132-christopher coney mind ? — [she]4495-mother [we]4918-we used to call Toad - skin , because [her]4495-mother face were so yaller and freckled , do [ye]132-christopher coney mind ? ”[132-christopher coney] “ [I]1538-i do , hee - hee , [I]1538-i do ! ”[1538-i] said [Christopher Coney]132-christopher coney . “ And well do [I]1538-i — for [I]1538-i was getting up husband - high at that time — [one - half girl]4923-one - half girl , and [t'other half woman]4924-t'other half woman , as [one]1127-one may say . And canst mind ”[1538-i] — [she]1538-i prodded [Solomon]131-longways 's shoulder with [her]1538-i finger - tip , while [her]1538-i eyes twinkled between the crevices of their lids — “ canst mind the sherry - wine , and the zilver - snuffers , and how [Joan Dummett]161-joan dummett was took bad when [we]4918-we were coming [home]675-home , and [Jack Griggs]162-jack griggs was forced to carry [her]161-joan dummett through the mud ; and how ' a let [her]161-joan dummett fall in [Dairyman Sweet - apple]163-dairyman sweet - apple 's cow - barton , and [we]4918-we had to clane [her]161-joan dummett gown wi ' grass — never such a mess as a ' were in ? ”[1538-i] “ Ay — that [I]158-nance do — hee - hee , such doggery as there was in [them]1539-them ancient days , to be sure ! Ah , the miles [I]158-nance used to walk then ; and now [I]158-nance can hardly step over a furrow ! ”[158-nance] [Their]1539-them reminiscences were cut short by the appearance of [the reunited pair]1540-the reunited pair — [Henchard]128-henchard looking round upon [the idlers]815-the idlers with that ambiguous gaze of [his]1542-he , which at one moment seemed to mean satisfaction , and at another fiery disdain . “ Well — there 's a difference between ['em]4927-'em , though [he]1542-he do call [himself]1542-he [a teetotaller]4928-a teetotaller , ”[158-nance] said [Nance Mockridge]158-nance . “ [She]161-joan dummett 'll wish [her]161-joan dummett cake dough afore [she]161-joan dummett 's done of [him]1542-he . There 's a blue - beardy look about ' en ; and ' twill out in time . ”[1543-the plain little brougham] “ Stuff — [he]1542-he 's well enough ! [Some folk]4929-some folk want [their]4929-some folk luck buttered . If [I]131-longways had a choice as wide as [the ocean sea]4930-the ocean sea [I]131-longways would n't wish for [a better man]4931-a better man . [A poor twanking woman like [her]161-joan dummett]4932-a poor twanking woman like her — ' tis a godsend for [her]161-joan dummett , and hardly a pair of jumps or night - rail to [her]161-joan dummett name . ”[131-longways] [The plain little brougham]1543-the plain little brougham drove off in the mist , and [the idlers]815-the idlers dispersed . “ Well , [we]4933-we hardly know how to look at things in these times ! ”[131-longways] said [Solomon]131-longways . “ There was [a man]4474-a man dropped down dead yesterday , not so very many miles from here ; and what wi ' that , and this moist weather , ' tis scarce worth one 's while to begin any work o ' consequence to - day . [I]132-christopher coney 'm in such a low key with drinking nothing but small table ninepenny this last week or two that [I]132-christopher coney shall call and warm up at the Mar'ners as [I]132-christopher coney pass along . ”[132-christopher coney] “ [I]132-christopher coney do n't know but that [I]132-christopher coney may as well go with ' ee , [Solomon]131-longways , ”[132-christopher coney] said [Christopher]132-christopher coney ; “ [I]191-henchard 'm as clammy as a cockle - snail . ”[191-henchard]

A Martinmas summer of [Mrs. Henchard]128-henchard 's life set in with [her]128-henchard entry into [[[her]128-henchard husband]387-her husband 's large house]1546-her husband 's large house and respectable social orbit ; and it was as bright as such summers well can be . Lest [she]128-henchard should pine for deeper affection than [he]387-her husband could give [he]387-her husband made a point of showing some semblance of it in external action . Among other things [he]387-her husband had the iron railings , that had smiled sadly in dull rust for the last eighty years , painted a bright green , and the heavy - barred , small - paned Georgian sash windows enlivened with three coats of white . [He]387-her husband was as kind to [her]128-henchard as [a man]4474-a man , [mayor]1548-mayor , and [churchwarden]4807-churchwarden could possibly be . [The house]782-the house was large , [the rooms]1551-the rooms lofty , and the landings wide ; and [the two unassuming women]1552-the two unassuming women scarcely made a perceptible addition to [its]782-the house contents . To [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard the time was a most triumphant one . The freedom [she]191-henchard experienced , the indulgence with which [she]191-henchard was treated , went beyond [her]191-henchard expectations . The reposeful , easy , affluent life to which [[her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother 's marriage had introduced [her]191-henchard was , in truth , the beginning of a great change in [Elizabeth]191-henchard . [She]191-henchard found [she]191-henchard could have nice personal possessions and ornaments for the asking , and , as the mediaeval saying puts it , “ Take , have , and keep , are pleasant words . ”[191-henchard] With peace of mind came development , and with development beauty . Knowledge — the result of great natural insight — [she]191-henchard did not lack ; learning , accomplishment — those , alas , [she]191-henchard had not ; but as the winter and spring passed by [her]191-henchard thin face and figure filled out in rounder and softer curves ; the lines and contractions upon [her]191-henchard young brow went away ; the muddiness of skin which [she]191-henchard had looked upon as [her]191-henchard lot by nature departed with a change to abundance of good things , and a bloom came upon [her]191-henchard cheek . Perhaps , too , [her]191-henchard grey , thoughtful eyes revealed an arch gaiety sometimes ; but this was infrequent ; the sort of wisdom which looked from [[their]1554-their pupils]1555-their pupils did not readily keep company with these lighter moods . Like [all people who have known rough times]1556-all people who have known rough times , light - heartedness seemed to [her]191-henchard too irrational and inconsequent to be indulged in except as a reckless dram now and then ; for [she]191-henchard had been too early habituated to anxious reasoning to drop the habit suddenly . [She]191-henchard felt none of those ups and downs of spirit which beset [so many people without cause]1557-so many people without cause ; never — to paraphrase [a recent poet]1558-a recent poet — never a gloom in [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard 's soul but [she]191-henchard well knew how it came there ; and [her]191-henchard present cheerfulness was fairly proportionate to [her]191-henchard solid guarantees for the same . It might have been supposed that , given [a girl]1559-a girl rapidly becoming good - looking , comfortably circumstanced , and for the first time in [her]191-henchard life commanding ready money , [she]191-henchard would go and make a fool of [herself]191-henchard by dress . But no . The reasonableness of almost everything that [Elizabeth]191-henchard did was nowhere more conspicuous than in this question of clothes . To keep in the rear of opportunity in matters of indulgence is as valuable a habit as to keep abreast of opportunity in matters of enterprise . [This unsophisticated girl]1560-this unsophisticated girl did it by an innate perceptiveness that was almost genius . Thus [she]191-henchard refrained from bursting out like a water - flower that spring , and clothing [herself]191-henchard in puffings and knick - knacks , as [most of [the Casterbridge girls]1562-the casterbridge girls]1561-most of the casterbridge girls would have done in [her]191-henchard circumstances . [Her]191-henchard triumph was tempered by circumspection , [she]191-henchard had still that field - mouse fear of the coulter of destiny despite fair promise , which is common among [the thoughtful who have suffered early from poverty and oppression]1563-the thoughtful who have suffered early from poverty and oppression . “ [I]191-henchard wo n't be too gay on any account , ”[191-henchard] [she]191-henchard would say to [herself]191-henchard . “ It would be tempting [Providence]35-providence to hurl [mother]4495-mother and [me]191-henchard down , and afflict [us]1564-us again as [He]35-providence used to do . ”[191-henchard] [We]1564-us now see [her]191-henchard in a black silk bonnet , velvet mantle or silk spencer , dark dress , and carrying a sunshade . In this latter article [she]191-henchard drew the line at fringe , and had it plain edged , with a little ivory ring for keeping it closed . It was odd about the necessity for that sunshade . [She]191-henchard discovered that with the clarification of [her]191-henchard complexion and the birth of pink cheeks [her]191-henchard skin had grown more sensitive to the sun 's rays . [She]191-henchard protected those cheeks forthwith , deeming spotlessness part of womanliness . [Henchard]128-henchard had become very fond of [her]191-henchard , and [she]191-henchard went out with [him]1565-he more frequently than with [[her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother now . [Her]191-henchard appearance one day was so attractive that [he]1565-he looked at [her]191-henchard critically . “ [I]1565-he happened to have the ribbon by [me]1565-he , so [I]1565-he made it up , ”[1565-he] [she]191-henchard faltered , thinking [him]1565-he perhaps dissatisfied with some rather bright trimming [she]191-henchard had donned for the first time . “ Ay — of course — to be sure , ”[165-indoors] [he]1565-he replied in [his]1565-he leonine way . “ Do as [you]191-henchard like — or rather as [[your]191-henchard mother]4779-your mother advises [ye]191-henchard . ' Od send — [I]1565-he 've nothing to say to't ! ”[1565-he] [Indoors]165-indoors [she]191-henchard appeared with [her]191-henchard hair divided by a parting that arched like a white rainbow from ear to ear . All in front of this line was covered with a thick encampment of curls ; all behind was dressed smoothly , and drawn to a knob . [The three members of [the family]574-the family]1567-the three members of the family were sitting at breakfast one day , and [Henchard]128-henchard was looking silently , as [he]1565-he often did , at this head of hair , which in colour was brown — rather light than dark . “ [I]380-his wife thought [Elizabeth]191-henchard - [Jane]191-henchard 's hair — did n't [you]380-his wife tell [me]380-his wife that [Elizabeth]191-henchard - [Jane]191-henchard 's hair promised to be black when [she]191-henchard was [a baby]4937-a baby ? ”[380-his wife] [he]1565-he said to [[his]1565-he wife]380-his wife . [She]380-his wife looked startled , jerked [his]1565-he foot warningly , and murmured , “ Did [I]128-henchard ? ”[128-henchard] As soon as [Elizabeth]191-henchard was gone to [[her]191-henchard own room]1570-her own room [Henchard]128-henchard resumed . “ Begad , [I]122-henchard nearly forgot [myself]122-henchard just now ! What [I]122-henchard meant was that [the girl]311-the girl 's hair certainly looked as if it would be darker , when [she]191-henchard was [a baby]4937-a baby . ”[122-henchard] “ It did ; but [they]4940-they alter so , ”[122-henchard] replied [Susan]122-henchard . “ [Their]4940-they hair gets darker , [I]380-his wife know — but [I]380-his wife was n't aware it lightened ever ? ”[380-his wife] “ O yes . ”[122-henchard] And the same uneasy expression came out on [her]380-his wife face , to which the future held the key . [It]1571-it passed as [Henchard]122-henchard went on : “ Well , so much the better . Now [Susan]122-henchard , [I]128-henchard want to have [her]311-the girl called [Miss Henchard]166-miss henchard — not [Miss Newson]167-miss newson . [Lots o ' [people]1161-people]4941-lots o ' people do it already in carelessness — it is [her]311-the girl legal name — so it may as well be made [her]311-the girl usual name — [I]128-henchard do n't like t'other name at all for [my]128-henchard own flesh and blood . [I]128-henchard 'll advertise it in the Casterbridge paper — that 's the way [they]1161-people do it . [She]311-the girl wo n't object . ”[128-henchard] “ No . O no . But — ”[122-henchard] “ Well , then , [I]122-henchard shall do it , ”[122-henchard] [he]122-henchard said , peremptorily . “ Surely , if [she]311-the girl 's willing , [you]1572-she must wish it as much as [I]1572-she ? ”[1572-she] “ O yes — if [she]311-the girl agrees let [us]4943-us do it by all means , ”[191-henchard] [she]1572-she replied . Then [Mrs. Henchard]128-henchard acted somewhat inconsistently ; it might have been called falsely , but that [her]128-henchard manner was emotional and full of the earnestness of [one who wishes to do right at great hazard]1573-one who wishes to do right at great hazard . [She]128-henchard went to [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard , whom [she]128-henchard found sewing in [[her]191-henchard own sitting - room [upstairs]1000-upstairs]1574-her own sitting - room upstairs , and told [her]191-henchard what had been proposed about [her]191-henchard surname . “ Can [you]191-henchard agree — is it not a slight upon [Newson]191-henchard — now [he]4944-he 's dead and gone ? ”[191-henchard] [Elizabeth]191-henchard reflected . “ [I]1572-she 'll think of it , [mother]4495-mother , ”[1572-she] [she]191-henchard answered . When , later in the day , [she]1572-she saw [Henchard]128-henchard , [she]1572-she adverted to the matter at once , in a way which showed that the line of feeling started by [[her]1572-she mother]588-her mother had been persevered in . “ Do [you]128-henchard wish this change so very much , [sir]4588-sir ? ”[1572-she] [she]1572-she asked . “ Wish it ? Why , [[my]191-henchard blessed fathers]4947-my blessed fathers , what an ado [you]128-henchard [women]4948-women make about a trifle ! [I]191-henchard proposed it — that 's all . Now , ' [Lizabeth - Jane]168-lizabeth - jane , just please [yourself]168-lizabeth - jane . Curse [me]191-henchard if [I]191-henchard care what [you]168-lizabeth - jane do . Now , [you]168-lizabeth - jane understand , do n't ' [ee]4949-ee go agreeing to it to please [me]191-henchard . ”[191-henchard] Here the subject dropped , and nothing more was said , and nothing was done , and [Elizabeth]191-henchard still passed as [Miss Newson]167-miss newson , and not by [her]191-henchard legal name . Meanwhile the great corn and hay traffic conducted by [Henchard]128-henchard throve under the management of [Donald Farfrae]139-farfrae as it had never thriven before . [It]1577-it had formerly moved in jolts ; now it went on oiled casters . The old crude viva voce system of [Henchard]120-henchard , in which everything depended upon [his]120-henchard memory , and bargains were made by the tongue alone , was swept away . Letters and ledgers took the place of “ [I]191-henchard 'll do't , ”[191-henchard] and “ [you]4950-you shall hae't ”[120-henchard] ; and , as in all such cases of advance , the rugged picturesqueness of the old method disappeared with its inconveniences . The position of [[Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard 's room]1578-elizabeth - jane 's room — rather high in [the house]782-the house , so that [it]1578-elizabeth - jane 's room commanded a view of [the hay - stores and granaries]1580-the hay - stores and granaries across [the garden]1272-the garden — afforded [her]191-henchard opportunity for accurate observation of what went on [there]447-there . [She]191-henchard saw that [Donald]139-farfrae and [Mr. Henchard]120-henchard were inseparables . When walking together [Henchard]120-henchard would lay [his]120-henchard arm familiarly on [[his]120-henchard manager]1583-his manager 's shoulder , as if [Farfrae]139-farfrae were [a younger brother]1584-a younger brother , bearing so heavily that [his]120-henchard slight frame bent under the weight . Occasionally [she]191-henchard would hear a perfect cannonade of laughter from [Henchard]120-henchard , arising from something [Donald]139-farfrae had said , [the latter]4511-the latter looking quite innocent and not laughing at all . In [Henchard]120-henchard 's somewhat lonely life [he]120-henchard evidently found [the young man]371-the young man as desirable for comradeship as [he]120-henchard was useful for consultations . [Donald]139-farfrae 's brightness of intellect maintained in the corn - factor the admiration it had won at the first hour of [their]1587-their meeting . The poor opinion , and but ill - concealed , that [he]120-henchard entertained of the slim [Farfrae]139-farfrae 's physical girth , strength , and dash was more than counterbalanced by the immense respect [he]120-henchard had for [his]120-henchard brains . [Her]191-henchard quiet eye discerned that [Henchard]120-henchard 's tigerish affection for [the younger man]1588-the younger man , [his]120-henchard constant liking to have [Farfrae]139-farfrae near [him]120-henchard , now and then resulted in a tendency to domineer , which , however , was checked in a moment when [Donald]139-farfrae exhibited marks of real offence . One day , looking down on [their]1587-their figures from on high , [she]191-henchard heard [the latter]4511-the latter remark , as [they]1587-their stood in the doorway between [the garden]1272-the garden and [yard]1591-yard , that [their]1587-their habit of walking and driving about together rather neutralized [Farfrae]139-farfrae 's value as a second pair of eyes , which should be used in places where [the principal]1592-the principal was not . “ ' Od damn it , ”[120-henchard] cried [Henchard]120-henchard , “ what 's all [the world]4424-the world ! [I]120-henchard like [a fellow]4427-a fellow to talk to . Now come along and [hae]4953-hae some supper , and do n't take too much thought about things , or ye'll drive [me]120-henchard crazy . ”[120-henchard] When [she]191-henchard walked with [[her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother , on the other hand , [she]191-henchard often beheld [the Scotchman]886-the scotchman looking at [them]1587-their with a curious interest . The fact that [he]886-the scotchman had met [her]191-henchard at [the Three Mariners]4601-the three mariners was insufficient to account for it , since on the occasions on which [she]191-henchard had entered [[his]886-the scotchman room]1135-his room [he]886-the scotchman had never raised [his]886-the scotchman eyes . Besides , it was at [[her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother more particularly than at [herself]191-henchard that [he]886-the scotchman looked , to [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard 's half - conscious , simple - minded , perhaps pardonable , disappointment . Thus [she]191-henchard could not account for this interest by [her]191-henchard own attractiveness , and [she]191-henchard decided that it might be apparent only — a way of turning [his]886-the scotchman eyes that [Mr. Farfrae]149-farfrae had . [She]191-henchard did not divine the ample explanation of [his]886-the scotchman manner , without personal vanity , that was afforded by the fact of [Donald]139-farfrae being [the depositary of [Henchard]120-henchard 's confidence in respect of [his]886-the scotchman past treatment of [the pale , chastened mother who walked by [her]886-the scotchman side]1599-the pale , chastened mother who walked by her side]1598-the depositary of henchard 's confidence in respect of his past treatment of the pale , chastened mother who walked by her side . [Her]191-henchard conjectures on that past never went further than faint ones based on things casually heard and seen — mere guesses that [Henchard]120-henchard and [[her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother might have been lovers in [their]1601-their younger days , who had quarrelled and parted . [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge , as has been hinted , was a place deposited in [the block upon [a corn - field]1603-a corn - field]1602-the block upon a corn - field . There was no suburb in the modern sense , or [transitional intermixture of [town and down]1605-town and down]1604-transitional intermixture of town and down . [It]6-casterbridge stood , with regard to [the wide fertile land adjoining]1606-the wide fertile land adjoining , clean - cut and distinct , like a chess - board on a green tablecloth . [[The farmer]1607-the farmer 's boy]1608-the farmer 's boy could sit under [his]1608-the farmer 's boy barley - mow and pitch a stone into [the office - window of [the town - clerk]1610-the town - clerk]1609-the office - window of the town - clerk ; [reapers at work among the sheaves]1611-reapers at work among the sheaves nodded to [acquaintances standing on the pavement - corner]1612-acquaintances standing on the pavement - corner ; [the red - robed judge]1613-the red - robed judge , when [he]1613-the red - robed judge condemned [a sheep - stealer]1614-a sheep - stealer , pronounced sentence to the tune of Baa , that floated in at the window from the remainder of the flock browsing hard by ; and at executions [the waiting crowd]1615-the waiting crowd stood in [a meadow immediately before the drop]1616-a meadow immediately before the drop , out of which the cows had been temporarily driven to give [the spectators room]1617-the spectators room . The corn grown on [the upland side of [the borough]1619-the borough]1618-the upland side of the borough was garnered by [[farmers]712-farmers who lived in [an eastern purlieu called [Durnover]15-durnover]1622-an eastern purlieu called durnover]1621-farmers who lived in an eastern purlieu called durnover . Here wheat - ricks overhung [the old Roman street]1623-the old roman street , and thrust [their]1624-their eaves against the church tower ; [green - thatched barns , with doorways as high as the gates of [Solomon]131-longways 's temple]1625-green - thatched barns , with doorways as high as the gates of solomon 's temple , opened directly upon [the main thoroughfare]1626-the main thoroughfare . [Barns]1627-barns indeed were so numerous as to alternate with [every half - dozen houses along the way]1628-every half - dozen houses along the way . Here lived [burgesses who daily walked the fallow]1629-burgesses who daily walked the fallow ; [shepherds]1630-shepherds in an intra - mural squeeze . [A street of]1631-a street of [[farmers]712-farmers ' homesteads]1633-farmers ' homesteads — [a street ruled by [a mayor and corporation , yet echoing with the thump of the flail , the flutter of the winnowing - fan]1635-a mayor and corporation , yet echoing with the thump of the flail , the flutter of the winnowing - fan , and the purr of the milk into the pails]1634-a street ruled by a mayor and corporation , yet echoing with the thump of the flail , the flutter of the winnowing - fan , and the purr of the milk into the pails — [a street which had nothing urban in [it]1636-a street which had nothing urban in it whatever whatever]1636-a street which had nothing urban in it whatever — this was [the Durnover end of [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge]1637-the durnover end of casterbridge . [Henchard]120-henchard , as was natural , dealt largely with [this nursery]1638-this nursery or bed of [small farmers close at hand]1639-small farmers close at hand — and [his]120-henchard waggons were often down that way . One day , when arrangements were in progress for getting [home]675-home corn from [one of [the aforesaid farms]1642-the aforesaid farms]1641-one of the aforesaid farms , [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard received a note by hand , asking [her]191-henchard to oblige [the writer]1643-the writer by coming at once to [a granary on [Durnover Hill]44-durnover hill]1644-a granary on durnover hill . As this was [the granary whose contents [Henchard]120-henchard was removing]1645-the granary whose contents henchard was removing , [she]191-henchard thought the request had something to do with [his]120-henchard business , and proceeded thither as soon as [she]191-henchard had put on [her]191-henchard bonnet . [The granary]1646-the granary was just within [the farm - yard]1647-the farm - yard , and stood on stone staddles , high enough for [persons]1648-persons to walk under . The gates were open , but [nobody]298-nobody was within . However , [she]191-henchard entered and waited . Presently [she]191-henchard saw [a figure approaching the gate]1650-a figure approaching the gate — that of [Donald Farfrae]139-farfrae . [He]120-henchard looked up at the church clock , and came in . By some unaccountable shyness , some wish not to meet [him]120-henchard there alone , [she]191-henchard quickly ascended the step - ladder leading to the granary door , and entered [it]1646-the granary before [he]120-henchard had seen [her]191-henchard . [Farfrae]139-farfrae advanced , imagining [himself]139-farfrae in solitude , and a few drops of rain beginning to fall [he]120-henchard moved and stood under the shelter where [she]191-henchard had just been standing . Here [he]120-henchard leant against one of the staddles , and gave [himself]120-henchard up to patience . [He]120-henchard , too , was plainly expecting [some one]1651-some one ; could it be [herself]191-henchard ? If so , why ? In a few minutes [he]120-henchard looked at [his]120-henchard watch , and then pulled out a note , a duplicate of the one [she]191-henchard had [herself]191-henchard received . This situation began to be very awkward , and the longer [she]191-henchard waited the more awkward it became . To emerge from a door just above [his]120-henchard head and descend the ladder , and show [she]191-henchard had been in hiding there , would look so very foolish that [she]191-henchard still waited on . [A winnowing machine]1652-a winnowing machine stood close beside [her]191-henchard , and to relieve [her]191-henchard suspense [she]191-henchard gently moved the handle ; whereupon a cloud of wheat husks flew out into [her]191-henchard face , and covered [her]191-henchard clothes and bonnet , and stuck into the fur of [her]191-henchard victorine . [He]120-henchard must have heard the slight movement for [he]120-henchard looked up , and then ascended the steps . “ Ah — it 's [Miss Newson]167-miss newson , ”[120-henchard] [he]120-henchard said as soon as [he]120-henchard could see into [the granary]1646-the granary . “ [I]191-henchard did n't know [you]191-henchard were [there]447-there . [I]191-henchard have kept the appointment , and am at [your]191-henchard service . ”[191-henchard] “ [O Mr. Farfrae]149-farfrae , ”[191-henchard] [she]191-henchard faltered , “ so have [I.]191-henchard But [I]120-henchard did n't know it was [you]120-henchard who wished to see [me]120-henchard , otherwise [I]120-henchard — ”[120-henchard] “ [I]191-henchard wished to see [you]120-henchard ? O no — at least , that is , [I]191-henchard am afraid there may be a mistake . ”[191-henchard] “ Did n't [you]120-henchard ask [me]1654-me to come here ? Did n't [you]120-henchard write this ? ”[1654-me] [Elizabeth]191-henchard held out [her]191-henchard note . “ No . Indeed , at no hand would [I]1654-me have thought of it ! And for [you]120-henchard — did n't [you]120-henchard ask [me]1654-me ? This is not [your]120-henchard writing ? ”[1654-me] And [he]1654-me held up [his]1654-me . “ By no means . ”[1655-they] “ And is that really so ! Then it 's [somebody]4446-somebody wanting to see [us]1655-they both . Perhaps [we]1655-they would do well to wait a little longer . ”[149-farfrae] Acting on this consideration [they]1655-they lingered , [Elizabeth]191-henchard - [Jane]191-henchard 's face being arranged to an expression of preternatural composure , and [the young Scot]1656-the young scot , at every footstep in [the street]797-the street without , looking from under [the granary]1646-the granary to see if [the passer]1659-the passer were about to enter and declare [himself]1659-the passer [[their]1655-they summoner]1660-their summoner . [They]1655-they watched individual drops of rain creeping down the thatch of [the opposite rick]1661-the opposite rick — straw after straw — till [they]1655-they reached the bottom ; but [nobody]298-nobody came , and the granary roof began to drip . “ [The person]1251-the person is not likely to be coming , ”[149-farfrae] said [Farfrae]149-farfrae . “ It 's a trick perhaps , and if so , it 's a great pity to waste [our]1655-they time like this , and so much to be done . ”[191-henchard] “ ' Tis a great liberty , ”[191-henchard] said [Elizabeth]191-henchard . “ It 's true , [Miss Newson]167-miss newson . [We]1655-they 'll hear news of this some day depend on't , and who it was that did it . [I]191-henchard would n't stand for it hindering [myself]191-henchard ; but [you]167-miss newson , [Miss Newson]167-miss newson — — ”[191-henchard] “ [I]191-henchard do n't mind — much , ”[191-henchard] [she]191-henchard replied . “ Neither do [I.]191-henchard ”[191-henchard] [They]1655-they lapsed again into silence . “ [You]167-miss newson are anxious to get back to [Scotland]21-scotland , [I]191-henchard suppose , [Mr. Farfrae]149-farfrae ? ”[191-henchard] [she]191-henchard inquired . “ O no , [Miss Newson]167-miss newson . Why would [I]191-henchard be ? ”[191-henchard] “ [I]139-farfrae only supposed [you]167-miss newson might be from the song [you]167-miss newson sang at [the Three Mariners]4601-the three mariners — about [Scotland]21-scotland and [home]675-home , [I]139-farfrae mean — which [you]167-miss newson seemed to feel so deep down in [your]167-miss newson heart ; so that [we]1655-they all felt for [you]167-miss newson . ”[139-farfrae] “ Ay — and [I]139-farfrae did sing there — [I]139-farfrae did — — But , [Miss Newson]167-miss newson ”[139-farfrae] — and [Donald]139-farfrae 's voice musically undulated between two semi - tones as it always did when [he]1663-he became earnest — “ it 's well [you]167-miss newson feel a song for a few minutes , and [your]167-miss newson eyes they get quite tearful ; but [you]167-miss newson finish it , and for all [you]167-miss newson felt [you]167-miss newson do n't mind it or think of it again for a long while . O no , [I]191-henchard do n't want to go back ! Yet [I]191-henchard 'll sing the song to [you]167-miss newson wi ' pleasure whenever [you]167-miss newson like . [I]191-henchard could sing it now , and not mind at all ? ”[191-henchard] “ Thank [you]139-farfrae , indeed . But [I]1664-he fear [I]1664-he must go — rain or no . ”[1664-he] “ Ay ! Then , [Miss Newson]167-miss newson , [ye]167-miss newson had better say nothing about this hoax , and take no heed of it . And if [the person]1251-the person should say anything to [you]167-miss newson , be civil to [him]4960-him or [her]4961-her , as if [you]167-miss newson did not mind it — so [you]167-miss newson 'll take [the clever person]4962-the clever person 's laugh away . ”[1664-he] In speaking [his]1664-he eyes became fixed upon [her]1665-her dress , still sown with wheat husks . “ There 's husks and dust on [you]1665-her . Perhaps [you]1665-her do n't know it ? ”[1664-he] [he]1664-he said , in tones of extreme delicacy . “ And it 's very bad to let rain come upon clothes when there 's chaff on them . It washes in and spoils them . Let [me]191-henchard help [you]1665-her — blowing is the best . ”[191-henchard] As [Elizabeth]191-henchard neither assented nor dissented [Donald Farfrae]139-farfrae began blowing [her]1665-her back hair , and [her]1665-her side hair , and [her]1665-her neck , and the crown of [her]1665-her bonnet , and the fur of [her]1665-her victorine , [Elizabeth]191-henchard saying , “ O , thank [you]1664-he , ”[1664-he] at every puff . At last [she]1665-her was fairly clean , though [Farfrae]139-farfrae , having got over [his]1664-he first concern at the situation , seemed in no manner of hurry to be gone . “ Ah — now [I]139-farfrae 'll go and get [ye]1665-her an umbrella , ”[139-farfrae] [he]1664-he said . [She]1665-her declined the offer , stepped out and was gone . [Farfrae]139-farfrae walked slowly after , looking thoughtfully at [her]1665-her diminishing figure , and whistling in undertones , “ As [I]169-the prophet baruch came down through [Cannobie]45-cannobie . ”[169-the prophet baruch]

At first [Miss Newson]167-miss newson 's budding beauty was not regarded with much interest by [anybody in [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge]1666-anybody in casterbridge . [Donald Farfrae]139-farfrae 's gaze , it is true , was now attracted by [[the Mayor]4556-the mayor 's so - called step - daughter]1668-the mayor 's so - called step - daughter , but [he]1664-he was only one . The truth is that [she]1665-her was but a poor illustrative instance of [the prophet Baruch]169-the prophet baruch 's sly definition : “ [The virgin that loveth to go gay]4963-the virgin that loveth to go gay . ”[170-rochefoucauld] When [she]1665-her walked [abroad]1669-abroad [she]1665-her seemed to be occupied with an inner chamber of ideas , and to have slight need for visible objects . [She]1665-her formed curious resolves on checking gay fancies in the matter of clothes , because it was inconsistent with [her]1665-her past life to blossom gaudily the moment [she]1665-her had become possessed of money . But nothing is more insidious than the evolution of wishes from mere fancies , and of wants from mere wishes . [Henchard]120-henchard gave [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard a box of delicately - tinted gloves one spring day . [She]191-henchard wanted to wear them to show [her]191-henchard appreciation of [his]120-henchard kindness , but [she]191-henchard had no bonnet that would harmonize . As an artistic indulgence [she]191-henchard thought [she]191-henchard would have such a bonnet . When [she]191-henchard had a bonnet that would go with the gloves [she]191-henchard had no dress that would go with the bonnet . It was now absolutely necessary to finish ; [she]191-henchard ordered the requisite article , and found that [she]191-henchard had no sunshade to go with the dress . In for a penny in for a pound ; [she]191-henchard bought the sunshade , and the whole structure was at last complete . [Everybody]1670-everybody was attracted , and [some]895-some said that [her]1665-her bygone simplicity was the art that conceals art , the “ delicate imposition ”[1665-her] of [Rochefoucauld]170-rochefoucauld ; [she]1665-her had produced an effect , a contrast , and it had been done on purpose . As a matter of fact this was not true , but it had its result ; for as soon as [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge thought [her]1665-her artful it thought [her]1665-her worth notice . “ It is the first time in [my]1665-her life that [I]1665-her have been so much admired , ”[1665-her] [she]1665-her said to [herself]1665-her ; “ though perhaps it is by [those whose admiration is not worth having]4964-those whose admiration is not worth having . ”[1665-her] But [Donald Farfrae]139-farfrae admired [her]1665-her , too ; and altogether the time was an exciting one ; sex had never before asserted itself in [her]1665-her so strongly , for in former days [she]1665-her had perhaps been too impersonally human to be distinctively feminine . After an unprecedented success one day [she]1665-her came [indoors]4777-indoors , went [upstairs]1000-upstairs , and leant upon [her]1665-her bed face downwards quite forgetting the possible creasing and damage . “ Good Heaven , ”[1665-her] [she]1665-her whispered , “ can it be ? Here am [I]1665-her setting up as [the town]632-the town beauty ! ”[1665-her] When [she]1665-her had thought it over , [her]1665-her usual fear of exaggerating appearances engendered a deep sadness . “ There is something wrong in all this , ”[1665-her] [she]1665-her mused . “ If [they]4966-they only knew what [an unfinished girl]4967-an unfinished girl [I]120-henchard am — that [I]120-henchard ca n't talk Italian , or use globes , or show any of the accomplishments [they]4966-they learn at [boarding schools]4968-boarding schools , how [they]4966-they would despise [me]120-henchard ! Better sell all this finery and buy [myself]120-henchard grammar - books and dictionaries and a history of all the philosophies ! ”[120-henchard] [She]1665-her looked from the window and saw [Henchard]120-henchard and [Farfrae]139-farfrae in [the hay - yard]1674-the hay - yard talking , with that impetuous cordiality on [the Mayor]4556-the mayor 's part , and genial modesty on [the younger man]1588-the younger man 's , that was now so generally observable in [their]1677-their intercourse . Friendship between [man]488-man and [man]488-man ; what a rugged strength there was in it , as evinced by [these two]1680-these two . And yet the seed that was to lift the foundation of this friendship was at that moment taking root in a chink of its structure . It was about six o'clock ; [the men]1681-the men were dropping off homeward one by one . [The last to leave]1682-the last to leave was [a round - shouldered , blinking young man of nineteen or twenty , whose mouth fell ajar on the slightest provocation , seemingly because there was no chin to support it]1683-a round - shouldered , blinking young man of nineteen or twenty , whose mouth fell ajar on the slightest provocation , seemingly because there was no chin to support it . [Henchard]120-henchard called aloud to [him]1683-a round - shouldered , blinking young man of nineteen or twenty , whose mouth fell ajar on the slightest provocation , seemingly because there was no chin to support it as [he]120-henchard went out of the gate , “ Here — [Abel Whittle]171-whittle ! ”[120-henchard] [Whittle]171-whittle turned , and ran back a few steps . “ Yes , [sir]4588-sir , ”[120-henchard] [he]120-henchard said , in breathless deprecation , as if [he]120-henchard knew what was coming next . “ Once more — be in time to - morrow morning . [You]4588-sir see what 's to be done , and [you]4588-sir hear what [I]171-whittle say , and [you]4588-sir know [I]171-whittle 'm not going to be trifled with any longer . ”[171-whittle] “ Yes , [sir]4588-sir . ”[171-whittle] Then [Abel Whittle]171-whittle left , and [Henchard]120-henchard and [Farfrae]139-farfrae ; and [Elizabeth]191-henchard saw no more of [them]1684-them . Now there was good reason for this command on [Henchard]120-henchard 's part . [Poor Abel]171-whittle , as [he]171-whittle was called , had an inveterate habit of over - sleeping [himself]171-whittle and coming late to [his]171-whittle work . [His]171-whittle anxious will was to be among the earliest ; but if [[his]171-whittle comrades]1685-his comrades omitted to pull the string that [he]171-whittle always tied round [his]171-whittle great toe and left hanging out the window for that purpose , [his]171-whittle will was as wind . [He]171-whittle did not arrive in time . As [he]171-whittle was often second hand at the hay - weighing , or at the crane which lifted the sacks , or was one of [those who had to accompany the waggons into [the country]633-the country]1686-those who had to accompany the waggons into the country to fetch away stacks that had been purchased , this affliction of [Abel]171-whittle 's was productive of much inconvenience . For two mornings in the present week [he]171-whittle had kept [the others]854-the others waiting nearly an hour ; hence [Henchard]120-henchard 's threat . It now remained to be seen what would happen to - morrow . Six o'clock struck , and there was no [Whittle]171-whittle . At half - past six [Henchard]120-henchard entered [the yard]1277-the yard ; [the waggon]1690-the waggon was horsed that [Abel]171-whittle was to accompany ; and [the other man]1691-the other man had been waiting twenty minutes . Then [Henchard]120-henchard swore , and [Whittle]171-whittle coming up breathless at that instant , [the corn - factor]4538-the corn - factor turned on [him]171-whittle , and declared with an oath that this was the last time ; that if [he]171-whittle were behind once more , by [God]126-god , [he]171-whittle would come and drag [him]171-whittle out o ' bed . “ There is sommit wrong in [my]171-whittle make , [[your]120-henchard worshipful]4971-your worshipful ! ”[171-whittle] said [Abel]171-whittle , “ especially in the inside , whereas [my]120-henchard poor dumb brain gets as dead as a clot afore [I]120-henchard 've said [my]120-henchard few scrags of prayers . Yes — it came on as [a stripling]4972-a stripling , just afore [I]120-henchard 'd got [man]488-man 's wages , whereas [I]120-henchard never enjoy [my]120-henchard bed at all , for no sooner do [I]120-henchard lie down than [I]120-henchard be asleep , and afore [I]120-henchard be awake [I]120-henchard be up . [I]120-henchard 've fretted [my]120-henchard gizzard green about it , [maister]4974-maister , but what can [I]120-henchard do ? Now last night , afore [I]120-henchard went to bed , [I]120-henchard only had a scantling o ' cheese and — ”[120-henchard] “ [I]120-henchard do n't want to hear it ! ”[120-henchard] roared [Henchard]120-henchard . “ To - morrow the waggons must start at four , and if [you]120-henchard 're not [here]4417-here , stand clear . [I]120-henchard 'll mortify [thy]120-henchard flesh for [thee]120-henchard ! ”[120-henchard] “ But let [me]171-whittle clear up [my]171-whittle points , [[your]120-henchard worshipful]4971-your worshipful — — ”[171-whittle] [Henchard]120-henchard turned away . “ [He]120-henchard asked [me]171-whittle and [he]120-henchard questioned [me]171-whittle , and then ' a would n't hear [my]171-whittle points ! ”[171-whittle] said [Abel]171-whittle , to [the yard]1277-the yard in general . “ Now , [I]120-henchard shall twitch like a moment - hand all night to - night for fear o ' [him]171-whittle ! ”[120-henchard] The journey to be taken by [the waggons]1694-the waggons next day was a long one into [Blackmoor Vale]46-blackmoor vale , and at four o'clock lanterns were moving about [the yard]1277-the yard . But [Abel]171-whittle was missing . Before [either of [the other men]1697-the other men]1696-either of the other men could run to [Abel]171-whittle 's and warn [him]171-whittle [Henchard]120-henchard appeared in the garden doorway . “ Where 's [Abel Whittle]171-whittle ? Not come after all [I]171-whittle 've said ? Now [I]171-whittle 'll carry out [my]171-whittle word , by [[my]171-whittle blessed fathers]4947-my blessed fathers — nothing else will do [him]171-whittle any good ! [I]171-whittle 'm going up that way . ”[171-whittle] [Henchard]120-henchard went off , entered [[Abel]171-whittle 's house]1698-abel 's house , [a little cottage in [Back Street]47-back street]1699-a little cottage in back street , the door of which was never locked because [the inmates]1700-the inmates had nothing to lose . Reaching [Whittle]171-whittle 's bedside [the corn - factor]4538-the corn - factor shouted a bass note so vigorously that [Abel]171-whittle started up instantly , and beholding [Henchard]120-henchard standing over [him]171-whittle , was galvanized into spasmodic movements which had not much relation to getting on [his]171-whittle clothes . “ Out of bed , [sir]4588-sir , and off to [the granary]1646-the granary , or [you]4588-sir leave [my]139-farfrae employ to - day ! ' Tis to teach [ye]4588-sir a lesson . March on ; never mind [your]4588-sir breeches ! ”[139-farfrae] [The unhappy Whittle]171-whittle threw on [his]171-whittle sleeve waistcoat , and managed to get into [his]171-whittle boots at the bottom of the stairs , while [Henchard]120-henchard thrust [his]120-henchard hat over [his]120-henchard head . [Whittle]171-whittle then trotted on down [Back Street]47-back street , [Henchard]120-henchard walking sternly behind . Just at this time [Farfrae]139-farfrae , who had been to [[Henchard]120-henchard 's house]1270-henchard 's house to look for [him]171-whittle , came out of the back gate , and saw something white fluttering in the morning gloom , which [he]171-whittle soon perceived to be part of [Abel]171-whittle 's shirt that showed below [his]171-whittle waistcoat . “ For maircy 's sake , what object 's this ? ”[171-whittle] said [Farfrae]139-farfrae , following [Abel]171-whittle into [the yard]1277-the yard , [Henchard]120-henchard being some way in the rear by this time . “ [Ye]139-farfrae see , [Mr. Farfrae]149-farfrae , ”[171-whittle] gibbered [Abel]171-whittle with a resigned smile of terror , “ [he]171-whittle said [he]171-whittle 'd mortify [my]120-henchard flesh if so be [I]120-henchard did n't get up sooner , and now [he]171-whittle 's a - doing on't ! [Ye]139-farfrae see it ca n't be helped , [Mr. Farfrae]149-farfrae ; things do happen queer sometimes ! Yes — [I]120-henchard 'll go to [Blackmoor]48-blackmoor Vale half naked as [I]120-henchard be , since [he]171-whittle do command ; but [I]120-henchard shall kill [myself]120-henchard afterwards ; [I]120-henchard ca n't outlive the disgrace , for [the women - folk]4980-the women - folk will be looking out of [their]4980-the women - folk winders at [my]120-henchard mortification all the way along , and laughing [me]120-henchard to scorn as [a man]4474-a man ' ithout breeches ! [You]139-farfrae know how [I]120-henchard feel such things , [Maister Farfrae]172-maister farfrae , and how forlorn thoughts get hold upon [me]120-henchard . Yes — [I]120-henchard shall do [myself]120-henchard harm — [I]120-henchard feel it coming on ! ”[120-henchard] “ Get back [home]675-home , and slip on [your]139-farfrae breeches , and come to wark like [a man]4474-a man ! If [ye]139-farfrae go not , [you]139-farfrae 'll ha'e [your]139-farfrae death standing there ! ”[120-henchard] “ [I]171-whittle 'm afeard [I]171-whittle must n't ! [Mr. Henchard]120-henchard said — — ”[171-whittle] “ [I]120-henchard do n't care what [Mr. Henchard]120-henchard said , nor [anybody else]4984-anybody else ! ' Tis simple foolishness to do this . Go and dress [yourself]139-farfrae instantly [Whittle]171-whittle . ”[120-henchard] “ Hullo , hullo ! ”[120-henchard] said [Henchard]120-henchard , coming up behind . “ Who 's sending [him]172-maister farfrae back ? ”[139-farfrae] [All the men]1704-all the men looked towards [Farfrae]172-maister farfrae . “ [I]139-farfrae am , ”[139-farfrae] said [Donald]139-farfrae . “ [I]139-farfrae say this joke has been carried far enough . ”[139-farfrae] “ And [I]139-farfrae say it has n't ! Get up in the waggon , Whittle . ”[139-farfrae] “ Not if [I]139-farfrae am [manager]4985-manager , ”[139-farfrae] said [Farfrae]139-farfrae . “ [He]172-maister farfrae either goes [home]675-home , or [I]139-farfrae march out of [this yard]4987-this yard for good . ”[139-farfrae] [Henchard]120-henchard looked at [him]172-maister farfrae with a face stern and red . But [he]120-henchard paused for a moment , and [their]1705-their eyes met . [Donald]139-farfrae went up to [him]120-henchard , for [he]120-henchard saw in [Henchard]120-henchard 's look that [he]120-henchard began to regret this . “ Come , ”[139-farfrae] said [Donald]139-farfrae quietly , “ [a man o ' [your]120-henchard position]4988-a man o ' your position should ken better , [sir]4588-sir ! It is tyrannical and no worthy of [you]120-henchard . ”[120-henchard] “ ' Tis not tyrannical ! ”[120-henchard] murmured [Henchard]120-henchard , like [a sullen boy]1706-a sullen boy . “ It is to make [him]120-henchard remember ! ”[120-henchard] [He]120-henchard presently added , in a tone of one bitterly hurt : “ Why did [you]139-farfrae speak to [me]139-farfrae before [them]4990-them like that , [Farfrae]139-farfrae ? [You]139-farfrae might have stopped till [we]4991-we were alone . Ah — [I]139-farfrae know why ! [I]139-farfrae 've told [ye]139-farfrae the secret o ' [my]139-farfrae life — fool that [I]139-farfrae was to do't — and [you]139-farfrae take advantage of [me]139-farfrae ! ”[139-farfrae] “ [I]1709-one of the men had forgot it , ”[1709-one of the men] said [Farfrae]139-farfrae simply . [Henchard]120-henchard looked on the ground , said nothing more , and turned away . During the day [Farfrae]139-farfrae learnt from [the men]1681-the men that [Henchard]120-henchard had kept [[Abel]171-whittle 's old mother]1708-abel 's old mother in coals and snuff all the previous winter , which made [him]120-henchard less antagonistic to the corn - factor . But [Henchard]120-henchard continued moody and silent , and when [one of [the men]1681-the men]1709-one of the men inquired of [him]120-henchard if some oats should be hoisted to an upper floor or not , [he]1709-one of the men said shortly , “ Ask [Mr. Farfrae]149-farfrae . [He]120-henchard 's master [here]4417-here ! ”[1716-the messenger] Morally [he]120-henchard was ; there could be no doubt of it . [Henchard]120-henchard , who had hitherto been [the most admired man in [[his]120-henchard circle]1712-his circle]1711-the most admired man in his circle , was the most admired no longer . One day [the daughters of [a deceased farmer in [Durnover]15-durnover]1714-a deceased farmer in durnover]1713-the daughters of a deceased farmer in durnover wanted an opinion of the value of [their]1713-the daughters of a deceased farmer in durnover haystack , and sent [a messenger]1715-a messenger to ask [Mr. Farfrae]149-farfrae to oblige [them]1713-the daughters of a deceased farmer in durnover with one . [The messenger]1716-the messenger , who was [a child]288-a child , met in [the yard]1277-the yard not [Farfrae]149-farfrae , but [Henchard]120-henchard . “ Very well , ”[1716-the messenger] [he]1716-the messenger said . “ [I]306-the child 'll come . ”[306-the child] “ But please will [Mr. Farfrae]149-farfrae come ? ”[120-henchard] said [the child]306-the child . “ [I]120-henchard am going that way .... Why [Mr. Farfrae]149-farfrae ? ”[120-henchard] said [Henchard]120-henchard , with the fixed look of thought . “ Why do [people]1161-people always want [Mr. Farfrae]149-farfrae ? ”[1716-the messenger] “ [I]1716-the messenger suppose because [they]1161-people like [him]149-farfrae so — that 's what [they]1161-people say . ”[1716-the messenger] “ Oh — [I]120-henchard see — that 's what [they]1161-people say — hey ? [They]1161-people like [him]149-farfrae because [he]149-farfrae 's cleverer than [Mr. Henchard]120-henchard , and because [he]149-farfrae knows more ; and , in short , [Mr. Henchard]120-henchard ca n't hold a candle to [him]149-farfrae — hey ? ”[120-henchard] “ Yes — that 's just it , [sir]4588-sir — some of it . ”[1716-the messenger] “ Oh , there 's more ? And when [some of [the women]4997-the women]4996-some of the women were a - walking [home]675-home [they]4996-some of the women said , ' [He]149-farfrae 's [a diment]4999-a diment — [he]149-farfrae 's a chap o ' wax — [he]149-farfrae 's the best — [he]149-farfrae 's the horse for [my]120-henchard money , ' says [they]4996-some of the women . And [I]120-henchard am coming to value the hay , d'ye hear ? — [I.]120-henchard ”[120-henchard] [The boy]1720-the boy departed , and [Henchard]120-henchard murmured , “ Wish [he]120-henchard were [master]5003-master here , do [they]4996-some of the women ? ”[139-farfrae] [He]120-henchard went towards [Durnover]15-durnover . On [his]120-henchard way [he]120-henchard overtook [Farfrae]149-farfrae . [They]1721-they walked on together , [Henchard]120-henchard looking mostly on the ground . “ [You]139-farfrae 're no yoursel ' the day ? ”[120-henchard] [Donald]139-farfrae inquired . “ Yes , [I]120-henchard am very well , ”[120-henchard] said [Henchard]120-henchard . “ But [ye]139-farfrae are a bit down — surely [ye]139-farfrae are down ? Why , there 's nothing to be angry about ! ' Tis splendid stuff that [we]1721-they 've got from [Blackmoor Vale]46-blackmoor vale . By the by , [the people in [Durnover]15-durnover]5004-the people in durnover want [their]5004-the people in durnover hay valued . ”[120-henchard] “ Yes . [I]120-henchard am going [there]447-there . ”[120-henchard] “ [I]1723-i 'll go with [ye]120-henchard . ”[1723-i] As [Henchard]120-henchard did not reply [Donald]139-farfrae practised a piece of music sotto voce , till , getting near [the bereaved people]1722-the bereaved people 's door , [he]1723-i stopped [himself]1723-i with — “ Ah , as [[their]1722-the bereaved people father]5006-their father is dead [I]120-henchard wo n't go on with such as that . How could [I]120-henchard forget ? ”[120-henchard] “ Do [you]139-farfrae care so very much about hurting [folks]4660-folks ' feelings ? ”[120-henchard] observed [Henchard]120-henchard with a half sneer . “ [You]139-farfrae do , [I]139-farfrae know — especially [mine]139-farfrae ! ”[139-farfrae] “ [I]1723-i am sorry if [I]1723-i have hurt [yours]1288-the corn - merchant , [sir]4588-sir , ”[1723-i] replied [Donald]139-farfrae , standing still , with a second expression of the same sentiment in the regretfulness of [his]1723-i face . “ Why should [you]1288-the corn - merchant say it — think it ? ”[1288-the corn - merchant] The cloud lifted from [Henchard]120-henchard 's brow , and as [Donald]139-farfrae finished [the corn - merchant]1288-the corn - merchant turned to [him]1723-i , regarding [his]1723-i breast rather than [his]1723-i face . “ [I]1288-the corn - merchant have been hearing things that vexed [me]1288-the corn - merchant , ”[1288-the corn - merchant] [he]1288-the corn - merchant said . “ ' Twas that made [me]4538-the corn - factor short in [my]4538-the corn - factor manner — made [me]4538-the corn - factor overlook what [you]139-farfrae really are . Now , [I]4538-the corn - factor do n't want to go in here about this hay — [Farfrae]139-farfrae , [you]139-farfrae can do it better than [I.]4538-the corn - factor [They]5009-they sent for ' ee , too . [I]4538-the corn - factor have to attend a meeting of [the Town Council]4580-the town council at eleven , and ' tis drawing on for't . ”[4538-the corn - factor] [They]1725-they parted thus in renewed friendship , [Donald]139-farfrae forbearing to ask [Henchard]120-henchard for meanings that were not very plain to [him]1723-i . On [Henchard]120-henchard 's part there was now again repose ; and yet , whenever [he]1288-the corn - merchant thought of [Farfrae]139-farfrae , it was with a dim dread ; and [he]1288-the corn - merchant often regretted that [he]1288-the corn - merchant had told [the young man]371-the young man [his]1288-the corn - merchant whole heart , and confided to [him]371-the young man the secrets of [his]1288-the corn - merchant life .

On this account [Henchard]120-henchard 's manner towards [Farfrae]139-farfrae insensibly became more reserved . [He]120-henchard was courteous — too courteous — and [Farfrae]139-farfrae was quite surprised at the good breeding which now for the first time showed itself among the qualities of [a man [he]120-henchard had hitherto thought undisciplined]1727-a man he had hitherto thought undisciplined , if warm and sincere . [The corn - factor]4538-the corn - factor seldom or never again put [his]4538-the corn - factor arm upon [the young man]371-the young man 's shoulder so as to nearly weigh [him]371-the young man down with the pressure of mechanized friendship . [He]4538-the corn - factor left off coming to [[Donald]139-farfrae 's lodgings]1730-donald 's lodgings and shouting into [the passage]1731-the passage . “ Hoy , [Farfrae]139-farfrae , [boy]5011-boy , come and have some dinner with [us]1732-their ! Do n't sit [here]4417-here in solitary confinement ! ”[120-henchard] But in the daily routine of [their]1732-their business there was little change . Thus [their]1732-their lives rolled on till a day of public rejoicing was suggested to [the country]633-the country at large in celebration of a national event that had recently taken place . For some time [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge , by nature slow , made no response . Then one day [Donald Farfrae]139-farfrae broached the subject to [Henchard]120-henchard by asking if [he]120-henchard would have any objection to lend some rick - cloths to [himself]139-farfrae and [a few others , who contemplated getting up an entertainment of some sort on the day named]1734-a few others , who contemplated getting up an entertainment of some sort on the day named , and required a shelter for the same , to which [they]1732-their might charge admission at the rate of so much a head . “ Have as many cloths as [you]120-henchard like , ”[120-henchard] [Henchard]120-henchard replied . When [[his]120-henchard manager]1583-his manager had gone about the business [Henchard]120-henchard was fired with emulation . It certainly had been very remiss of [him]120-henchard , as [Mayor]133-mr. mayor , [he]120-henchard thought , to call no meeting ere this , to discuss what should be done on this holiday . But [Farfrae]139-farfrae had been so cursed quick in [his]120-henchard movements as to give [old - fashioned people in authority]1736-old - fashioned people in authority no chance of the initiative . However , it was not too late ; and on second thoughts [he]120-henchard determined to take upon [his]120-henchard own shoulders the responsibility of organizing some amusements , if [the other Councilmen]1737-the other councilmen would leave the matter in [his]120-henchard hands . To this [they]1737-the other councilmen quite readily agreed , the majority being [fine old crusted characters who had a decided taste for living without worry]1738-fine old crusted characters who had a decided taste for living without worry . So [Henchard]120-henchard set about [his]120-henchard preparations for a really brilliant thing — such as should be worthy of [the venerable town]1739-the venerable town . As for [Farfrae]139-farfrae 's little affair , [Henchard]120-henchard nearly forgot it ; except once now and then when , on it coming into [his]120-henchard mind , [he]120-henchard said to [himself]120-henchard , “ Charge admission at so much a head — just like [a Scotchman]4611-a scotchman ! — who is going to pay anything a head ? ”[120-henchard] The diversions which [the Mayor]4556-the mayor intended to provide were to be entirely free . [He]120-henchard had grown so dependent upon [Donald]139-farfrae that [he]120-henchard could scarcely resist calling [him]120-henchard in to consult . But by sheer self - coercion [he]120-henchard refrained . No , [he]120-henchard thought , [Farfrae]139-farfrae would be suggesting such improvements in [his]120-henchard damned luminous way that in spite of [himself]120-henchard [he]120-henchard , [Henchard]120-henchard , would sink to the position of second fiddle , and only scrape harmonies to [[his]120-henchard manager]1583-his manager 's talents . [Everybody]1670-everybody applauded [the Mayor]4556-the mayor 's proposed entertainment , especially when it became known that [he]4556-the mayor meant to pay for it all [himself]4556-the mayor . Close to [the town]632-the town was an elevated green spot surrounded by an ancient square earthwork — [earthworks square]1745-earthworks square and not square , were as common as blackberries hereabout — [a spot whereon [the Casterbridge people]1747-the casterbridge people usually held any kind of merry - making , meeting , or sheep - fair that required more space than [the streets]1748-the streets would afford]1746-a spot whereon the casterbridge people usually held any kind of merry - making , meeting , or sheep - fair that required more space than the streets would afford . On one side [it]1749-it sloped to [the river Froom]1750-the river froom , and from any point a view was obtained of [the country round]4673-the country round for many miles . [This pleasant upland]1752-this pleasant upland was to be the scene of [Henchard]120-henchard 's exploit . [He]120-henchard advertised about [the town]632-the town , in long posters of a pink colour , that games of all sorts would take place [here]4417-here ; and set to work [a little battalion of [men]4432-men under [his]120-henchard own eye]1755-a little battalion of men under his own eye . [They]1755-a little battalion of men under his own eye erected greasy - poles for climbing , with smoked hams and local cheeses at the top . [They]1755-a little battalion of men under his own eye placed hurdles in rows for jumping over ; across [the river]1757-the river [they]1755-a little battalion of men under his own eye laid a slippery pole , with a live pig of [the neighbourhood]1758-the neighbourhood tied at the other end , to become the property of [the man who could walk over and get it]1759-the man who could walk over and get it . There were also provided wheelbarrows for racing , donkeys for the same , a stage for boxing , wrestling , and drawing blood generally ; sacks for jumping in . Moreover , not forgetting [his]120-henchard principles , [Henchard]120-henchard provided a mammoth tea , of which [everybody who lived in [the borough]1619-the borough]1760-everybody who lived in the borough was invited to partake without payment . The tables were laid parallel with the inner slope of the rampart , and awnings were stretched overhead . Passing to and fro [the Mayor]4556-the mayor beheld the unattractive exterior of [Farfrae]139-farfrae 's erection in [the West Walk]1763-the west walk , rick - cloths of different sizes and colours being hung up to the arching trees without any regard to appearance . [He]120-henchard was easy in [his]120-henchard mind now , for [his]120-henchard own preparations far transcended these . The morning came . The sky , which had been remarkably clear down to within a day or two , was overcast , and the weather threatening , the wind having an unmistakable hint of water in it . [Henchard]120-henchard wished [he]120-henchard had not been quite so sure about the continuance of a fair season . But it was too late to modify or postpone , and the proceedings went on . At twelve o'clock the rain began to fall , small and steady , commencing and increasing so insensibly that it was difficult to state exactly when dry weather ended or wet established itself . In an hour the slight moisture resolved itself into a monotonous smiting of earth by heaven , in torrents to which no end could be prognosticated . [A number of people]1764-a number of people had heroically gathered in [the field]4499-the field but by three o'clock [Henchard]120-henchard discerned that [his]120-henchard project was doomed to end in failure . The hams at the top of the poles dripped watered smoke in the form of a brown liquor , the pig shivered in the wind , the grain of the deal tables showed through the sticking tablecloths , for the awning allowed the rain to drift under at its will , and to enclose the sides at this hour seemed a useless undertaking . [The landscape]543-the landscape over [the river]1757-the river disappeared ; the wind played on the tent - cords in aeolian improvisations , and at length rose to such a pitch that the whole erection slanted to the ground [those who had taken shelter within [it]1769-it]1768-those who had taken shelter within it having to crawl out on [their]1768-those who had taken shelter within it hands and knees . But towards six the storm abated , and a drier breeze shook the moisture from the grass bents . It seemed possible to carry out the programme after all . The awning was set up again ; [the band]849-the band was called out from [its]849-the band shelter , and ordered to begin , and where the tables had stood a place was cleared for dancing . “ But where are [the folk]5014-the folk ? ”[120-henchard] said [Henchard]120-henchard , after the lapse of half - an - hour , during which time only [two men]736-two men and [a woman]647-a woman had stood up to dance . “ [The shops]5015-the shops are all shut . Why do n't [they]5014-the folk come ? ”[1773-a councilman who stood in the field with the mayor] “ [They]5014-the folk are at [Farfrae]139-farfrae 's affair in [the West Walk]50-the west walk , ”[1773-a councilman who stood in the field with the mayor] answered [a Councilman who stood in [the field]4499-the field with [the Mayor]4556-the mayor]1773-a councilman who stood in the field with the mayor . “ A few , [I]120-henchard suppose . But where are the body o 'em ? ”[120-henchard] “ All out of doors are there . ”[120-henchard] “ Then the more fools [they]5014-the folk ! ”[1127-one] [Henchard]120-henchard walked away moodily . [One or two young fellows]1776-one or two young fellows gallantly came to climb the poles , to save the hams from being wasted ; but as there were [no spectators]1777-no spectators , and the whole scene presented the most melancholy appearance [Henchard]120-henchard gave orders that the proceedings were to be suspended , and the entertainment closed , the food to be distributed among [the poor people of [the town]632-the town]1778-the poor people of the town . In a short time nothing was left in [the field]4499-the field but a few hurdles , the tents , and the poles . [Henchard]120-henchard returned to [[his]120-henchard house]1329-his house , had tea with [[his]120-henchard wife]380-his wife and [daughter]603-daughter , and then walked out . It was now dusk . [He]120-henchard soon saw that the tendency of [all promenaders]1784-all promenaders was towards a particular spot in [the Walks]1515-the walks , and eventually proceeded thither [himself]120-henchard . The notes of a stringed band came from [the enclosure that [Farfrae]139-farfrae had erected]1786-the enclosure that farfrae had erected — [the pavilion as [he]120-henchard called [it]1787-the pavilion as he called it]1787-the pavilion as he called it — and when [the Mayor]4556-the mayor reached [it]1787-the pavilion as he called it [he]4556-the mayor perceived that [a gigantic tent]1789-a gigantic tent had been ingeniously constructed without poles or ropes . [The densest point of [the avenue of sycamores]1791-the avenue of sycamores]1790-the densest point of the avenue of sycamores had been selected , where the boughs made a closely interlaced vault overhead ; to these boughs the canvas had been hung , and a barrel roof was the result . The end towards the wind was enclosed , the other end was open . [Henchard]120-henchard went round and saw the interior . In form it was like [the nave of [a cathedral]1793-a cathedral with one gable]1792-the nave of a cathedral with one gable removed , but the scene within was anything but devotional . A reel or fling of some sort was in progress ; and [the usually sedate Farfrae]1794-the usually sedate farfrae was in the midst of [the other dancers in the costume of [a wild Highlander]1796-a wild highlander]1795-the other dancers in the costume of a wild highlander , flinging [himself]120-henchard about and spinning to the tune . For a moment [Henchard]120-henchard could not help laughing . Then [he]120-henchard perceived the immense admiration for [the Scotchman that revealed itself in the women]1797-the scotchman that revealed itself in the women 's faces ; and when this exhibition was over , and a new dance proposed , and [Donald]139-farfrae had disappeared for a time to return in [his]120-henchard natural garments , [he]120-henchard had an unlimited choice of [partners]1798-partners , [every girl]1799-every girl being in a coming - on disposition towards one who so thoroughly understood the poetry of motion as [he]120-henchard . All [the town]632-the town crowded to the Walk , such a delightful idea of a ballroom never having occurred to [the inhabitants]780-the inhabitants before .
