Where was it ? ”[158-nance] “ At [the Three Mariners]4601-the three mariners ; one evening for a little while , when [we]5148-we were staying [there]447-there . ”[191-henchard] [Nance]158-nance glanced triumphantly at [Henchard]191-henchard , and sailed into [the barn]2072-the barn ; for assuming that [she]158-nance was to be discharged on the instant [she]158-nance had resolved to make the most of [her]158-nance victory . [Henchard]191-henchard , however , said nothing about discharging [her]191-henchard . Unduly sensitive on such points by reason of [his]120-henchard own past , [he]120-henchard had the look of one completely ground down to the last indignity . [Elizabeth]191-henchard followed [him]120-henchard to [the house]782-the house like [a culprit]2075-a culprit ; but when [she]191-henchard got inside [she]191-henchard could not see [him]120-henchard . Nor did [she]191-henchard see [him]120-henchard again that day . Convinced of the scathing damage to [his]120-henchard local repute and position that must have been caused by such a fact , though it had never before reached [his]120-henchard own ears , [Henchard]191-henchard showed a positive distaste for the presence of [this girl]4461-this girl not [his]120-henchard own , whenever [he]120-henchard encountered [her]191-henchard . [He]120-henchard mostly dined with [the farmers]2077-the farmers at [the market - room of one of [the two chief hotels]2079-the two chief hotels]2078-the market - room of one of the two chief hotels , leaving [her]191-henchard in utter solitude . Could [he]120-henchard have seen how [she]191-henchard made use of those silent hours [he]120-henchard might have found reason to reserve [his]120-henchard judgment on [her]191-henchard quality . [She]191-henchard read and took notes incessantly , mastering facts with painful laboriousness , but never flinching from [her]191-henchard self - imposed task . [She]191-henchard began the study of Latin , incited by the Roman characteristics of [the town]632-the town [she]191-henchard lived in . “ If [I]2124-he am not well - informed it shall be by no fault of [my]2124-he own , ”[2124-he] [she]191-henchard would say to [herself]191-henchard through the tears that would occasionally glide down [her]191-henchard peachy cheeks when [she]191-henchard was fairly baffled by the portentous obscurity of many of these educational works . Thus [she]191-henchard lived on , [a dumb , deep - feeling , great - eyed creature]2081-a dumb , deep - feeling , great - eyed creature , construed by [not a single contiguous being]2082-not a single contiguous being ; quenching with patient fortitude [her]191-henchard incipient interest in [Farfrae]149-farfrae , because it seemed to be one - sided , unmaidenly , and unwise . True , that for reasons best known to [herself]191-henchard , [she]191-henchard had , since [Farfrae]149-farfrae 's dismissal , shifted [[her]191-henchard quarters]2083-her quarters from [the back room]1948-the back room affording a view of [the yard]1277-the yard ( which [she]191-henchard had occupied with such zest ) to [a front chamber overlooking [the street]797-the street]2086-a front chamber overlooking the street ; but as for [the young man]371-the young man , whenever [he]371-the young man passed [the house]782-the house [he]371-the young man seldom or never turned [his]371-the young man head . Winter had almost come , and unsettled weather made [her]191-henchard still more dependent upon indoor resources . But there were certain early winter days in [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge — days of firmamental exhaustion which followed [angry south - westerly tempests]2090-angry south - westerly tempests — when , if the sun shone , the air was like velvet . [She]191-henchard seized on these days for [her]191-henchard periodical visits to the spot where [[her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother lay buried — [the still - used burial - ground of [the old Roman - British city]2093-the old roman - british city , whose curious feature was this , [its]2093-the old roman - british city continuity as [a place of sepulture]2094-a place of sepulture]2092-the still - used burial - ground of the old roman - british city , whose curious feature was this , its continuity as a place of sepulture . [Mrs. Henchard]128-henchard 's dust mingled with the dust of [women who lay ornamented with glass hair - pins and amber necklaces]2095-women who lay ornamented with glass hair - pins and amber necklaces , and [men who held in [their]2096-men who held in their mouths coins of hadrian , posthumus , and the constantines mouths coins of [Hadrian]197-hadrian , [Posthumus]198-posthumus , and [the Constantines]2097-the constantines]2096-men who held in their mouths coins of hadrian , posthumus , and the constantines . Half - past ten in the morning was about [her]191-henchard hour for seeking [this spot]1420-this spot — a time when [the town]632-the town avenues were deserted as [the avenues of [Karnac]57-karnac]2100-the avenues of karnac . Business had long since passed down [them]2100-the avenues of karnac into [its]2100-the avenues of karnac daily cells , and [Leisure]199-leisure had not arrived [there]447-there . So [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard walked and read , or looked over the edge of the book to think , and thus reached [the churchyard]2102-the churchyard . There , approaching [[[her]191-henchard mother]588-her mother 's grave]2104-her mother 's grave [she]191-henchard saw [a solitary dark figure in the middle of the gravel - walk]2105-a solitary dark figure in the middle of the gravel - walk . [This figure]2106-this figure , too , was reading ; but not from a book : the words which engrossed it being the inscription on [[Mrs. Henchard]128-henchard 's tombstone]2107-mrs. henchard 's tombstone . [The personage]2108-the personage was in mourning like [herself]191-henchard , was about [her]191-henchard age and size , and might have been [her]191-henchard wraith or double , but for the fact that it was [a lady]2109-a lady much more beautifully dressed than [she]191-henchard . Indeed , comparatively indifferent as [Elizabeth]191-henchard - [Jane]191-henchard was to dress , unless for some temporary whim or purpose , [her]191-henchard eyes were arrested by the artistic perfection of [the lady]2110-the lady 's appearance . [Her]191-henchard gait , too , had a flexuousness about it , which seemed to avoid angularity . It was a revelation to [Elizabeth]191-henchard that [human beings]1011-human beings could reach this stage of external development — [she]191-henchard had never suspected it . [She]191-henchard felt all the freshness and grace to be stolen from [herself]191-henchard on the instant by the neighbourhood of [such a stranger]2112-such a stranger . And this was in face of the fact that [Elizabeth]191-henchard could now have been writ handsome , while [the young lady]4876-the young lady was simply pretty . Had [she]191-henchard been envious [she]191-henchard might have hated [the woman]300-the woman ; but [she]191-henchard did not do that — [she]191-henchard allowed [herself]191-henchard the pleasure of feeling fascinated . [She]191-henchard wondered where [the lady]2110-the lady had come from . The stumpy and practical walk of honest homeliness which mostly prevailed there , the two styles of dress thereabout , the simple and the mistaken , equally avouched that [this figure]2106-this figure was [no Casterbridge woman]2117-no casterbridge woman 's , even if a book in [her]191-henchard hand resembling a guide - book had not also suggested it . [The stranger]2118-the stranger presently moved from [the tombstone of [Mrs. Henchard]128-henchard]2119-the tombstone of mrs. henchard , and vanished behind the corner of the wall . [Elizabeth]191-henchard went to [the tomb]2120-the tomb [herself]191-henchard ; beside [it]2120-the tomb were two footprints distinct in the soil , signifying that [the lady]2110-the lady had stood there a long time . [She]191-henchard returned [homeward]2122-homeward , musing on what [she]191-henchard had seen , as [she]191-henchard might have mused on a rainbow or the Northern Lights , a rare butterfly or a cameo . Interesting as things had been out of doors , at [home]675-home it turned out to be one of [her]191-henchard bad days . [Henchard]128-henchard , whose two years ' mayoralty was ending , had been made aware that [he]2124-he was not to be chosen to fill a vacancy in the list of [aldermen]2125-aldermen ; and that [Farfrae]149-farfrae was likely to become [one of [the Council]2127-the council]2126-one of the council . This caused the unfortunate discovery that [she]2110-the lady had played [the waiting - maid in [the town of which [he]2124-he was [Mayor]1548-mayor]2129-the town of which he was mayor to rankle in [his]2124-he mind yet more poisonously]2128-the waiting - maid in the town of which he was mayor to rankle in his mind yet more poisonously . [He]2124-he had learnt by personal inquiry at the time that it was to [Donald Farfrae]139-farfrae — [that treacherous upstart]2131-that treacherous upstart — that [she]2110-the lady had thus humiliated [herself]2110-the lady . And though [Mrs. Stannidge]136-mrs. stannidge seemed to attach no great importance to the incident — the cheerful souls at [the Three Mariners]4601-the three mariners having exhausted its aspects long ago — such was [Henchard]128-henchard 's haughty spirit that the simple thrifty deed was regarded as little less than a social catastrophe by [him]2124-he . Ever since the evening of [[his]2124-he wife]380-his wife 's arrival with [[her]380-his wife daughter]4518-her daughter there had been something in the air which had changed [his]2124-he luck . That dinner at [the King]1084-the king 's Arms with [[his]2124-he friends]2136-his friends had been [Henchard]128-henchard 's Austerlitz : [he]2124-he had had [his]2124-he successes since , but [his]2124-he course had not been upward . [He]2124-he was not to be numbered among [the aldermen]2137-the aldermen — [that Peerage of burghers]2138-that peerage of burghers — as [he]2124-he had expected to be , and the consciousness of this soured [him]2124-he to - day . “ Well , where have [you]380-his wife been ? ”[2124-he] [he]2124-he said to [her]380-his wife with offhand laconism . “ [I]2124-he 've been strolling in the Walks and [churchyard]5150-churchyard , [father]4491-father , till [I]2124-he feel quite leery . ”[2124-he] [She]380-his wife clapped [her]380-his wife hand to [her]380-his wife mouth , but too late . This was just enough to incense [Henchard]128-henchard after the other crosses of the day . “ [I]2124-he WON'T have [you]380-his wife talk like that ! ”[2124-he] [he]2124-he thundered . “ ' Leery , ' indeed . [One]1127-one would think [you]380-his wife worked upon [a farm]5153-a farm ! One day [I]2124-he learn that [you]380-his wife lend a hand in [public - houses]5154-public - houses . Then [I]2124-he hear [you]380-his wife talk like a clodhopper . [I]2124-he 'm burned , if it goes on , [this house]5155-this house ca n't hold [us]5156-us two . ”[2124-he] The only way of getting a single pleasant thought to go to sleep upon after this was by recalling [the lady [she]380-his wife had seen]2139-the lady she had seen that day , and hoping [she]2139-the lady she had seen might see [her]2139-the lady she had seen again . Meanwhile [Henchard]128-henchard was sitting up , thinking over [his]2124-he jealous folly in forbidding [Farfrae]139-farfrae to pay [his]2124-he addresses to [this girl who did not belong to [him]2124-he]2140-this girl who did not belong to him , when if [he]2124-he had allowed [them]2141-them to go on [he]2124-he might not have been encumbered with [her]2140-this girl who did not belong to him . At last [he]2124-he said to [himself]2124-he with satisfaction as [he]2124-he jumped up and went to the writing - table : “ Ah ! [he]2124-he 'll think it means peace , and a marriage portion — not that [I]2110-the lady do n't want [[my]2110-the lady house]4643-my house to be troubled with [her]191-henchard , and no portion at all ! ”[2110-the lady] [He]2124-he wrote as follows : — [Sir]4588-sir , — On consideration , [I]0-i do n't wish to interfere with [your]4588-sir courtship of [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard , if [you]4588-sir care for [her]191-henchard . [I]0-i therefore withdraw [my]0-i objection ; excepting in this — that the business be not carried on in [[my]0-i house]4643-my house . — [Yours]4588-sir , [M. HENCHARD]178-henchard . [Mr. Farfrae]149-farfrae . The morrow , being fairly fine , found [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard again in [the churchyard]2102-the churchyard , but while looking for [the lady]2110-the lady [she]191-henchard was startled by the apparition of [Farfrae]149-farfrae , who passed outside the gate . [He]2124-he glanced up for a moment from a pocket - book in which [he]2124-he appeared to be making figures as [he]2124-he went ; whether or not [he]2124-he saw [her]2110-the lady [he]2124-he took no notice , and disappeared . Unduly depressed by a sense of [her]2110-the lady own superfluity [she]2110-the lady thought [he]2124-he probably scorned [her]2110-the lady ; and quite broken in spirit sat down on a bench . [She]2110-the lady fell into painful thought on [her]2110-the lady position , which ended with [her]2110-the lady saying quite loud , “ O , [I]2110-the lady wish [I]2110-the lady was dead with [dear mother]5158-dear mother ! ”[2110-the lady] Behind the bench was a little promenade under the wall where [people]1161-people sometimes walked instead of on the gravel . The bench seemed to be touched by something , [she]2110-the lady looked round , and a face was bending over [her]2110-the lady , veiled , but still distinct , the face of [the young woman [she]2110-the lady had seen yesterday]2147-the young woman she had seen yesterday . [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard looked confounded for a moment , knowing [she]191-henchard had been overheard , though there was pleasure in [her]191-henchard confusion . “ Yes , [I]2110-the lady heard [you]2110-the lady , ”[2110-the lady] said [the lady]2110-the lady , in a vivacious voice , answering [her]2110-the lady look . “ What can have happened ? ”[191-henchard] “ [I]4511-the latter do n't — [I]4511-the latter ca n't tell [you]4876-the young lady , ”[4511-the latter] said [Elizabeth]191-henchard , putting [her]191-henchard hand to [her]191-henchard face to hide a quick flush that had come . There was no movement or word for a few seconds ; then [the girl]311-the girl felt that [the young lady]4876-the young lady was sitting down beside [her]311-the girl . “ [I]4876-the young lady guess how it is with [you]311-the girl , ”[4876-the young lady] said [the latter]4511-the latter . “ That was [[your]311-the girl mother]4779-your mother . ”[311-the girl] [She]4876-the young lady waved [her]4876-the young lady hand towards [the tombstone]2152-the tombstone . [Elizabeth]191-henchard looked up at [her]4876-the young lady as if inquiring of [herself]191-henchard whether there should be confidence . [The lady]2110-the lady 's manner was so desirous , so anxious , that [the girl]311-the girl decided there should be confidence . “ It was [[my]311-the girl mother]5160-my mother , ”[311-the girl] [she]311-the girl said , “ [[my]2110-the lady only friend]5161-my only friend . ”[2110-the lady] “ But [[your]311-the girl father]5032-your father , [Mr. Henchard]120-henchard . [He]5032-your father is living ? ”[191-henchard] “ Yes , [he]5032-your father is living , ”[191-henchard] said [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard . “ Is [he]5032-your father not kind to [you]311-the girl ? ”[2110-the lady] “ [I]2110-the lady 've no wish to complain of [him]5032-your father . ”[2110-the lady] “ There has been a disagreement ? ”[191-henchard] “ A little . ”[2118-the stranger] “ Perhaps [you]311-the girl were to blame , ”[191-henchard] suggested [the stranger]2118-the stranger . “ [I]191-henchard was — in many ways , ”[191-henchard] sighed [the meek Elizabeth]191-henchard . “ [I]191-henchard swept up the coals when [the servants]2053-the servants ought to have done it ; and [I]191-henchard said [I]191-henchard was leery ; — and [he]5032-your father was angry with [me]191-henchard . ”[191-henchard] [The lady]2110-the lady seemed to warm towards [her]191-henchard for that reply . “ Do [you]2110-the lady know the impression [your]2110-the lady words give [me]191-henchard ? ”[191-henchard] [she]191-henchard said ingenuously . “ That [he]5032-your father is [a hot - tempered man]5164-a hot - tempered man — a little proud — perhaps ambitious ; but not [a bad man]5165-a bad man . ”[2157-the honest girl] [Her]2110-the lady anxiety not to condemn [Henchard]191-henchard while siding with [Elizabeth]191-henchard was curious . “ O no ; certainly not BAD , ”[2157-the honest girl] agreed [the honest girl]2157-the honest girl . “ And [he]5032-your father has not even been unkind to [me]191-henchard till lately — since [mother]4495-mother died . But it has been very much to bear while it has lasted . All is owing to [my]191-henchard defects , [I]191-henchard daresay ; and [my]191-henchard defects are owing to [my]191-henchard history . ”[191-henchard] “ What is [your]2158-her questioner history ? ”[191-henchard] [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard looked wistfully at [[her]191-henchard questioner]2158-her questioner . [She]191-henchard found that [[her]191-henchard questioner]2158-her questioner was looking at [her]191-henchard , turned [her]2158-her questioner eyes down ; and then seemed compelled to look back again . “ [My]191-henchard history is not gay or attractive , ”[191-henchard] [she]191-henchard said . “ And yet [I]311-the girl can tell it , if [you]2158-her questioner really want to know . ”[311-the girl] [The lady]2110-the lady assured [her]191-henchard that [she]191-henchard did want to know ; whereupon [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard told the tale of [her]191-henchard life as [she]191-henchard understood it , which was in general the true one , except that the sale at the fair had no part therein . Contrary to [the girl]311-the girl 's expectation [[her]191-henchard new friend]2162-her new friend was not shocked . This cheered [her]311-the girl ; and it was not till [she]311-the girl thought of returning to [that home in which [she]311-the girl had been treated so roughly of late]2163-that home in which she had been treated so roughly of late that [her]311-the girl spirits fell . “ [I]311-the girl do n't know how to return , ”[311-the girl] [she]311-the girl murmured . “ [I]2164-her friend think of going away . But what can [I]2164-her friend do ? Where can [I]2164-her friend go ? ”[2164-her friend] “ Perhaps it will be better soon , ”[2164-her friend] said [[her]191-henchard friend]2164-her friend gently . “ So [I]191-henchard would not go far . Now what do [you]2162-her new friend think of this : [I]191-henchard shall soon want [somebody]4446-somebody to live in [[my]191-henchard house]4643-my house , partly as [housekeeper]5169-housekeeper , partly as [companion]5170-companion ; would [you]2162-her new friend mind coming to [me]191-henchard ? But perhaps — ”[191-henchard] “ O yes , ”[191-henchard] cried [Elizabeth]191-henchard , with tears in [her]191-henchard eyes . “ [I]2164-her friend would , indeed — [I]2164-her friend would do anything to be independent ; for then perhaps [[my]2164-her friend father]5103-my father might get to love [me]2164-her friend . But , ah ! ”[2164-her friend] “ What ? ”[2164-her friend] “ [I]2164-her friend am [no accomplished person]5172-no accomplished person . And [a companion]5173-a companion to [you]2162-her new friend must be that . ”[2164-her friend] “ O , not necessarily . ”[2164-her friend] “ Not ? But [I]2164-her friend ca n't help using rural words sometimes , when [I]2164-her friend do n't mean to . ”[2164-her friend] “ Never mind , [I]2164-her friend shall like to know [them]5174-them . ”[2164-her friend] “ And — O , [I]191-henchard know [I]191-henchard sha n't do ! ”[191-henchard] — [she]191-henchard cried with a distressful laugh . “ [I]2164-her friend accidentally learned to write round hand instead of ladies'-hand . And , of course , [you]2162-her new friend want [some one who can write that]5175-some one who can write that ? ”[2164-her friend] “ Well , no . ”[191-henchard] “ What , not necessary to write ladies'-hand ? ”[191-henchard] cried [the joyous Elizabeth]191-henchard . “ Not at all . ”[2164-her friend] “ But where do [you]2162-her new friend live ? ”[191-henchard] “ In [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge , or rather [I]191-henchard shall be living [here]4417-here after twelve o'clock to - day . ”[191-henchard] [Elizabeth]191-henchard expressed [her]191-henchard astonishment . “ [I]2191-the old - fashioned stranger have been staying at [Budmouth]54-budmouth for a few days while [[my]2191-the old - fashioned stranger house]4643-my house was getting ready . [The house [I]2191-the old - fashioned stranger am going into]5178-the house i am going into is [that one [they]5180-they call [High - Place Hall]58-high - place hall]5179-that one they call high - place hall — [the old stone one looking down [the lane]5182-the lane to [the market]5183-the market]5181-the old stone one looking down the lane to the market . [Two or three rooms]5184-two or three rooms are fit for occupation , though not all : [I]2191-the old - fashioned stranger sleep [there]447-there to - night for the first time . Now will [you]191-henchard think over [my]2191-the old - fashioned stranger proposal , and meet [me]2191-the old - fashioned stranger [here]4417-here the first fine day next week , and say if [you]191-henchard are still in the same mind ? ”[2191-the old - fashioned stranger] [Elizabeth]191-henchard , [her]191-henchard eyes shining at this prospect of a change from an unbearable position , joyfully assented ; and [the two]2165-the two parted at the gate of [the churchyard]2102-the churchyard .

As a maxim glibly repeated from childhood remains practically unmarked till some mature experience enforces it , so did [this High - Place Hall]2167-this high - place hall now for the first time really show itself to [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard , though [her]191-henchard ears had heard its name on a hundred occasions . [Her]191-henchard mind dwelt upon nothing else but [the stranger]2118-the stranger , and [the house]782-the house , and [her]191-henchard own chance of living [there]447-there , all the rest of the day . In the afternoon [she]191-henchard had occasion to pay a few bills in [the town]632-the town and do a little shopping when [she]191-henchard learnt that what was a new discovery to [herself]191-henchard had become a common topic about [the streets]1748-the streets . [High - Place Hall]58-high - place hall was undergoing repair ; [a lady]2109-a lady was coming [there]447-there to live shortly ; [all the shop - people]2175-all the shop - people knew it , and had already discounted the chance of [her]2109-a lady being [a customer]2176-a customer . [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard could , however , add a capping touch to information so new to [her]191-henchard in the bulk . [The lady]2110-the lady , [she]191-henchard said , had arrived that day . When the lamps were lighted , and it was yet not so dark as to render chimneys , [attics]2178-attics , and [roofs]2179-roofs invisible , [Elizabeth]191-henchard , almost with [a lover]2180-a lover 's feeling , thought [she]191-henchard would like to look at the outside of [High - Place Hall]58-high - place hall . [She]191-henchard went up [the street]797-the street in that direction . [The Hall]1877-the hall , with [its]1877-the hall grey facade and parapet , was [the only residence of [its]1877-the hall sort so near [the centre of [the town]632-the town]2184-the centre of the town]2183-the only residence of its sort so near the centre of the town . [It]1877-the hall had , in the first place , the characteristics of [a country mansion]2186-a country mansion — birds ' nests in [its]1877-the hall chimneys , damp nooks where fungi grew and irregularities of surface direct from Nature 's trowel . At night the forms of [passengers]2187-passengers were patterned by the lamps in black shadows upon the pale walls . This evening motes of straw lay around , and other signs of [the premises]1016-the premises having been in that lawless condition which accompanies the entry of [a new tenant]2189-a new tenant . [The house]782-the house was entirely of stone , and formed an example of dignity without great size . [It]782-the house was not altogether aristocratic , still less consequential , yet [the old - fashioned stranger]2191-the old - fashioned stranger instinctively said “ [Blood]200-blood built [it]782-the house , and [Wealth]201-wealth enjoys [it]782-the house ”[191-henchard] however vague [his]2191-the old - fashioned stranger opinions of those accessories might be . Yet as regards the enjoying it [the stranger]2118-the stranger would have been wrong , for until this very evening , when [the new lady]2193-the new lady had arrived , [the house]782-the house had been empty for a year or two while before that interval [its]782-the house occupancy had been irregular . The reason of [its]782-the house unpopularity was soon made manifest . Some of [[its]782-the house rooms]2195-its rooms overlooked [the market - place]1919-the market - place ; and such a prospect from [such a house]2197-such a house was not considered desirable or seemly by [[its]782-the house would - be occupiers]2198-its would - be occupiers . [Elizabeth]191-henchard 's eyes sought [the upper rooms]2199-the upper rooms , and saw lights there . [The lady]2110-the lady had obviously arrived . The impression that [this woman of comparatively practised manner]2201-this woman of comparatively practised manner had made upon [the studious girl]2202-the studious girl 's mind was so deep that [she]191-henchard enjoyed standing under an opposite archway merely to think that [the charming lady]2203-the charming lady was inside the confronting walls , and to wonder what [she]2110-the lady was doing . [Her]191-henchard admiration for the architecture of [that front]2204-that front was entirely on account of the inmate [it]782-the house screened . Though for that matter the architecture deserved admiration , or at least study , on its own account . It was Palladian , and like most architecture erected since the Gothic age was a compilation rather than a design . But its reasonableness made it impressive . [It]782-the house was not rich , but rich enough . A timely consciousness of the ultimate vanity of human architecture , no less than of other human things , had prevented artistic superfluity . [Men]4432-men had still quite recently been going in and out with parcels and packing - cases , rendering the door and [hall]2206-hall within like a public thoroughfare . [Elizabeth]191-henchard trotted through the open door in the dusk , but becoming alarmed at [her]191-henchard own temerity [she]191-henchard went quickly out again by another which stood open in the lofty wall of [the back court]2207-the back court . To [her]191-henchard surprise [she]191-henchard found [herself]191-henchard in [one of [the little - used alleys of [the town]632-the town]2209-the little - used alleys of the town]2208-one of the little - used alleys of the town . Looking round at the door which had given [her]191-henchard egress , by the light of the solitary lamp fixed in [the alley]2211-the alley , [she]191-henchard saw that [it]2212-it was arched and old — older even than [the house]782-the house itself . The door was studded , and the keystone of the arch was a mask . Originally the mask had exhibited a comic leer , as could still be discerned ; but [generations of Casterbridge boys]2214-generations of casterbridge boys had thrown stones at the mask , aiming at its open mouth ; and the blows thereon had chipped off the lips and jaws as if they had been eaten away by disease . The appearance was so ghastly by the weakly lamp - glimmer that [she]191-henchard could not bear to look at it — the first unpleasant feature of [her]191-henchard visit . The position of the queer old door and the odd presence of the leering mask suggested one thing above all others as appertaining to [the mansion]2215-the mansion 's past history — intrigue . By [the alley]2211-the alley it had been possible to come unseen from [all sorts of quarters in [the town]632-the town]2217-all sorts of quarters in the town — [the old play - house]2219-the old play - house , [the old bull - stake]2220-the old bull - stake , [the old cock - pit]2221-the old cock - pit , [the pool wherein [nameless infants]2223-nameless infants had been used to disappear]2222-the pool wherein nameless infants had been used to disappear . [High - Place Hall]58-high - place hall could boast of [its]58-high - place hall conveniences undoubtedly . [She]191-henchard turned to come away in the nearest direction homeward , which was down [the alley]2211-the alley , but hearing footsteps approaching in [that quarter]2225-that quarter , and having no great wish to be found in such a place at such a time [she]191-henchard quickly retreated . There being no other way out [she]191-henchard stood behind [a brick pier]2226-a brick pier till [the intruder]2227-the intruder should have gone [his]2227-the intruder ways . Had [she]191-henchard watched [she]191-henchard would have been surprised . [She]191-henchard would have seen that [the pedestrian on coming up]2228-the pedestrian on coming up made straight for the arched doorway : that as [he]2227-the intruder paused with [his]2227-the intruder hand upon the latch the lamplight fell upon the face of [Henchard]191-henchard . But [Elizabeth]191-henchard - [Jane]191-henchard clung so closely to [[her]191-henchard nook]2229-her nook that [she]191-henchard discerned nothing of this . [Henchard]191-henchard passed in , as ignorant of [her]191-henchard presence as [she]191-henchard was ignorant of [his]2227-the intruder identity , and disappeared in the darkness . [Elizabeth]191-henchard came out a second time into [the alley]2211-the alley , and made the best of [her]191-henchard way [home]675-home . [Henchard]191-henchard 's chiding , by begetting in [her]191-henchard a nervous fear of doing anything definable as unladylike , had operated thus curiously in keeping [them]2232-them unknown to each other at a critical moment . Much might have resulted from recognition — at the least a query on either side in one and the selfsame form : What could [he]2233-he or [she]2234-she possibly be doing [there]447-there ? [Henchard]191-henchard , whatever [his]2227-the intruder business at [[the lady]2110-the lady 's house]2237-the lady 's house , reached [[his]2227-the intruder own home]2238-his own home only a few minutes later than [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard . [Her]191-henchard plan was to broach the question of leaving [[his]2227-the intruder roof]2239-his roof this evening ; the events of the day had urged [her]191-henchard to the course . But its execution depended upon [his]2227-the intruder mood , and [she]191-henchard anxiously awaited [his]2227-the intruder manner towards [her]191-henchard . [She]191-henchard found that it had changed . [He]2227-the intruder showed no further tendency to be angry ; [he]2227-the intruder showed something worse . Absolute indifference had taken the place of irritability ; and [his]2227-the intruder coldness was such that it encouraged [her]191-henchard to departure , even more than hot temper could have done . “ [Father]202-father , have [you]202-father any objection to [my]191-henchard going away ? ”[191-henchard] [she]191-henchard asked . “ Going away ! No — none whatever . Where are [you]191-henchard going ? ”[191-henchard] [She]191-henchard thought it undesirable and unnecessary to say anything at present about [her]191-henchard destination to one who took so little interest in [her]191-henchard . [He]2227-the intruder would know that soon enough . “ [I]191-henchard have heard of an opportunity of getting more cultivated and finished , and being less idle , ”[191-henchard] [she]191-henchard answered , with hesitation . “ A chance of a place in [a household where [I]2227-the intruder can have advantages of study , and seeing refined life]5187-a household where i can have advantages of study , and seeing refined life . ”[2227-the intruder] “ Then make the best of it , in [Heaven]123-heaven 's name — if [you]191-henchard ca n't get cultivated where [you]191-henchard are . ”[2227-the intruder] “ [You]191-henchard do n't object ? ”[191-henchard] “ Object — [I]2227-the intruder ? Ho — no ! Not at all . ”[2227-the intruder] After a pause [he]2227-the intruder said , “ But [you]191-henchard wo n't have enough money for this lively scheme without help , [you]191-henchard know ? If [you]191-henchard like [I]2227-the intruder should be willing to make [you]191-henchard an allowance , so that [you]191-henchard not be bound to live upon the starvation wages [refined folk]5188-refined folk are likely to pay ' [ee]5189-ee . ”[2227-the intruder] [She]191-henchard thanked [him]2227-the intruder for this offer . “ It had better be done properly , ”[2227-the intruder] [he]2227-the intruder added after a pause . “ A small annuity is what [I]2227-the intruder should like [you]191-henchard to have — so as to be independent of [me]2227-the intruder — and so that [I]2227-the intruder may be independent of [you]191-henchard . Would that please [ye]191-henchard ? ”[2227-the intruder] “ Certainly . ”[2227-the intruder] “ Then [I]2110-the lady 'll see about it this very day . ”[2110-the lady] [He]2227-the intruder seemed relieved to get [her]191-henchard off [his]2227-the intruder hands by this arrangement , and as far as [they]2240-they were concerned the matter was settled . [She]191-henchard now simply waited to see [the lady]2110-the lady again . The day and the hour came ; but a drizzling rain fell . [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard having now changed [her]191-henchard orbit from one of gay independence to laborious self - help , thought the weather good enough for such declined glory as [hers]191-henchard , if [[her]191-henchard friend]2164-her friend would only face it — a matter of doubt . [She]191-henchard went to [the boot - room where [her]191-henchard pattens had hung ever since [her]191-henchard apotheosis]2243-the boot - room where her pattens had hung ever since her apotheosis ; took them down , had their mildewed leathers blacked , and put them on as [she]191-henchard had done in old times . Thus mounted , and with cloak and umbrella , [she]191-henchard went off to [the place of appointment]2244-the place of appointment — intending , if [the lady]2110-the lady were not [there]447-there , to call at [the house]782-the house . [One side of [the churchyard]2102-the churchyard]2248-one side of the churchyard — the side towards the weather — was sheltered by an ancient thatched mud wall whose eaves overhung as much as one or two feet . At the back of the wall was [a corn - yard]2250-a corn - yard with [[its]2250-a corn - yard granary and [barns]1627-barns]2251-its granary and barns — [the place wherein [she]191-henchard had met [Farfrae]149-farfrae many months earlier]2253-the place wherein she had met farfrae many months earlier . Under the projection of the thatch [she]191-henchard saw a figure . [The young lady]4876-the young lady had come . [Her]4876-the young lady presence so exceptionally substantiated [the girl]311-the girl 's utmost hopes that [she]311-the girl almost feared [her]311-the girl good fortune . Fancies find rooms in the strongest minds . Here , in [a churchyard old as civilization]2256-a churchyard old as civilization , in the worst of weathers , was [a strange woman of curious fascinations never seen elsewhere]2257-a strange woman of curious fascinations never seen elsewhere : there might be some devilry about [her]4876-the young lady presence . However , [Elizabeth]191-henchard went on to [the church tower]2258-the church tower , on whose summit the rope of a flagstaff rattled in the wind ; and thus [she]191-henchard came to the wall . [The lady]2110-the lady had such a cheerful aspect in the drizzle that [Elizabeth]191-henchard forgot [her]191-henchard fancy . “ Well , ”[2110-the lady] said [the lady]2110-the lady , a little of the whiteness of [her]2110-the lady teeth appearing with the word through the black fleece that protected [her]2110-the lady face , “ have [you]191-henchard decided ? ”[2110-the lady] “ Yes , quite , ”[2110-the lady] said the other eagerly . “ [[Your]191-henchard father]5032-your father is willing ? ”[2110-the lady] “ Yes . ”[2110-the lady] “ Then come along . ”[2110-the lady] “ When ? ”[2110-the lady] “ Now — as soon as [you]191-henchard like . [I]2110-the lady had a good mind to send to [you]191-henchard to come to [[my]2110-the lady house]4643-my house , thinking [you]191-henchard might not venture up here in the wind . But as [I]2110-the lady like getting out of doors , [I]2110-the lady thought [I]2110-the lady would come and see first . ”[2110-the lady] “ It was [my]2110-the lady own thought . ”[2110-the lady] “ That shows [we]2263-both the women shall agree . [[My]311-the girl house]4643-my house is so hollow and dismal that [I]311-the girl want some living thing there . ”[311-the girl] “ [I]2110-the lady think [I]2110-the lady might be able to , ”[2110-the lady] said [the girl]311-the girl , reflecting . [Both the women]2263-both the women listened . “ Who are those ? ”[2110-the lady] said [the lady]2110-the lady . “ One is [[my]2110-the lady father]5103-my father . At last [she]2110-the lady said suddenly , “ Did [you]191-henchard tell [him]5103-my father where [you]191-henchard were going to ? ”[2110-the lady] “ No . ”[2110-the lady] “ O — how was that ? ”[2110-the lady] “ [I]2110-the lady thought it safer to get away first — as [he]5103-my father is so uncertain in [his]5103-my father temper . ”[2110-the lady] “ Perhaps [you]191-henchard are right .... Six o'clock then . ”[2070-his step - daughter] When [they]2267-they had emerged upon [the open road]2268-the open road and parted , [they]2267-they found enough to do in holding [their]2267-they bowed umbrellas to the wind . Now [Henchard]191-henchard had not the slightest suspicion that [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard 's movement was to be so prompt . [We]2287-we go back for a moment to the preceding night , to account for [Henchard]191-henchard 's attitude . At the hour when [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard was contemplating [her]191-henchard stealthy reconnoitring excursion to [the abode of [the lady of [her]191-henchard fancy]2289-the lady of her fancy]2288-the abode of the lady of her fancy , [he]2284-i had been not a little amazed at receiving a letter by hand in [[Lucetta]188-lucetta 's well - known characters]2290-lucetta 's well - known characters .
