[I]0-i 've capital , mind [ye]2601-ye , and [I]0-i can do it . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i 'm all that way of thinking , ” said [the new foreman]5453-the new foreman . [Jopp]137-jopp 's dislike of [Farfrae]139-farfrae as [the man who had once ursurped [his]886-the scotchman place]5454-the man who had once ursurped his place , while it made [him]886-the scotchman a willing tool , made [him]137-jopp , at the same time , commercially as unsafe [a colleague as [Henchard]191-henchard]5455-a colleague as henchard could have chosen . “[0-i] [I]0-i sometimes think , ” [he]0-i added , “[886-the scotchman] that [he]886-the scotchman must have some glass that [he]886-the scotchman sees next year in . [He]886-the scotchman has such a knack of making everything bring [him]886-the scotchman fortune . ” “[2603-we] [He]886-the scotchman 's deep beyond all [honest men]2602-honest men 's discerning , but [we]2603-we must make [him]886-the scotchman shallower . [We]2603-we 'll undersell [him]886-the scotchman , and over - buy [him]886-the scotchman , and so snuff [him]886-the scotchman out . ” [They]2603-we then entered into specific details of the process by which this would be accomplished , and parted at a late hour . [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard heard by accident that [Jopp]137-jopp had been engaged by [[her]191-henchard stepfather]5242-her stepfather . [She]191-henchard was so fully convinced that [he]886-the scotchman was not [the right man for [the place]515-the place]5457-the right man for the place that , at the risk of making [Henchard]191-henchard angry , [she]191-henchard expressed [her]191-henchard apprehension to [him]886-the scotchman when [they]2603-we met . But it was done to no purpose . [Henchard]191-henchard shut up [her]191-henchard argument with a sharp rebuff . The season 's weather seemed to favour [their]2603-we scheme . The time was in the years immediately before foreign competition had revolutionized the trade in grain ; when still , as from the earliest ages , the wheat quotations from month to month depended entirely upon the home harvest . A bad harvest , or the prospect of one , would double the price of corn in a few weeks ; and the promise of a good yield would lower it as rapidly . Prices were like the roads of the period , steep in gradient , reflecting in their phases the local conditions , without engineering , levellings , or averages . [The farmer]1607-the farmer 's income was ruled by the wheat - crop within [his]1607-the farmer own horizon , and the wheat - crop by the weather . Thus in [person]5460-person , [he]886-the scotchman became a sort of flesh - barometer , with feelers always directed to the sky and wind around [him]886-the scotchman . The local atmosphere was everything to [him]886-the scotchman ; the atmospheres of [other countries]5461-other countries a matter of indifference . [The people]4635-the people , too , who were not [farmers]712-farmers , [the rural multitude]5464-the rural multitude , saw in the god of the weather a more important personage than [they]4635-the people do now . Indeed , the feeling of [the peasantry]5465-the peasantry in this matter was so intense as to be almost unrealizable in these equable days . [Their]5465-the peasantry impulse was well - nigh to prostrate [themselves]5465-the peasantry in lamentation before untimely rains and tempests , which came as the Alastor of [those households whose crime it was to be poor]5466-those households whose crime it was to be poor . After midsummer [they]5465-the peasantry watched the weather - cocks as [men waiting in antechambers]5467-men waiting in antechambers watch [the lackey]5468-the lackey . Sun elated [them]5465-the peasantry ; quiet rain sobered [them]5465-the peasantry ; weeks of watery tempest stupefied [them]5465-the peasantry . That aspect of the sky which [they]5465-the peasantry now regard as disagreeable [they]5465-the peasantry then beheld as maleficent . It was June , and the weather was very unfavourable . [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge , being as it were the bell - board on which [all the adjacent hamlets and villages]5469-all the adjacent hamlets and villages sounded [their]5465-the peasantry notes , was decidedly dull . Instead of new articles in the shop - windows those that had been rejected in the foregoing summer were brought out again ; superseded reap - hooks , badly - shaped rakes , shop - worn leggings , and time - stiffened water - tights reappeared , furbished up as near to new as possible . [Henchard]191-henchard , backed by [Jopp]137-jopp , read a disastrous garnering , and resolved to base [his]137-jopp strategy against [Farfrae]139-farfrae upon that reading . But before acting [he]137-jopp wished — what so many have wished — that [he]137-jopp could know for certain what was at present only strong probability . [He]137-jopp was superstitious — as such head - strong natures often are — and [he]137-jopp nourished in [his]137-jopp mind an idea bearing on the matter ; an idea [he]137-jopp shrank from disclosing even to [Jopp]137-jopp . In [a lonely hamlet a few miles from [the town]632-the town]5470-a lonely hamlet a few miles from the town — so lonely that [what are called lonely villages]5472-what are called lonely villages were teeming by comparison — there lived [a man of curious repute]5473-a man of curious repute as [a forecaster or weather - prophet]5474-a forecaster or weather - prophet . The way to [[his]5473-a man of curious repute house]1329-his house was crooked and miry — even difficult in the present unpropitious season . One evening when it was raining so heavily that ivy and laurel resounded like distant musketry , and [an out - door man]5476-an out - door man could be excused for shrouding [himself]5473-a man of curious repute to [his]5473-a man of curious repute ears and eyes , such [a shrouded figure on foot]5477-a shrouded figure on foot might have been perceived travelling in the direction of the hazel - copse which dripped over [the prophet]5478-the prophet 's cot . [The turnpike - road]1405-the turnpike - road became [a lane]537-a lane , [the lane]5182-the lane a cart - track , [the cart - track]5482-the cart - track a bridle - path , [the bridle - path]5483-the bridle - path a foot - way , the foot - way overgrown . [The solitary walker]5484-the solitary walker slipped here and there , and stumbled over the natural springes formed by the brambles , till at length [he]5484-the solitary walker reached [the house]782-the house , which , with [[its]782-the house garden]5486-its garden , was surrounded with a high , dense hedge . [The cottage]5487-the cottage , comparatively a large one , had been built of mud by [the occupier]5488-the occupier 's own hands , and thatched also by [himself]5473-a man of curious repute . Here [he]5473-a man of curious repute had always lived , and here it was assumed [he]5473-a man of curious repute would die . [He]5473-a man of curious repute existed on unseen supplies ; for it was an anomalous thing that while there was hardly [a soul in [the neighbourhood]1758-the neighbourhood]5489-a soul in the neighbourhood but affected to laugh at [this man]542-this man 's assertions , uttering the formula , “[2603-we] There 's nothing in 'em , ” with full assurance on the surface of [their]5492-they faces , [very few of [them]5492-they]5493-very few of them were unbelievers in [their]5492-they secret hearts . Whenever [they]5492-they consulted [him]5473-a man of curious repute [they]5492-they did it “[2603-we] for a fancy . ” When [they]5492-they paid [him]5473-a man of curious repute [they]5492-they said , “[2603-we] Just a trifle for Christmas , ” or “[2603-we] Candlemas , ” as the case might be . [He]5473-a man of curious repute would have preferred more honesty in [[his]5473-a man of curious repute clients]5494-his clients , and less sham ridicule ; but fundamental belief consoled [him]5473-a man of curious repute for superficial irony . As stated , [he]5473-a man of curious repute was enabled to live ; [people]1161-people supported [him]5473-a man of curious repute with [their]1161-people backs turned . [He]5473-a man of curious repute was sometimes astonished that [men]4432-men could profess so little and believe so much at [[his]5473-a man of curious repute house]1329-his house , when at [church]1525-church [they]4432-men professed so much and believed so little . Behind [his]5473-a man of curious repute back [he]5473-a man of curious repute was called “[219-mr. ” fall] Wide - oh , ” on account of [his]5473-a man of curious repute reputation ; to [his]5473-a man of curious repute face “[219-mr. ” fall] [Mr. ” Fall]219-mr. ” fall . The hedge of [[his]5473-a man of curious repute garden]5499-his garden formed an arch over the entrance , and a door was inserted as in a wall . Outside the door [the tall traveller]5500-the tall traveller stopped , bandaged [his]5500-the tall traveller face with a handkerchief as if [he]5500-the tall traveller were suffering from toothache , and went up [the path]5501-the path . The window shutters were not closed , and [he]5500-the tall traveller could see [the prophet within]5502-the prophet within , preparing [his]5473-a man of curious repute supper . In answer to the knock [Fall]219-mr. ” fall came to the door , candle in hand . [The visitor]5265-the visitor stepped back a little from the light , and said , “[0-i] Can [I]0-i speak to ' [ee]2604-you ? ” in significant tones . [The other]338-the other 's invitation to come in was responded to by the country formula , “[0-i] This will do , thank ' ee , ” after which [the householder]5505-the householder had no alternative but to come out . [He]219-mr. ” fall placed the candle on the corner of the dresser , took [his]219-mr. ” fall hat from a nail , and joined [the stranger]2118-the stranger in [the porch]557-the porch , shutting the door behind [him]219-mr. ” fall . “[2604-you] [I]0-i 've long heard that [you]2604-you can — do things of a sort ? ” began [the other]338-the other , repressing [his]338-the other individuality as much as [he]338-the other could . “[120-henchard] Maybe so , [Mr. Henchard]120-henchard , ” said [the weather - caster]5509-the weather - caster . “[2604-you] Ah — why do [you]2604-you call [me]0-i that ? ” asked [the visitor]5265-the visitor with a start . “[2604-you] Because it 's [your]2604-you name . Feeling [you]2604-you 'd come [I]0-i 've waited for ' ee ; and thinking [you]2604-you might be leery from [your]2604-you walk [I]0-i laid two supper plates — look [ye]2604-you here . ” [He]0-i threw open the door and disclosed the supper - table , at which appeared a second chair , knife and fork , plate and mug , as [he]0-i had declared . [Henchard]120-henchard felt like [Saul]220-saul at [his]120-henchard reception by [Samuel]221-samuel wakely ; [he]120-henchard remained in silence for a few moments , then throwing off the disguise of frigidity which [he]120-henchard had hitherto preserved [he]120-henchard said , “[2604-you] Then [I]0-i have not come in vain .... Now , for instance , can [ye]2604-you charm away warts ? ” “[2604-you] Without trouble . ” “[2604-you] Cure the evil ? ” “[2604-you] That [I]0-i 've done — with consideration — if [they]2605-they will wear the toad - bag by night as well as by day . ” “[2604-you] Forecast the weather ? ” “[2604-you] With labour and time . ” “[2604-you] Then take this , ” said [Henchard]120-henchard . “[2606-five farmers] ' Tis a crownpiece . Now , what is the harvest fortnight to be ? When can [I]0-i know ? ' “ [I]2606-five farmers 've worked it out already , and [you]2604-you can know at once . ”[2606-five farmers] ( The fact was that [five farmers]2606-five farmers had already been [there]447-there on the same errand from [different parts of [the country]633-the country]2608-different parts of the country . ) “ By the sun , moon , and stars , by the clouds , the winds , the trees , and grass , the candle - flame and swallows , the smell of the herbs ; likewise by the cats ' eyes , the ravens , the leeches , the spiders , and the dungmixen , the last fortnight in August will be — rain and tempest . ”[2606-five farmers] “ [You]120-henchard are not certain , of course ? ”[2606-five farmers] “ As one can be in a world where all 's unsure . ' Twill be more like living in [Revelations]67-revelations this autumn than in [England]3-england . Shall [I]120-henchard sketch it out for ' ee in a scheme ? ”[120-henchard] “ O no , no , ”[120-henchard] said [Henchard]120-henchard . “ [I]222-wide - oh do n't altogether believe in forecasts , come to second thoughts on such . But [I]222-wide - oh — ”[222-wide - oh] “ [You]120-henchard do n't — [you]120-henchard do n't — ' tis quite understood , ”[222-wide - oh] said [Wide - oh]222-wide - oh , without a sound of scorn . “ [You]120-henchard have given [me]120-henchard a crown because [you]120-henchard 've one too many . But wo n't [you]120-henchard join [me]120-henchard at supper , now ' tis waiting and all ? ”[120-henchard] [Henchard]120-henchard would gladly have joined ; for the savour of the stew had floated from [the cottage]5487-the cottage into [the porch]557-the porch with such appetizing distinctness that the meat , the onions , the pepper , and the herbs could be severally recognized by [his]120-henchard nose . But as sitting down to hob - and - nob there would have seemed to mark [him]120-henchard too implicitly as [[the weather - caster]5509-the weather - caster 's apostle]2613-the weather - caster 's apostle , [he]120-henchard declined , and went [his]120-henchard way . The next Saturday [Henchard]120-henchard bought grain to such an enormous extent that there was quite a talk about [his]120-henchard purchases among [[his]120-henchard neighbours]2614-his neighbours [the lawyer]1820-the lawyer , [the wine merchant]2616-the wine merchant , and [the doctor]2617-the doctor ; also on the next , and on all available days . When [his]120-henchard granaries were full to choking all the weather - cocks of [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge creaked and set [their]2618-their faces in another direction , as if tired of [the south - west]2619-the south - west . The weather changed ; the sunlight , which had been like tin for weeks , assumed the hues of topaz . The temperament of [the welkin]2620-the welkin passed from the phlegmatic to the sanguine ; an excellent harvest was almost a certainty ; and as a consequence prices rushed down . All these transformations , lovely to [the outsider]2621-the outsider , to [the wrong - headed corn - dealer]2622-the wrong - headed corn - dealer were terrible . [He]120-henchard was reminded of what [he]120-henchard had well known before , that [a man]4474-a man might gamble upon the square green areas of [fields]2624-fields as readily as upon those of [a card - room]2625-a card - room . [Henchard]120-henchard had backed bad weather , and apparently lost . [He]120-henchard had mistaken the turn of the flood for the turn of the ebb . [His]120-henchard dealings had been so extensive that settlement could not long be postponed , and to settle [he]120-henchard was obliged to sell off corn that [he]120-henchard had bought only a few weeks before at figures higher by many shillings a quarter . Much of the corn [he]120-henchard had never seen ; it had not even been moved from the ricks in which it lay stacked miles away . Thus [he]120-henchard lost heavily . In the blaze of an early August day [he]120-henchard met [Farfrae]139-farfrae in [the market - place]1919-the market - place . [Farfrae]139-farfrae knew of [his]120-henchard dealings ( though [he]120-henchard did not guess [their]2627-their intended bearing on [himself]120-henchard ) and commiserated [him]120-henchard ; for since [their]2628-their exchange of words in [the South Walk]2629-the south walk [they]2628-their had been on stiffly speaking terms . [Henchard]120-henchard for the moment appeared to resent the sympathy ; but [he]120-henchard suddenly took a careless turn . “ Ho , no , no ! — nothing serious , [man]488-man ! ”[120-henchard] [he]120-henchard cried with fierce gaiety . “ These things always happen , do n't they ? [I]120-henchard know it has been said that figures have touched [me]120-henchard tight lately ; but is that anything rare ? The case is not so bad as [folk]5018-folk make out perhaps . And dammy , [a man]4474-a man must be [a fool to mind the common hazards of trade]5514-a fool to mind the common hazards of trade ! ”[120-henchard] But [he]120-henchard had to enter [the Casterbridge Bank]2630-the casterbridge bank that day for reasons which had never before sent [him]120-henchard [there]447-there — and to sit a long time in [[the partners]2632-the partners ' room]2633-the partners ' room with a constrained bearing . It was rumoured soon after that [much real property]2634-much real property as well as vast stores of produce , which had stood in [Henchard]120-henchard 's name in [the town]632-the town and [neighbourhood]2636-neighbourhood , was actually the possession of [[his]120-henchard bankers]2637-his bankers . Coming down the steps of [the bank]325-the bank [he]120-henchard encountered [Jopp]137-jopp . The gloomy transactions just completed within had added fever to the original sting of [Farfrae]139-farfrae 's sympathy that morning , which [Henchard]120-henchard fancied might be a satire disguised so that [Jopp]137-jopp met with anything but a bland reception . [The latter]4511-the latter was in the act of taking off [his]120-henchard hat to wipe [his]120-henchard forehead , and saying , “ A fine hot day , ”[120-henchard] to [an acquaintance]5403-an acquaintance . “ [You]137-jopp can wipe and wipe , and say , ' A fine hot day , ' can [ye]137-jopp ! ”[120-henchard] cried [Henchard]120-henchard in a savage undertone , imprisoning [Jopp]137-jopp between [himself]120-henchard and the bank wall . “ If it had n't been for [your]137-jopp blasted advice it might have been a fine day enough ! Why did [ye]137-jopp let [me]120-henchard go on , hey ? — when a word of doubt from [you]137-jopp or [anybody]4437-anybody would have made [me]120-henchard think twice ! For [you]137-jopp can never be sure of weather till ' tis past . ”[120-henchard] “ [My]120-henchard advice , [sir]4588-sir , was to do what [you]4588-sir thought best . ”[120-henchard] “ [A useful fellow]5517-a useful fellow ! And the sooner [you]137-jopp help [somebody else]5518-somebody else in that way the better ! ”[137-jopp] [Henchard]120-henchard continued [his]120-henchard address to [Jopp]137-jopp in similar terms till it ended in [Jopp]137-jopp 's dismissal there and then , [Henchard]120-henchard turning upon [his]120-henchard heel and leaving [him]137-jopp . “ [You]4588-sir shall be sorry for this , [sir]4588-sir ; sorry as [a man]4474-a man can be ! ”[120-henchard] said [Jopp]137-jopp , standing pale , and looking after [the corn - merchant]1288-the corn - merchant as [he]137-jopp disappeared in the crowd of [market - men hard by]2642-market - men hard by .

It was the eve of harvest . Prices being low [Farfrae]139-farfrae was buying . As was usual , after reckoning too surely on famine weather [the local farmers]2643-the local farmers had flown to the other extreme , and ( in [Farfrae]139-farfrae 's opinion ) were selling off too recklessly — calculating with just a trifle too much certainty upon an abundant yield . So [he]120-henchard went on buying old corn at its comparatively ridiculous price : for the produce of the previous year , though not large , had been of excellent quality . When [Henchard]120-henchard had squared [his]120-henchard affairs in a disastrous way , and got rid of [his]120-henchard burdensome purchases at a monstrous loss , the harvest began . There were three days of excellent weather , and then — “ What if [that curst conjuror]5521-that curst conjuror should be right after all ! ”[120-henchard] said [Henchard]120-henchard . The fact was , that no sooner had the sickles begun to play than the atmosphere suddenly felt as if cress would grow in it without other nourishment . It rubbed [people]1161-people 's cheeks like damp flannel when [they]1161-people walked abroad . There was a gusty , high , warm wind ; isolated raindrops starred the window - panes at remote distances : the sunlight would flap out like a quickly opened fan , throw the pattern of the window upon the floor of [the room]985-the room in a milky , colourless shine , and withdraw as suddenly as it had appeared . From that day and hour it was clear that there was not to be so successful an ingathering after all . If [Henchard]120-henchard had only waited long enough [he]120-henchard might at least have avoided loss though [he]120-henchard had not made a profit . But the momentum of [his]120-henchard character knew no patience . At this turn of the scales [he]120-henchard remained silent . The movements of [his]120-henchard mind seemed to tend to the thought that some power was working against [him]120-henchard . “ [I]120-henchard wonder , ”[120-henchard] [he]120-henchard asked [himself]120-henchard with eerie misgiving ; “ [I]120-henchard wonder if it can be that [somebody]4446-somebody has been roasting a waxen image of [me]120-henchard , or stirring an unholy brew to confound [me]120-henchard ! [I]120-henchard do n't believe in such power ; and yet — what if [they]4446-somebody should ha ' been doing it ! ”[120-henchard] Even [he]120-henchard could not admit that [the perpetrator]2646-the perpetrator , if any , might be [Farfrae]139-farfrae . These isolated hours of superstition came to [Henchard]120-henchard in time of moody depression , when all [his]120-henchard practical largeness of view had oozed out of [him]120-henchard . Meanwhile [Donald Farfrae]139-farfrae prospered . [He]120-henchard had purchased in so depressed [a market]2647-a market that the present moderate stiffness of prices was sufficient to pile for [him]120-henchard a large heap of gold where a little one had been . “ Why , [he]120-henchard 'll soon be [Mayor]1548-mayor ! ”[2666-farfrae 's waggoner] said [Henchard]120-henchard . It was indeed hard that [the speaker]803-the speaker should , of all others , have to follow the triumphal chariot of [this man]542-this man to [the Capitol]2650-the capitol . The rivalry of [the masters]2651-the masters was taken up by [the men]1681-the men . September - night shades had fallen upon [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge ; the clocks had struck half - past eight , and the moon had risen . [The streets of [the town]632-the town]2653-the streets of the town were curiously silent for such a comparatively early hour . A sound of jangling horse - bells and heavy wheels passed up [the street]797-the street . These were followed by angry voices outside [[Lucetta]214-lucetta 's house]2450-lucetta 's house , which led [her]214-lucetta and [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard to run to the windows , and pull up the blinds . [The neighbouring Market House]2657-the neighbouring market house and [Town Hall]2658-town hall abutted against [its]2657-the neighbouring market house next neighbour the Church except in the lower storey , where an arched thoroughfare gave admittance to [a large square called [Bull Stake]68-bull stake]2659-a large square called bull stake . A stone post rose in the midst , to which the oxen had formerly been tied for baiting with dogs to make [them]2660-them tender before [they]2660-them were killed in the adjoining shambles . In a corner stood the stocks . [The thoroughfare leading to [this spot]1420-this spot]2661-the thoroughfare leading to this spot was now blocked by two four - horse waggons and horses , [one laden with hay - trusses]2663-one laden with hay - trusses , [the leaders]2664-the leaders having already passed each other , and become entangled head to tail . The passage of [the vehicles]601-the vehicles might have been practicable if empty ; but built up with hay to the bedroom windows as one was , it was impossible . “ [You]191-henchard must have done it a ' purpose ! ”[2666-farfrae 's waggoner] said [[Farfrae]139-farfrae 's waggoner]2666-farfrae 's waggoner . “ [You]191-henchard can hear [my]2667-the wroth representative of henchard horses ' bells half - a - mile such a night as this ! ”[2667-the wroth representative of henchard] “ If ye'd been minding [your]191-henchard business instead of zwailing along in such a gawk - hammer way , [you]191-henchard would have zeed [me]214-lucetta ! ”[214-lucetta] retorted [the wroth representative of [Henchard]191-henchard]2667-the wroth representative of henchard . However , according to the strict rule of [the road]320-the road it appeared that [[Henchard]191-henchard 's man]2669-henchard 's man was most in the wrong , [he]2669-henchard 's man therefore attempted to back into [the High Street]759-the high street . In doing this the near hind - wheel rose against the churchyard wall and the whole mountainous load went over , two of the four wheels rising in the air , and the legs of the thill horse . Instead of considering how to gather up the load [the two men]2671-the two men closed in a fight with [their]2671-the two men fists . Before the first round was quite over [Henchard]191-henchard came upon the spot , [somebody]4446-somebody having run for [him]2669-henchard 's man . [Henchard]191-henchard sent [the two men]2671-the two men staggering in contrary directions by collaring one with each hand , turned to the horse that was down , and extricated [him]2669-henchard 's man after some trouble . [He]2669-henchard 's man then inquired into the circumstances ; and seeing the state of [his]2669-henchard 's man waggon and its load began hotly rating [[Farfrae]139-farfrae 's man]2674-farfrae 's man . [Lucetta]214-lucetta and [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard had by this time run down to [the street corner]5448-the street corner , whence [they]2671-the two men watched the bright heap of new hay lying in the moon 's rays , and passed and repassed by the forms of [Henchard]191-henchard and [the waggoners]2676-the waggoners . [The women]4997-the women had witnessed what [nobody else]4836-nobody else had seen — the origin of the mishap ; and [Lucetta]214-lucetta spoke . “ [I]214-lucetta saw it all , [Mr. Henchard]120-henchard , ”[214-lucetta] [she]214-lucetta cried ; “ and [[your]120-henchard man]4744-your man was most in the wrong ! ”[120-henchard] [Henchard]120-henchard paused in [his]120-henchard harangue and turned . “ Oh , [I]120-henchard did n't notice [you]214-lucetta , [Miss Templeman]203-miss templeman , ”[120-henchard] said [he]120-henchard . “ [[My]191-henchard man]5525-my man in the wrong ? Ah , to be sure ; to be sure ! But [I]191-henchard beg [your]214-lucetta pardon notwithstanding . [The other 's]5526-the other 's is [the empty waggon]5527-the empty waggon , and [he]5525-my man must have been most to blame for coming on . ”[191-henchard] “ No ; [I]191-henchard saw it , too , ”[191-henchard] said [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard . “ And [I]191-henchard can assure [you]214-lucetta [he]5525-my man could n't help it . ”[191-henchard] “ [You]191-henchard ca n't trust [THEIR]5528-their senses ! ”[191-henchard] murmured [[Henchard]191-henchard 's man]2669-henchard 's man . “ Why not ? ”[191-henchard] asked [Henchard]191-henchard sharply . “ Why , [you]191-henchard see , [sir]4588-sir , all [the women]4997-the women side with [Farfrae]139-farfrae — being [a damn young dand]5531-a damn young dand — of the sort that [he]5525-my man is — one that creeps into [a maid]5532-a maid 's heart like the giddying worm into a sheep 's brain — making crooked seem straight to [their]5528-their eyes ! ”[191-henchard] “ But do [you]191-henchard know who [that lady]1536-that lady is [you]191-henchard talk about in such a fashion ? Do [you]191-henchard know that [I]191-henchard pay [my]191-henchard attentions to [her]1536-that lady , and have for some time ? Just be careful ! ”[191-henchard] “ Not I. [I]191-henchard know nothing , [sir]4588-sir , outside eight shillings a week . ”[191-henchard] “ And that [Mr. Farfrae]149-farfrae is well aware of it ? [He]149-farfrae 's sharp in trade , but [he]149-farfrae would n't do anything so underhand as what [you]191-henchard hint at . ”[1288-the corn - merchant] Whether because [Lucetta]214-lucetta heard this low dialogue , or not [her]214-lucetta white figure disappeared from [her]214-lucetta doorway inward , and the door was shut before [Henchard]191-henchard could reach it to converse with [her]214-lucetta further . This disappointed [him]2680-him , for [he]2680-him had been sufficiently disturbed by what [the man]291-the man had said to wish to speak to [her]214-lucetta more closely . While pausing [the old constable]2682-the old constable came up . “ Just see that [nobody]298-nobody drives against that hay and waggon to - night , [Stubberd]223-stubberd , ”[1288-the corn - merchant] said [the corn - merchant]1288-the corn - merchant . “ [It]5536-it must bide till the morning , for all hands are in [the field]4499-the field still . And if [any coach]5538-any coach or [road - waggon]5539-road - waggon wants to come along , tell ['em]5540-'em [they]5539-road - waggon must go round by [the back street]5541-the back street , and be hanged to 'em .... Any case tomorrow up in [Hall]2206-hall ? ”[2682-the old constable] “ Yes , [sir]4588-sir . One in number , [sir]4588-sir . ”[2682-the old constable] “ Oh , what 's that ? ”[1288-the corn - merchant] “ [An old flagrant female]5545-an old flagrant female , [sir]4588-sir , swearing and committing a nuisance in a horrible profane manner against the church wall , [sir]4588-sir , as if ' twere no more than [a pot - house]5548-a pot - house ! That 's all , [sir]4588-sir . ”[2682-the old constable] “ Oh . [The Mayor]4556-the mayor 's out o [' town]4723-' town , is n't [he]4556-the mayor ? ”[2682-the old constable] “ [He]4556-the mayor is , [sir]4588-sir . ”[1288-the corn - merchant] “ Very well , then [I]191-henchard 'll be [there]447-there . Do n't forget to keep an eye on that hay . Good night t ' ' ee . ”[191-henchard] During those moments [Henchard]191-henchard had determined to follow up [Lucetta]214-lucetta notwithstanding [her]214-lucetta elusiveness , and [he]2684-he knocked for admission . The answer [he]2684-he received was an expression of [Miss Templeman]203-miss templeman 's sorrow at being unable to see [him]2684-he again that evening because [she]203-miss templeman had an engagement to go out . [Henchard]191-henchard walked away from the door to the opposite side of [the street]797-the street , and stood by [his]2684-he hay in a lonely reverie , [the constable]2686-the constable having strolled elsewhere , and the horses being removed . Though the moon was not bright as yet there were no lamps lighted , and [he]2684-he entered the shadow of one of the projecting jambs which formed [the thoroughfare to [Bull Stake]68-bull stake]2687-the thoroughfare to bull stake ; here [he]2684-he watched [Lucetta]214-lucetta 's door . Candle - lights were flitting in and out of [[her]214-lucetta bedroom]2688-her bedroom , and it was obvious that [she]214-lucetta was dressing for the appointment , whatever the nature of that might be at such an hour . The lights disappeared , the clock struck nine , and almost at the moment [Farfrae]149-farfrae came round the opposite corner and knocked . That [she]214-lucetta had been waiting just inside for [him]2684-he was certain , for [she]214-lucetta instantly opened the door [herself]214-lucetta . [They]2689-they went together by the way of [a back lane]2690-a back lane westward , avoiding [the front street]2691-the front street ; guessing where [they]2689-they were going [he]2684-he determined to follow . The harvest had been so delayed by the capricious weather that whenever a fine day occurred all sinews were strained to save what could be saved of the damaged crops . On account of the rapid shortening of the days [the harvesters]2692-the harvesters worked by moonlight . Hence to - night the wheat - fields abutting on the two sides of [the square formed by [Casterbridge town]2694-casterbridge town]2693-the square formed by casterbridge town were animated by [the gathering hands]2695-the gathering hands . [Their]2689-they shouts and laughter had reached [Henchard]191-henchard at [the Market House]1179-the market house , while [he]2684-he stood there waiting , and [he]2684-he had little doubt from the turn which [Farfrae]149-farfrae and [Lucetta]214-lucetta had taken that [they]2689-they were bound for [the spot]521-the spot . Nearly [the whole town]2698-the whole town had gone into [the fields]2699-the fields . [The Casterbridge populace]2700-the casterbridge populace still retained the primitive habit of helping [one another]5036-one another in time of need ; and thus , though the corn belonged to [the farming section of [the little community]2703-the little community — that inhabiting [the Durnover quarter]2704-the durnover quarter]2702-the farming section of the little community — that inhabiting the durnover quarter — [the remainder]2705-the remainder was no less interested in the labour of getting it [home]675-home . Reaching the top of [the lane]5182-the lane [Henchard]191-henchard crossed [the shaded avenue on the walls]2708-the shaded avenue on the walls , slid down [the green rampart]2709-the green rampart , and stood amongst the stubble . [The “ stitches ”[214-lucetta] or shocks]2710-the “ stitches ” or shocks rose like tents about [the yellow expanse]2711-the yellow expanse , those in the distance becoming lost in the moonlit hazes . [He]2684-he had entered at a point removed from the scene of immediate operations ; but [two others]2712-two others had entered at [that place]2713-that place , and [he]2684-he could see [them]2712-two others winding among the shocks . [They]2712-two others were paying no regard to the direction of [their]2712-two others walk , whose vague serpentining soon began to bear down towards [Henchard]120-henchard . A meeting promised to be awkward , and [he]2684-he therefore stepped into the hollow of the nearest shock , and sat down . “ [You]120-henchard have [my]214-lucetta leave , ”[214-lucetta] [Lucetta]214-lucetta was saying gaily . “ Speak what [you]120-henchard like . ”[149-farfrae] “ Well , then , ”[120-henchard] replied [Farfrae]149-farfrae , with the unmistakable inflection of the lover pure , which [Henchard]191-henchard had never heard in full resonance of [his]120-henchard lips before , “ [you]120-henchard are sure to be much sought after for [your]120-henchard position , wealth , talents , and beauty . But will [ye]120-henchard resist the temptation to be one of [those ladies with lots of [admirers]5555-admirers]5554-those ladies with lots of admirers — ay — and be content to have only [a homely one]5556-a homely one ? ”[214-lucetta] “ And [he]2684-he [the speaker]803-the speaker ? ”[214-lucetta] said [she]214-lucetta , laughing . “ Very well , [sir]4588-sir , what next ? ”[120-henchard] “ Ah ! [I]214-lucetta 'm afraid that what [I]214-lucetta feel will make [me]214-lucetta forget [my]214-lucetta manners ! ”[214-lucetta] “ Then [I]214-lucetta hope [you]120-henchard 'll never have any , if [you]120-henchard lack them only for that cause . ”[214-lucetta] After some broken words which [Henchard]191-henchard lost [she]214-lucetta added , “ Are [you]4588-sir sure [you]4588-sir wo n't be jealous ? ”[214-lucetta] [Farfrae]149-farfrae seemed to assure [her]214-lucetta that [he]149-farfrae would not , by taking [her]214-lucetta hand . “ [You]4588-sir are convinced , [Donald]139-farfrae , that [I]214-lucetta love [nobody else]4836-nobody else , ”[214-lucetta] [she]214-lucetta presently said . “ But [I]149-farfrae should wish to have [my]149-farfrae own way in some things . ”[149-farfrae] “ In everything ! What special thing did [you]4588-sir mean ? ”[191-henchard] “ If [I]214-lucetta wished not to live always in [Casterbridge]6-casterbridge , for instance , upon finding that [I]214-lucetta should not be happy [here]4417-here ? ”[214-lucetta] [Henchard]191-henchard did not hear the reply ; [he]149-farfrae might have done so and much more , but [he]149-farfrae did not care to play [the eavesdropper]2714-the eavesdropper . [They]2715-they went on towards the scene of activity , where the sheaves were being handed , a dozen a minute , upon [the carts]532-the carts and waggons which carried them away . [Lucetta]214-lucetta insisted on parting from [Farfrae]139-farfrae when [they]2715-they drew near [the workpeople]2717-the workpeople . [He]149-farfrae had some business with [them]2717-the workpeople , and , though [he]149-farfrae entreated [her]214-lucetta to wait a few minutes , [she]214-lucetta was inexorable , and tripped off homeward alone . [Henchard]191-henchard thereupon left [the field]4499-the field and followed [her]214-lucetta . [His]149-farfrae state of mind was such that on reaching [Lucetta]214-lucetta 's door [he]149-farfrae did not knock but opened it , and walked straight up to [[her]214-lucetta sitting - room]2719-her sitting - room , expecting to find [her]214-lucetta there . But [the room]985-the room was empty , and [he]149-farfrae perceived that in [his]149-farfrae haste [he]149-farfrae had somehow passed [her]214-lucetta on the way hither . [He]149-farfrae had not to wait many minutes , however , for [he]149-farfrae soon heard [her]214-lucetta dress rustling in [the hall]1877-the hall , followed by a soft closing of the door . In a moment [she]214-lucetta appeared . The light was so low that [she]214-lucetta did not notice [Henchard]191-henchard at first . As soon as [she]214-lucetta saw [him]149-farfrae [she]214-lucetta uttered a little cry , almost of terror . “ How can [you]149-farfrae frighten [me]214-lucetta so ? ”[214-lucetta] [she]214-lucetta exclaimed , with a flushed face . “ It is past ten o'clock , and [you]149-farfrae have no right to surprise [me]214-lucetta here at such a time . ”[214-lucetta] “ [I]214-lucetta do n't know that [I]214-lucetta 've not the right . At any rate [I]214-lucetta have the excuse . Is it so necessary that [I]214-lucetta should stop to think of manners and customs ? ”[214-lucetta] “ It is too late for propriety , and might injure [me]214-lucetta . ”[214-lucetta] “ [I]214-lucetta called an hour ago , and [you]149-farfrae would not see [me]214-lucetta , and [I]214-lucetta thought [you]149-farfrae were in when [I]214-lucetta called now . It is [you]149-farfrae , [Lucetta]214-lucetta , who are doing wrong . It is not proper in ' ee to throw [me]214-lucetta over like this . [I]214-lucetta have a little matter to remind [you]149-farfrae of , which [you]149-farfrae seem to forget . ”[214-lucetta] [She]214-lucetta sank into a chair , and turned pale . “ [I]2722-i do n't want to hear it — [I]2722-i do n't want to hear it ! ”[2722-i] [she]214-lucetta said through [her]214-lucetta hands , as [he]2722-i , standing close to the edge of [her]214-lucetta gown , began to allude to the Jersey days . “ But [you]214-lucetta ought to hear it , ”[2722-i] said [he]2722-i . “ It came to nothing ; and through [you]214-lucetta . Then why not leave [me]2723-i the freedom that [I]2723-i gained with such sorrow ! Had [I]2723-i found that [you]214-lucetta proposed to marry [me]2723-i for pure love [I]2723-i might have felt bound now . But [I]2723-i soon learnt that [you]214-lucetta had planned it out of mere charity — almost as an unpleasant duty — because [I]2723-i had nursed [you]214-lucetta , and compromised [myself]2723-i , and [you]214-lucetta thought [you]214-lucetta must repay [me]2723-i . After that [I]2723-i did not care for [you]214-lucetta so deeply as before . ”[2723-i] “ Why did [you]2722-i come here to find [me]2722-i , then ? ”[2722-i] “ [I]2723-i thought [I]2723-i ought to marry [you]214-lucetta for conscience ' sake , since [you]214-lucetta were free , even though [I]2723-i — did not like [you]214-lucetta so well . ”[2723-i] “ And why then do n't [you]2722-i think so now ? ”[2723-i] [She]2723-i was silent . It was only too obvious that conscience had ruled well enough till new love had intervened and usurped that rule . In feeling this [she]2723-i [herself]2723-i forgot for the moment [her]2723-i partially justifying argument — that having discovered [Henchard]191-henchard 's infirmities of temper , [she]2723-i had some excuse for not risking [her]2723-i happiness in [his]2724-his hands after once escaping [them]2725-them . The only thing [she]2723-i could say was , “ [I]2723-i was [a poor girl]5561-a poor girl then ; and now [my]2723-i circumstances have altered , so [I]2723-i am hardly [the same person]5562-the same person . ”[2723-i] “ That 's true . And it makes the case awkward for [me]2723-i . But [I]2723-i do n't want to touch [your]214-lucetta money . [I]2723-i am quite willing that every penny of [your]214-lucetta property shall remain to [your]214-lucetta personal use . Besides , that argument has nothing in it . [The man [you]214-lucetta are thinking of]5563-the man you are thinking of is no better than [I.]2723-i ”[2723-i] “ If [you]191-henchard were as good as [he]5563-the man you are thinking of [you]191-henchard would leave [me]2726-me ! ”[2726-me] [she]2723-i cried passionately . This unluckily aroused [Henchard]191-henchard . “ [You]2723-i can not in honour refuse [me]2726-me , ”[2726-me] [he]2726-me said . “ And unless [you]2723-i give [me]2726-me [your]2723-i promise this very night to be [[my]2726-me wife]4821-my wife , before [a witness]5565-a witness , [I]2726-me 'll reveal [our]5566-our intimacy — in common fairness to [other men]5567-other men ! ”[2726-me] A look of resignation settled upon [her]2723-i . [Henchard]191-henchard saw its bitterness ; and had [Lucetta]214-lucetta 's heart been given to [any other man in [the world]4424-the world]2727-any other man in the world than Farfrae [he]2726-me would probably have had pity upon [her]2723-i at that moment . But [the supplanter]2729-the supplanter was the upstart ( as [Henchard]191-henchard called [him]2729-the supplanter ) who had mounted into prominence upon [his]2729-the supplanter shoulders , and [he]2729-the supplanter could bring [himself]2729-the supplanter to show no mercy . Without another word [she]2723-i rang the bell , and directed that [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard should be fetched from [[her]191-henchard room]1935-her room . [The latter]4511-the latter appeared , surprised in the midst of [her]191-henchard lucubrations . As soon as [she]2723-i saw [Henchard]191-henchard [she]2723-i went across to [him]2726-me dutifully . “ [Elizabeth]191-henchard - [Jane]191-henchard , ”[2726-me] [he]2726-me said , taking [her]2723-i hand , “ [I]2726-me want [you]2723-i to hear this . ”[2726-me] And turning to [Lucetta]214-lucetta : “ Will [you]2726-me , or will [you]2726-me not , marry [me]214-lucetta ? “[214-lucetta] If [you]2726-me — wish it , [I]0-i must agree ! ” “[214-lucetta] [You]214-lucetta say yes ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do . ” No sooner had [she]214-lucetta given the promise than [she]214-lucetta fell back in a fainting state . “[4491-father] What dreadful thing drives [her]2723-i to say this , [father]4491-father , when it is such a pain to [her]2723-i ? ” asked [Elizabeth]191-henchard , kneeling down by [Lucetta]214-lucetta . “[0-i] Do n't compel [her]2723-i to do anything against [her]2723-i will ! [I]0-i have lived with [her]2723-i , and know that [she]2723-i can not bear much . ” “[0-i] Do n't be [a no'thern simpleton]2733-a no'thern simpleton ! ” said [Henchard]191-henchard drily . “[2734-him] This promise will leave [him]2734-him free for [you]214-lucetta , if [you]214-lucetta want [him]2734-him , wo n't it ? ” At this [Lucetta]214-lucetta seemed to wake from [her]214-lucetta swoon with a start . “[298-nobody] [Him]2734-him ? Who are [you]4491-father talking about ? ” [she]214-lucetta said wildly . “[298-nobody] [Nobody]298-nobody , as far as [I]0-i am concerned , ” said [Elizabeth]191-henchard firmly . “[0-i] Oh — well . Then it is [my]0-i mistake , ” said [Henchard]191-henchard . “[203-miss templeman] But the business is between [me]0-i and [Miss Templeman]203-miss templeman . [She]203-miss templeman agrees to be [[my]0-i wife]4821-my wife . ” “[0-i] But do n't dwell on it just now , ” entreated [Elizabeth]191-henchard , holding [Lucetta]214-lucetta 's hand . “[203-miss templeman] [I]0-i do n't wish to , if [she]203-miss templeman promises , ” said [Henchard]191-henchard . “[0-i] [I]0-i have , [I]0-i have , ” groaned [Lucetta]214-lucetta , [her]214-lucetta limbs hanging like fluid , from very misery and faintness . “[0-i] [Michael]120-henchard , please do n't argue it any more ! ” “[0-i] [I]0-i will not , ” [he]0-i said . And taking up [his]0-i hat [he]0-i went away . [Elizabeth - Jane]191-henchard continued to kneel by [Lucetta]214-lucetta . “[120-henchard] What is this ? ” [she]191-henchard said . “[120-henchard] [You]120-henchard called [[my]0-i father]5103-my father ' [Michael]120-henchard ' as if [you]120-henchard knew [him]120-henchard well ? And how is it [he]120-henchard has got this power over [you]120-henchard , that [you]120-henchard promise to marry [him]120-henchard against [your]120-henchard will ? Ah — [you]120-henchard have many many secrets from [me]0-i ! ” “[120-henchard] Perhaps [you]120-henchard have some from [me]0-i , ” [Lucetta]214-lucetta murmured with closed eyes , little thinking , however , so unsuspicious was [she]214-lucetta , that the secret of [Elizabeth]191-henchard 's heart concerned [the young man who had caused this damage to [her]191-henchard own]5568-the young man who had caused this damage to her own . “[0-i] [I]0-i would not — do anything against [you]0-i at all ! ” stammered [Elizabeth]191-henchard , keeping in all signs of emotion till [she]191-henchard was ready to burst . “[0-i] [I]0-i can not understand how [[my]0-i father]5103-my father can command [you]0-i so ; [I]0-i do n't sympathize with [him]5103-my father in it at all . [I]0-i 'll go to [him]5103-my father and ask [him]5103-my father to release [you]0-i . ” “[0-i] No , no , ” said [Lucetta]214-lucetta . “[0-i] Let it all be . ”[5103-my father]

The next morning [Henchard]191-henchard went to [the Town Hall below [Lucetta]214-lucetta 's house]2739-the town hall below lucetta 's house , to attend [Petty Sessions]69-petty sessions , being still [a magistrate]2740-a magistrate for the year by virtue of [his]5103-my father late position as [Mayor]1548-mayor . In passing [he]5103-my father looked up at [her]214-lucetta windows , but nothing of [her]214-lucetta was to be seen . [Henchard]191-henchard as [a Justice of the Peace]2742-a justice of the peace may at first seem to be an even greater incongruity than [Shallow]224-shallow and Silence [themselves]2743-themselves . But [his]5103-my father rough and ready perceptions , [his]5103-my father sledge - hammer directness , had often served [him]5103-my father better than nice legal knowledge in despatching such simple business as fell to [his]5103-my father hands in [this Court]2744-this court . To - day [Dr. Chalkfield]225-dr. chalkfield , [the Mayor]4556-the mayor for the year , being absent , [the corn - merchant]1288-the corn - merchant took the big chair , [his]1288-the corn - merchant eyes still abstractedly stretching out of the window to the ashlar front of [High - Place Hall]58-high - place hall . There was one case only , and [the offender]2747-the offender stood before [him]5103-my father . [She]214-lucetta was [an old woman of mottled countenance , attired in a shawl of that nameless tertiary hue which comes , but can not be made]2748-an old woman of mottled countenance , attired in a shawl of that nameless tertiary hue which comes , but can not be made — a hue neither tawny , russet , hazel , nor ash ; a sticky black bonnet that seemed to have been worn in [the country of [the Psalmist]2750-the psalmist where the clouds drop fatness]2749-the country of the psalmist where the clouds drop fatness ; and an apron that had been white in time so comparatively recent as still to contrast visibly with the rest of [her]214-lucetta clothes . The steeped aspect of [the woman as a whole]2751-the woman as a whole showed [her]214-lucetta to be [no native of [the country - side]2753-the country - side or even of [a country - town]2754-a country - town]2752-no native of the country - side or even of a country - town . [She]214-lucetta looked cursorily at [Henchard]191-henchard and [the second magistrate]2755-the second magistrate , and [Henchard]191-henchard looked at [her]214-lucetta , with a momentary pause , as if [she]214-lucetta had reminded [him]5103-my father indistinctly of [somebody]4446-somebody or something which passed from [his]5103-my father mind as quickly as it had come . “ Well , and what has [she]214-lucetta been doing ? ”[223-stubberd] [he]5103-my father said , looking down at the charge sheet . “ [She]214-lucetta is charged , [sir]4588-sir , with the offence of disorderly female and nuisance , ”[2757-the other magistrate] whispered [Stubberd]223-stubberd . “ Where did [she]214-lucetta do that ? ”[2757-the other magistrate] said [the other magistrate]2757-the other magistrate . “ By [the church]552-the church , [sir]4588-sir , of [all the horrible places in [the world]4424-the world]5572-all the horrible places in the world ! — [I]191-henchard caught [her]214-lucetta in the act , [[your]4588-sir worship]5574-your worship . ”[191-henchard] “ Stand back then , ”[191-henchard] said [Henchard]191-henchard , “ and let 's hear what [you]4588-sir 've got to say . ”[2686-the constable] [Stubberd]223-stubberd was sworn in , [[the magistrate]2758-the magistrate 's clerk]2759-the magistrate 's clerk dipped [his]2759-the magistrate 's clerk pen , [Henchard]191-henchard being [no note - taker [himself]191-henchard]2760-no note - taker himself , and [the constable]2686-the constable began — “ Hearing a ' illegal noise [I]223-stubberd went down [the street]797-the street at twenty - five minutes past eleven P.M. on the night of the fifth instinct , [Hannah Dominy]226-hannah dominy . When [I]223-stubberd had — “[223-stubberd] Do n't go so fast , [Stubberd]223-stubberd , ” said [the clerk]5576-the clerk . [The constable]2686-the constable waited , with [his]2686-the constable eyes on [the clerk]5576-the clerk 's pen , till [the latter]4511-the latter stopped scratching and said , “[223-stubberd] yes . ” [Stubberd]223-stubberd continued : “[0-i] When [I]0-i had proceeded to the spot [I]0-i saw defendant at another spot , namely , the gutter . ” [He]223-stubberd paused , watching the point of [the clerk]5576-the clerk 's pen again . “[223-stubberd] Gutter , yes , [Stubberd]223-stubberd . ” “[0-i] Spot measuring twelve feet nine inches or thereabouts from where [I]0-i — ” Still careful not to outrun [the clerk]5576-the clerk 's penmanship [Stubberd]223-stubberd pulled up again ; for having got [his]223-stubberd evidence by heart it was immaterial to [him]223-stubberd whereabouts [he]223-stubberd broke off . “[0-i] [I]0-i object to that , ” spoke up [the old woman]4510-the old woman , “[0-i] ' spot measuring twelve feet nine or thereabouts from where [I]0-i , ' is not sound testimony ! ” [The magistrates]5583-the magistrates consulted , and [the second one]5584-the second one said that the bench was of opinion that twelve feet nine inches from [a man on [his]5585-a man on his oath oath]5585-a man on his oath was admissible . [Stubberd]223-stubberd , with a suppressed gaze of victorious rectitude at [the old woman]4510-the old woman , continued : “[2762-she] Was standing [myself]0-i .
